sense.def: a large bag made of paper, plastic, or cloth and used to carry or store things
dictionaryExamples: a burlap/plastic sack
sacks of rice/flour/potatoes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The worst thing was with [tra]sh, which wasn't collected. People in [the area], special groups, used big bags and sacks to gather it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: relating to a religion or considered to be holy
dictionaryExamples: sacred music
a sacred object
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a volcanic island which has been enshrined as a sacred place. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: too important to be changed or destroyed
dictionaryExamples: I don't work on weekends - my private time is sacred.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The old sweatshop has no appeal, and even many well-paid extra hours are rejected in order to preserve one's most sacred thing: free time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: something valuable that you give up in order to achieve something or help someone, or the act of giving it up
dictionaryExamples: We had to make sacrifices in order to pay for our children's education.
They cared for their disabled son for 27 years, at great personal sacrifice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a small sacrifice but I think that it will serve him [well] in the long run. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to give up something that is valuable to you in order to achieve something or help someone
dictionaryExamples: Many women sacrifice interesting careers for their family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are very proud of our low costs [...], a pleasing fact primarily based upon a large number of volunteers who sacrifice their spare time in our organisation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: unhappy or making you feel unhappy
dictionaryExamples: I've just received some very sad news.
She gave a sad smile.
It's sad (that) the trip had to be canceled.
I'm so sad (that) you can't come.
It's sad to see them leave.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We like this park because there [are] a lot of place to walk, and play.  In England I'[ve] not found [a] similar place, so I'm sad. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to say that it is unfortunate or embarrassing that something is true
dictionaryExamples: Sad to say, the violin was never found.
Yes, sad to say, I've seen the movie fifteen times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sad to say, there are many points in your report we do not agree with, as pointed by my friend Maria Jones as well. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: to make someone feel sad or disappointed
dictionaryExamples: We were saddened by his death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They have a right to be consulted about their future: nothing saddens me more than a father sending his son (who dreams about becoming a painter) to the School of Law because that is "the best for him" or "that's what I always wanted to do" or, the worst of all, "you will study such-and-such because I say so!" Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a leather seat that you put on a horse so that you can ride it
dictionaryExamples: Can you help me fasten the saddle?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't like to use a saddle, I just put a sheep skin on the back of my horse and jumped on it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to put a saddle on a horse
dictionaryExamples: We saddled our horses and rode off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to climb to my father's shoulders to see the horses, and then realized that they hadn't been saddled. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to give someone a job or problem which will cause them a lot of work or difficulty
dictionaryExamples: We're saddled with a lot of debt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People go on shopping sprees and are then saddled with huge credit card bills. International English Language Testing System; C2; Marathi

sense.def: in an unhappy way
dictionaryExamples: "He's gone away for six months," she said sadly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Alice quickly got in the car and waved sadly at her parents while Natalie drove off. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: in a way that is not satisfactory
dictionaryExamples: Sadly, the treatment doesn't work for all patients.
If you think she'll let you do that, you're sadly  mistaken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some forms of entertainment which were popular decades ago have, sadly, disappeared. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: being sad
dictionaryExamples: Her sadness at her grandfather's death was obvious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What can be more real that when your lover is gone or taken away, your own soul is also alone, bitter and dark and there is nothing else than feelings of rev[e]nge, anger, frustration and sadness? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not in danger or likely to be harmed
dictionaryExamples: In some cities you don't feel safe going out alone at night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this place because I feel safe there. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: not dangerous or likely to cause harm
dictionaryExamples: a safe driver
That ladder doesn't look safe.
Have a safe trip.
Is this medicine safe for children?
It's safe to cross the road now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Have [a] safe journey, and I will meet you at the Airport.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Indonesian

sense.def: not harmed or damaged
dictionaryExamples: She said that all the hostages were safe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly I felt something strange near me, I turn[ed] back quickly and two men were there. They showed me their weapons. Then, I woke up safe in my bed.  Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not involving much risk
dictionaryExamples: Salmon is a safe choice  - most people like it.
He told us this a safe investment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, I could have chosen to stay in my town and start [at] the University. It would be the recommended and most appropriate choice. I would get my degree and start a normal and safe career. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If it is safe to say something, you are sure it is correct.
dictionaryExamples: I think it's safe to say that he'll be the next president.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is probably safe to say that there are no good books about engineering written in Portuguese so my teachers always use books written in English. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a place where something will not be lost or stolen
dictionaryExamples: It's very valuable so put it somewhere safe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Don't show off your money but keep it in a safe place. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: being cared for or dealt with by someone skilled
dictionaryExamples: The project is in safe hands - Jan has lots of experience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has also been trained as a lifeguard so the residents of your hotel would probably be in safe hands. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: completely safe and without injury or damage
dictionaryExamples: After three days lost in the mountains, all the climbers arrived home safe and sound.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, by the time you read this letter I'll probably be safe and sound in Liverpool. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: something that you are certain will happen
dictionaryExamples: Wheeler is a safe bet for a place on the team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Automatically, we think that black is a safe bet for any occasion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: in a safe way
dictionaryExamples: We all arrived safely.
Drive safely!
Are the children safely fastened into their car seats?
I think we can safely  say they won't find us now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend has come back safely and now a new life [starts for him]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the state of being safe, or a place or situation where someone or something is safe
dictionaryExamples: food/road safety
Fire officials worry about the safety of those heaters.
For your (comfort and) safety, we recommend you keep your seat belt loosely fastened during the flight.
Journalists may enter the danger zone but unfortunately we cannot guarantee their safety.
They all ran/dived for safety behind trees.
Police are concerned for the safety of  the five-year-old.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We heard from the news, all the disasters that the hurr[i]cane "Gilbert" had left while passing by in other States of Mexico.  We were really worried about our safety. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: how safe something is
dictionaryExamples: Safety at the factory has been improved.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Safety regulations: Ten years ago, regulations on working did not exist. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to control a boat that has no engine and is pushed by the wind
dictionaryExamples: He sailed the dinghy up the river.
She sailed around the world solo in her yacht.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, we are going to the beach where some sail[o]rs are going to teach us how to sail. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to travel somewhere on a boat or a ship
dictionaryExamples: We sailed to New York.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know, I've got a boat and if you want, we will be able to spend five days on it. We will sail to the Channel Islands (Jersey, Guernsey, Sark...) . Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: When a boat or a ship sails, it travels on the water.
dictionaryExamples: The ship was sailing to China.
The boat sailed along/down the coast.
As the ship sailed by/past, everyone on deck waved.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I started the film and we could all see a ship sailing towards the camera. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a large piece of material that is fixed to a pole on a boat to catch the wind and make the boat move
dictionaryExamples: Our boat has a yellow sail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surrounded by swooping birds and the distant moos of the cows, the billowing sails would sen[d] us off with the wind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to start a trip on a boat or ship
dictionaryExamples: We set sail for home the next day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What made things turn from gr[a]y to black was that soon after my return I was invited to set sail to the Spanish islands. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a sport using boats with sails
dictionaryExamples: a sailing boat
We're going sailing next weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She wants to show me how to do canoeing and sailing. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: someone who sails ships or boats as their job or as a sport
dictionaryExamples: Over 100 sailors took part in the race.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is a sailor. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: a dead person who has been officially respected by the Christian church for living their life in a holy way
dictionaryExamples: Catherine of Siena was made a saint in 1461.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were originally a mixture of a pagan and a religious feast related to [the] worshipping of two saints: St Antony in Lisbon and St. John in Porto. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a cold mixture of vegetables that usually have not been cooked, sometimes eaten with meat, cheese, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a salad bowl
Serve the risotto with a mixed salad.
Toss  the salad with oil and vinegar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What about a vegetable salad, [...] fried potatoes and chicken with beer? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a fixed amount of money that you receive from your employer, usually every month
dictionaryExamples: an annual salary of $50,000
His net monthly salary is $3500.
She has quite a good/decent salary in her present job.
He took a drop in  salary when he changed jobs.
a 10 percent salary increase
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was my boss [who] said "I'm in Australia, and I can't read my e-mail, the server at work crashed. Please repair it today and I will double your salary." Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: someone whose job is selling things
dictionaryExamples: I asked the salesman for advice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sad to say, I have not applied for it again but I did apply for another job as a salesman. First Certificate in English; B2; Malay

sense.def: someone whose job is selling things in a store
dictionaryExamples: She's a salesperson at a book store.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my previous job, I was [a] salesperson, where I used to deal with many, many people [and] I can guarantee my skill to manage with people is extraordinar[ily] good and I am prep[a]red to work under pres[s]ure. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone whose job is selling things
dictionaryExamples: The saleswoman showed me the car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many years ago, when I was seventeen, I was working as a saleswoman [for] a print[er]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a large, silver fish, or the pink meat of this fish
dictionaryExamples: fresh/smoked/canned salmon
salmon fishing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My favorite restaurant is Pampa Grill. My favorite food [there] is the salmon, it's delicious. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a place where women have their hair cut and put in a style
dictionaryExamples: a beauty/hair salon
My hairdresser opened her own salon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I want to [take a] beauty course because I've got my own beauty salon. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Panjabi

sense.def: a white substance used to add flavor to food
dictionaryExamples: salt and pepper
Pass the salt, please.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But before, you put on the top of [the] chicken salt and pepper or [a] piece of bacon. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak

sense.def: tasting of or containing salt
dictionaryExamples: Is the soup too salty?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, [the] Western one gave [good] service but [the] food was oily and salty. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a small number of people from a larger group that is being tested or considered
dictionaryExamples: a random sample of voters
a nationally representative sample of 200 schools
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This report is based on a sample of over 50 students. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a small amount of something that shows you what it is like
dictionaryExamples: a free sample of chocolate
She brought in some samples of her work.
samples of carpet/curtain material

sense.def: a small amount of a substance that a doctor or scientist collects in order to examine it
dictionaryExamples: a blood/urine sample
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had taken blood samples, listened to her lungs and heart but nothing seemed to be wrong with her a[par]t from the fact that she couldn't move her legs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to experience a place or an activity, often for the first time
dictionaryExamples: an opportunity to sample the local night life
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having said that, the recent recession in Japan ha[s] caused a drop in prices and I consider this is the best time to set up a new program to send students to Japan to allow them [to] sample the culture and brush up their language ability. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a punishment for not obeying a rule or a law
dictionaryExamples: economic/trade sanctions against a country
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The war effort and the US sanctions have led the economy to distress too. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a substance that is found on beaches and in deserts, which is made from very small grains of rock
dictionaryExamples: a grain of sand
The children played all day in the sand.
coarse/fine sand
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We got to a bea[uti]ful beach. The sand looked like gold. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a light shoe with straps that you wear in warm weather
dictionaryExamples: a pair of sandals
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In summer, I wear skirts and sandals. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: two slices of bread with meat, cheese, etc. between them
dictionaryExamples: a tuna/cheese sandwich
sandwich fillings
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can make a quick snack, for example a sandwich. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: covered with or containing sand
dictionaryExamples: a sandy beach
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have no mountains in Lithuania, but we have sandy beaches at [the] seaside. Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: not suffering from mental illness
dictionaryExamples: Psychiatrists pronounced her sane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On these occasions I would yell at him for no reason at all and my family started wondering whether I was completely sane. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: using sarcasm
dictionaryExamples: a sarcastic comment/remark
Are you being sarcastic?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to learn how to be more assertive, find emotional independence, fulfil[l] my dreams, be more tolerant, less sarcastic and, most importantly be given the precious gift of patience. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a piece of equipment that is sent into space around the Earth to receive and send signals or to collect information
dictionaryExamples: The World Cup was transmitted around the world by satellite.
satellite television/TV
a TV/weather satellite
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To balance this, technology has developed a lot in the last decades and now people can have wild animal[s] inside their homes, [even though] they may be locked up on a CD-Rom or coming in a wave format through the satellite dish. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a pleasant feeling that you get when you receive something you wanted, or when you have done something you wanted to do
dictionaryExamples: She looked at the finished painting with satisfaction.
She got great satisfaction from/out of helping other people.
For me, job satisfaction is more important than the money.
She had the satisfaction of knowing that she'd done everything she could.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whatever it [is], it must give us satisfaction. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: as well as someone wants
dictionaryExamples: He won't get paid until he completes the job to my satisfaction.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I do hope that you will settle this matter to everybod[y’]s satisfaction within a couple of days. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: in a satisfactory way
dictionaryExamples: I'm sure these problems can be satisfactorily resolved.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of the students were not happy with the type of job they had or with the people they lived with, but the purpose for which they went there was satisfactorily accomplished as the students reached most of the goals that took them to follow this plan. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: good enough
dictionaryExamples: We hope very much to find a satisfactory  solution to the problem.
The teachers seem to think his work is satisfactory.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The service is satisfactory. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: pleased because you have got what you wanted, or because something has happened in the way that you wanted
dictionaryExamples: Some people are never satisfied!
a satisfied smile
Are you satisfied with the new arrangement?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must say that I'm very satisfied with [the club]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: If you are satisfied that something is true, you believe it.
dictionaryExamples: The judge was satisfied that she was telling the truth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suppose that is only because they are satisfied that other [people] than the British can strike. Well, you don't need to worry! [The] following has happened; about 20% of the Swedish nurses have been striking. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to please someone by giving them what they want or need
dictionaryExamples: They have 31 flavors of ice cream - enough to satisfy everyone!
Come on, satisfy my curiosity, what happened last night?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But how can anyone satisfy a wealthy woman like her without giving her an expensive present? First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to have or provide something that is needed or wanted
dictionaryExamples: She satisfies all the requirements for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In general, the conference satisfied my needs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the day of the week after Friday and before Sunday
dictionaryExamples: He's leaving on Saturday.
Most of our swim meets are held on Saturdays.
Joel was born on a Saturday.
last/next Saturday
Saturday morning/afternoon/evening
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is [a] swim[m]ing pool, so I go there every Saturday after lunch. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: a thick hot or cold liquid eaten with food to add flavor
dictionaryExamples: a hot/sweet sauce
tomato sauce
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It will be rice and chicken with [a] sweet and sour sauce, so if you want you can bring some wine. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a small plate that you put under a cup
dictionaryExamples: a cup and saucer
She gave the cat a saucer of milk.

sense.def: a mixture of meat and spices pressed into a long tube
dictionaryExamples: fried/grilled sausages
sliced garlic sausage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They usually prepare traditional Polish food like cabbage with mushrooms and sausages. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: to keep money so that you can buy something with it in the future
dictionaryExamples: Michael's saving up for a new computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I had to save a lot of money. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to keep something to use in the future
dictionaryExamples: I've saved some food for you.
She saved her black dress for special occasions.
I save all my old letters in case I want to read them again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you don't mind, please save it for me until I come your house at 8:30 p.m. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: to make sure that a computer keeps information that you have put on it
dictionaryExamples: Make sure you save your files regularly.
I saved the photos in the family folder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need my laptop because I saved my school project [o]n it. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: to prevent time, money or effort being wasted or spent
dictionaryExamples: You'll save time if you take the car.
Thanks for your help - it saved me a lot of work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If both schools are similar, you should choose the one nearest [to] your new house, in order that you save money and time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to stop someone or something from being killed, injured or destroyed
dictionaryExamples: Wearing seat belts has saved many lives.
He fell in the river but his friend saved him from drowning.
He had to borrow money to save his business.
He was desperately trying to save their failing marriage.
We all need to do our part to save the planet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We watched a movie called "Men in Black II" and it was about two guys that save the world from alien attacks. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to help someone avoid having to do something
dictionaryExamples: We'll eat in a restaurant - it'll save you having to cook.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Building a new supermarket along with a multi-storey car park will save city dwellers from having to travel to the sub[u]rbs to buy what they need. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the money that you keep in a bank or similar financial organization
dictionaryExamples: He spent all his savings on an expensive car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also spent all my savings [o]n executive-looking clothes. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: an amount of money you save because you were able to spend  less
dictionaryExamples: You can renew your membership now for only $40, a savings of 20%.
a $10 savings
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: “Switching off lights when not required at home” can make a big difference if everyone follows it. Not only just [because] it gives personal savings, but [it] also contributes to decreasing global warming. International English Language Testing System; C1; Pushtu

sense.def: to speak words
dictionaryExamples: "I'd like to go home," she said.
How do you say this word?
She said goodbye to all her friends and left.
"How do you say 'goodbye' in French?"
I couldn't hear what they were saying.
Do you know what she said to him?
I've got something to say to you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I['m] speaking in class, I'm very nervous and I can't say anything. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to tell someone about a fact, thought, or opinion
dictionaryExamples: Did she say where she was going?
Officials refused to say what had happened.
What did they say about the house?
The doctors say (that) it will take him a few weeks to recover.
She didn't say whether she was coming or not.
"Who do you think will get the job?" "I'd rather not say."
What are you saying, exactly ?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mary, You asked me in your last letter about my bedroom. There aren't a lot of things to say about it, it is quite small but nice. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to give information in writing, numbers or signs
dictionaryExamples: My watch says 3 o'clock.
Can you read what that notice says?
It says in the paper (that) they've found the man who did it.
It says on the bottle to take the medicine three times a day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well yesterday I was reading a new fashion magazine. It says that this summer the best clothes to wear are skirts with different colors! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to think or believe
dictionaryExamples: People/They say (that) he's over 100.
"It's going to be a very hot summer." "So they say ."
She is a firm leader, too firm, some might say.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People say that it never rains here. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: used to show that many people believe something about something
dictionaryExamples: Drinking plenty of water is said to be good for your skin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On our way around the lake we would have [the] possibility of visiting a huge medieval castle which is said to be haunted. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: If something goes without saying, it is obvious or generally accepted.
dictionaryExamples: It goes without saying that you should arrive on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It goes without saying that I will participate! First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to think something but not speak
dictionaryExamples: "I hope she likes me," he said to himself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I remember saying to myself that "this little boy will survive" and after that I felt totally cool and calm and did what had to be done. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: used to remind someone that you said this earlier
dictionaryExamples: Like I said, I’m not interested in buying insurance at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wonder if it's not too late for my own little munchkins.  Like I said, they already love to SHOP! International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: used to say that it is unfortunate or embarrassing that something is true
dictionaryExamples: Sad to say, the violin was never found.
Yes, sad to say, I've seen the movie fifteen times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sad to say, there are many points in your report we do not agree with, as pointed [out] by my friend Maria Jones as well. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: used to emphasize that you could have said something in a much stronger way
dictionaryExamples: We were surprised, to say the least.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You get slightly bored, to say the least. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: as you would expect
dictionaryExamples: Needless to say, it rained the whole time we were there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Needless to say, bribes are a frequent occur[r]ence. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: used to say that something seems like a good idea but it would be difficult to do
dictionaryExamples: I want to ask her out, but it's easier said than done.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know it's easier said than done but you have to try. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: If it is safe to say something, you are sure it is correct.
dictionaryExamples: I think it's safe to say that he'll be the next president.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is probably safe to say that there are no good books about engineering written in Portuguese so my teachers always use books written in English. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to emphasize other problems you have not talked about
dictionaryExamples: Most wild otters have disappeared from populated areas, to say nothing of wilderness areas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed would not it be an oversimplification to make one's judgement of the country's national character on the grounds of the amount and the quality of food people eat, to say nothing of the fact that this judgement is usually highly subjective? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a famous phrase that people use to give advice about life
dictionaryExamples: Have you heard the saying "Don't count your chickens before they're hatched"?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But as the saying goes "Time flies when you are having fun". Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the size or level of something
dictionaryExamples: We don't yet know the scale of the problem.
The blackout caused rush-hour travel disruptions on a massive scale.
My parents used to entertain friends on a large/small scale.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He leads an evil trade: they [carry out] smuggling on a grand scale and use the inn as a store. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a set of numbers, amounts, etc., used to measure or compare the level of something
dictionaryExamples: the Centigrade/Fahrenheit scale
How would you rate his work on a scale of 1 to 5?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In brief, I think it would be a very good idea to create a new scale of [salaries] based on our needs, in which doctors would be [higher] than professional footballer [player]s. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: how the size of things on a map, model, etc. relates to the same things in real life
dictionaryExamples: a scale of 1:50 000
This map is large scale.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My f[ri]end gave me a 1/72 scale kit of "Supermarine Spitfire" for my birthday. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a piece of equipment for measuring weight
dictionaryExamples: A kitchen/bathroom scale

sense.def: to use a piece of equipment that copies words or pictures from paper into a computer
dictionaryExamples: to scan photos into a computer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Instead of drawing some of our customers document[s] we will just scan them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to quickly read a piece of writing to understand the main meaning or to find a particular piece of information
dictionaryExamples: I scanned the travel brochures looking for a cheap vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, I suggest that you buy a newspaper called "The Loot," sit down with a strong cup of coffee and scan it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to look around an area quickly to try to find a person or thing
dictionaryExamples: She scanned the crowd for a familiar face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She looked at Lisa: her restless eyes were scanning the room while her thin fingers were tapping on the table. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a medical examination in which an image of the inside of the body is made using a special machine
dictionaryExamples: a brain scan
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: John went with Sophie for a scan[;] John was hoping for a boy and Sophie for a girl. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: something that shocks people because they think it is morally wrong

People withdrew their money from banks caught up in the scandal.
It's a scandal (that) children could be treated in this way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Among them are the increasingly popular reality shows and all the daily news about gossip and scandal. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a permanent mark left on the body from a cut or other injury

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: David is a tall man with black curly hair, black eyes, a big nose, [a]  beard and a scar on his neck. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: damage done to a person's mind by a very unpleasant event or situation
dictionaryExamples: a psychological scar
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A person who [has been] affluent since childhood might be said to not have the emotional scars of experiencing poverty during childhood and might be able to look at the world, and to the life as an adult, in a positive and constructive way. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: to cause a scar
dictionaryExamples: He was scarred for life by the accident.

sense.def: rare or not available in large amounts
dictionaryExamples: scarce   resources
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the context of Singapore, where land is scarce and widening or building of more roads is just not feasible, we have no choice but to choose what is best for everyone. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: only just
dictionaryExamples: They had scarcely finished eating when the doorbell rang.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Scarcely had the ferry reached the shore than the heavy storm abated. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when there is not enough of something
dictionaryExamples: a scarcity of food/affordable housing

sense.def: to frighten a person or animal
dictionaryExamples: Sudden, loud noises scare me.

blocks.phrase: scare the hell/life/living daylights, etc. out of sb

sense.def: to make someone feel very frightened
dictionaryExamples: You scared the life out of me, creeping up on me like that!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Such gory details scared the living daylights out of each parent in town and, soon after the second dead girl was found, [one] Mary Joe Chavez, supposedly another high-school genius, a [state of] emergency was proclaimed and a thorough investigation followed, proving to be in vain, despite all the effort put into it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

blocks.phrasalVerb: scare sb/sth away/off or scare away/off sb/sth

sense.def: to make a person or an animal so frightened that they go away
dictionaryExamples: She scared off her attacker by screaming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, in the Ionian Islands, people break pots on Friday night in order to scare away evil spirits. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: scare sb away/off or scare away/off sb

sense.def: to make someone worried about doing something or going somewhere so that they decide not to do it or go there
dictionaryExamples: The recent bomb attacks have scared away the tourists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the dance display and horse show we actually did experience some rainfall, however it was a small shower and it didn't manage to scare off the people and to prevent the organi[z]ers from reaching their main goal. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: frightened or worried
dictionaryExamples: He's scared of spiders.
He's scared to tell her what really happened.
I was scared  (that) you might not be there.
I was scared stiff.
She had a scared look on her face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I came for [the] first time to my new English class I was a little bit scared. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: a piece of cloth that you wear around your neck, head, or shoulders to keep warm or for decoration
dictionaryExamples: a silk/wool scarf
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And my sister gave me a scarf too. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: frightening
dictionaryExamples: a scary movie/story
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was quite exciting but a little scary. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: covering a wide area
dictionaryExamples: His toys were scattered all over the floor.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, families are scattered in all the parts of world, for example, my husband's family is in Australia[,] so our wedding provided me a chance to spend time with his family and learn about their family traditions. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: a description of a situation, or of a situation that may develop in the future

a horrific/nightmare scenario such as a Third World War

sense.def: a short part of a film, play, or book in which the events happen in one place

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you haven't seen any of th[ese] three "Star Wars" movies, I suggest you do see them tonight or tomorrow. They are great, with [a] lot of action scenes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: a view or picture of a place, event, or activity
dictionaryExamples: Lowry painted street scenes.
scenes of everyday life

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like especially the scene of the garden with snow in winter. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a place where an unpleasant event has happened
dictionaryExamples: He was convicted of leaving the scene of an accident.

sense.def: all the things connected with a particular way of life or activity

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Great Britain has his own comic scene and it would be a good idea to meet them and talk with them about all their comics and they could write me and other German collectors. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: when people have a loud argument or show strong emotions in a public place
dictionaryExamples: She made a scene when I told her she couldn't come with us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She didn't cry, she didn't scream, she didn't make a scene. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

dictionaryExamples: A lot of hard work has been going on behind the scenes.

sense.def: having views of the attractive, natural things in the countryside
dictionaryExamples: a scenic route
an area of great scenic beauty
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: France is an area of great scenic beauty, famous for its excellent cooking and wine. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a pleasant smell
dictionaryExamples: the sweet scent of orange blossom
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Flowers are in bloom and their scent triggers my romantic mood. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a list of the times and days of classes at a school, college, etc.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, it started at 1:30 but it was on schedule. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

dictionaryExamples: The meeting has been scheduled for tomorrow afternoon.

sense.def: planned to happen at a particular time or on a particular date

sense.def: traveling at a regular time each day or week
dictionaryExamples: a scheduled flight

sense.def: a plan for doing or organizing something
dictionaryExamples: The committee came up with a creative fund-raising scheme.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [W]hat really helped me was my scheme to lessen pol[l]ution in [the] wild enviro[n]ment, and with that me and my colle[a]g[u]es succeed in cutting down pollution, in the main rivers and fields around the city.  First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a college or university student who has been given a scholarship or chosen for a special honor or program
dictionaryExamples: Rhodes/Fulbright scholars
a research scholar

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This determination to succeed of the children from less-[well]-to-do families, can be seen from the scholarship recip[i]ents each year in Thailand.  [The] majority of the recip[i]ents come from less-[well]-to-do families, and i[t] is very uncommon to see a scholar from a wealthy family. International English Language Testing System; C1; Thai

dictionaryExamples: She got a scholarship to the college.

dictionaryExamples: an elementary/secondary school

school lunch/uniforms
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like going to school by bus. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

law/medical/business school

dictionaryExamples: a science class
a science teacher

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can study math and science. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

advances in medical science

dictionaryExamples: I ride to school on  my scooter.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last place I would visit was an isolated [building], where some lean mongrel dogs were gnawing on rusty bones, while sniffing [a]round the piles of scrap iron the left side of the building was thick with. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to not continue with a plan or idea

"I wish you would leave!" she screamed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I opened the door and screamed - in front of me was a man standing with [his] hands covered in blood. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

dictionaryExamples: We heard screams coming down the hall.

My new phone has a touch screen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has a large screen, so I can see videos and pictures. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the words written for and spoken in a film, play, broadcast or speech
dictionaryExamples: Bruce Robinson wrote the script for "The Killing Fields."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't get involved that much in writing a script because it was very hard and the director wrote most of it but the main idea of the background of the stage was m[ine], and I am very proud of it. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: a set of letters used for writing a particular language
dictionaryExamples: Arabic/Roman script

sense.def: dirty and untidy
dictionaryExamples: scruffy jeans

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, if it is particularly trendy for kids to wear scruffy bomber jackets and faded jeans there is no point in compelling them to dress our conventional way. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when you examine something carefully
dictionaryExamples: Every aspect of her life came under public scrutiny.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything is placed under careful scrutiny. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a piece of art that is made from stone, wood, clay, etc., or the process of making objects like this
dictionaryExamples: a wood/bronze/marble sculpture
modern sculpture

The museum has several life-sized sculptures of people and animals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, they will film the ancient buildings, the sculptures and statues; and they will interview some students! Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a large area of salt water
dictionaryExamples: the Caribbean/Mediterranean Sea

When we moved to the US, we shipped our belongings by sea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We['ve] got two different seas, in the north is the Caribbean Sea and in the west is the Pa[c]ific [Ocean]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an animal with smooth fur that eats fish and lives near the sea
dictionaryExamples: We could see seals swimming near the shore.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After leaving the Orkney Islands, we went by boat to [the] Shetland Islands, because we wanted to observe the gr[a]y seals with their pups that were [o]n the northwest coast. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to close an entrance or container so that air or liquid cannot enter or leave it
dictionaryExamples: She sealed the jars so the jam wouldn't spoil.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Egypt, [the] Pyramids are being sealed, because the perspiration of the tourists was ruining the paintings on the walls. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

blocks.phrasalVerb: seal off sth or seal sth off

sense.def: to prevent people from entering an area or building, often because it is dangerous
dictionaryExamples: Police immediately sealed off the streets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The police sealed off the main street a few weeks ago because they have been building a new restaurant. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to try to find someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I've searched my bedroom but I can't find my watch.

Rescue workers continue  to search the area for survivors.
He searched (in/through) his pockets for some change.
I've searched high and low, but I can't find my birth certificate.
We searched the house from top to bottom, but we can't find that book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He searched the whole bank but could not find it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malayalam

sense.def: to use a computer to find information, especially on the Internet
dictionaryExamples: I searched the Internet to find the best prices for flights to Barcelona.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before you had to go to a lib[r]ary to finish [your] homework. Now, we just search on the internet. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If the police search a place or a person, they look to see if they are hiding anything illegal.
dictionaryExamples: They were searched at the airport.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The undercover [patrol] searched our car rather roughly, looking for drugs. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to try to find an answer to a problem
dictionaryExamples: Doctors are still searching for a cure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The governments are therefore searching for solutions to compensate [for] the lack of financial resources. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when you try to find someone or something
dictionaryExamples: After a long search, they eventually found the missing papers.
The police carried out/conducted/made a thorough search of the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Joshua instantly thought it could be a bomb, so he organized a search all over the airport. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when you use a computer to find information, especially on the Internet
dictionaryExamples: Why not do a search on Google for hotels in the area?
We're doing a computer search for all words beginning with "high."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I think you shouldn't ask me, the best thing is [a] search on the Internet, so you can see the photos and choose the option you like mo[st]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: when you try to find an answer to a problem
dictionaryExamples: the search for happiness

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hemingway fought in the Spanish Civil War and in World War II, always [i]n the search for answers to questions like "... what defines a man", or "... what happens to us in critical situations." First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: an area or town next to the sea
dictionaryExamples: a seaside resort/town

sense.def: one of the four periods of the year: spring, summer, fall, or winter

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once they had finished, Peter kissed his parents and started his journey [on] foot heading towards the stadium, to play the first game of the season. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If vegetables or fruit are out of season, they are not usually available at that time.
dictionaryExamples: Strawberries are out of season now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As our place was famous for fresh sea food, I bought crabs and salmon although they were out of season and expensive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: If you go somewhere out of season, you go during a period of the year when few people are there.
dictionaryExamples: I prefer to travel out of season.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some towns [that] are completely dependent on tourism "die" out of season, while others are destroyed because of the excessive emigration of [their] people. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: relating to or happening during a particular period in the year
dictionaryExamples: seasonal vegetables
seasonal farm work
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand we [always] need someone in our hotel in Luzern, so my parents could get you a seasonal permi[t] to work. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: a piece of furniture that you sit on
dictionaryExamples: Chairs, stools, sofas and benches are all seats.
Please have/take a seat.
Just leave you jacket in/on your seat.
I got a seat on the flight to New York.
My ticket says 22D but there's already someone in  that seat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can sell seats to help with the concert. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a position in an elected governing group or in another group that makes official decisions
dictionaryExamples: a seat in parliament
a congressional seat
a seat on the company board of trustees
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is the story of a man who spent his life paying kickbacks to achieve power and eventually a seat in the parliament. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to be sitting down
dictionaryExamples: The director was seated on his right.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A big pink elephant was seated near me. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If a building, room, or vehicle seats a particular number of people, that many people can sit in it.
dictionaryExamples: The new concert hall seats 1500 people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to the owners, the Swan seats 100 guests and it is always advisable to make reservations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If a place is secluded, it is quiet and not near people.
dictionaryExamples: a secluded beach/garden
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a place of rare beauty: secluded beaches, transparent and shimmering water are only a little part of the fas[c]inating mystery of this gorgeous sea resort. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: immediately after the first and before any others
dictionaryExamples: Is Megan her first or second child?
It's the second time I've had the flu this winter.
Jones took second place in the long jump.
I was second in line.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I forgot [to] answer the second question. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: another
dictionaryExamples: She is often described as the second Marilyn Monroe.
You really ought to make the most of the opportunity, because you won't get a second chance.
Richard and Liz have a second home in Florida.
Pay attention to what she's saying because she won't explain it a second time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought everybody [sh]ould have a second chance therefore I started running to him. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: Second is used to show that only one thing is better, bigger, etc. than the thing mentioned.
dictionaryExamples: St. Petersburg is Russia's second (biggest/largest) city.
Iraq's oil reserves are second only to Saudi Arabia's.
Services in this hospital are second to none.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Joao Pessoa is the second green[est] city in the world. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: after one other person or thing in order or importance
dictionaryExamples: She didn't win the race, but she did come in second.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [O]n the other hand, New Zealand came second [for] senior government. International English Language Testing System; B1; Arabic

sense.def: used to talk about the second in a series of things
dictionaryExamples: Second, they failed to send written warning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Second, I think it a good idea to enjoy picking up and eating grapes in a vineyard. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: one of the 60 parts a minute is divided into
dictionaryExamples: There are sixty seconds in a minute.
She won by 22 seconds.
These computers process millions of instructions per second.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought the British one, Peter, was going to win, but [in] the last 10 seconds, the Venez[ue]lan won! Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a very short period of time
dictionaryExamples: "Come on, hurry up!" "I'll just/only be a second - I have to lock the back door."
Have you got a second, Paul? I'd like to have a word with you.
It won't take a second.
Wait a couple of/a few seconds before trying again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A few seconds later, a huge tree beside my house fell down and destroyed most of my house. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: relating to the education of children approximately between the ages of 12 and 18 years old
dictionaryExamples: secondary education
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A TV company has decided to make a film in my high school because it's a normal secondary school. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a school for students aged between about 14 and 18
dictionaryExamples: State funding has increased for elementary and secondary schools.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They said they chose our school because we are one of the best secondary schools [in] Mexico City. Can you believe that!? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If something is second-hand, someone else owned or used it before you.
dictionaryExamples: second-hand books/clothes
She buys a lot of clothes second-hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally, I only buy second-hand clothes because in second-hand shops, I really like discover[ing] rare things and funny clothes from the 60s or 70s. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used for introducing the second reason, idea, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I want two things: firstly, more money, and secondly, better working hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, I didn't know that you were working in [an] organization which [is] trying to save wildlife, but it sounds very ex[c]iting. First Certificate in English; B2; Azerbaijani

sense.def: the form of a verb or pronoun that is used when referring to the person being spoken or written to
dictionaryExamples: "You" is a second person pronoun.

sense.def: something that you tell no one about or only a few people
dictionaryExamples: I'm having a party for him but it's a secret.
Can you keep a secret?
We don't keep secrets from each other.
Aren't you going to let me in on the secret?
She makes no secret of her desire to sell the house.
That restaurant is one of the best-kept secrets in Denver.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I told her everything, she knew all my secrets but she never told me her secrets. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the best way of achieving something
dictionaryExamples: That's the secret to making a good tomato sauce.
So what's the secret of your success?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The secret of this diet is that you have to be very optimist[ic]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: without telling other people
dictionaryExamples: For years they worked in secret.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And then I realized it was my birthday! Everybody congratulated me on my exam.  They [had] prepared everything in secret. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: If something is secret, other people are not allowed to know about it.
dictionaryExamples: The President escaped through a secret passage underneath the parliament building.
This is top  secret information.
Do you think we'll manage to keep the surprise party secret from Mom until her birthday?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I was at the airport I lost my secret diary. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: someone who works in an office, typing letters, answering the telephone, and arranging meetings, etc.
dictionaryExamples: My secretary will phone you to arrange a meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The class is on Friday. You have to bring paper. For more information, ask the secretary. Key English Test; A2; Polish

sense.def: the member of a committee who keeps records of meetings and deals with correspondence
dictionaryExamples: I'm secretary of the tennis club this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From: Secretary of the Social Club To: Mr. Ford, Museum Director Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: an official who is in charge of a large department of the government
dictionaryExamples: the Secretary of State
the Home secretary
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The person I want to propose for this duty is the former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: without allowing other people to know
dictionaryExamples:
She said she didn't care about it, but I believe she was secretly
                         thrilled.
They secretly took photographs of Jack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then in the evening we'll come to her house secretly. Of course, we should tell her m[o]m everything about this plan. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: one of the parts that something is divided into
dictionaryExamples: the sports section of the newspaper
the tail section of an aircraft
He lived in a poor section of town.
You’ll find ice cream in the frozen food section.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has two floor[s] and is divided into sections, one that is a [general] restaurant and one for vegetarian people. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: one part of a country's economy
dictionaryExamples: In the financial sector, banks and insurance companies have both lost a lot of money.
The new government's policy is to transfer state industries from the public sector to the private sector.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our software solutions are oriented towards the corporate sector where we are recognized as market leaders in this field. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: safe from danger or harm or not likely to end
dictionaryExamples: a secure job/investment
I don't feel that the house is secure.
Her promotion has made her position in the company more secure.
The museum has a large endowment, so its future is secure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think homes in the future will be more secure. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: confident about yourself and the situation that you are in
dictionaryExamples: Children need to feel secure in order to do well at school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, you feel secure because you know that all the members of the family love you. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: designed to make sure that only the person who knows it can get onto a computer system, Web site, etc.
dictionaryExamples: You will be issued with a secure password.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you decided to work with our superb Direct Net, you would get a secure password which you have to change at your first log in and an electronic card which produces every minute a new combination. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: not likely to fail
dictionaryExamples: a secure investment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I consider tourism a secure investment and [one] that is beneficial. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: protection of a person, building, organization or country against threats such as crime or attacks by foreign countries
dictionaryExamples: security forces/guards
security measures
security concerns/issues
For security reasons, they felt it necessary to close the avenue.
He sold information that may have damaged our national security.
The new measures will improve border/airport security.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's about a man that is cloned by a computer and he has to escape from a maximum security jail, it's an action [film]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Somali

sense.def: when something is not likely to fail or be lost
dictionaryExamples: If it's a choice between higher pay and job security, I'd prefer to keep my job.
I'm on a temporary contract and have little financial security.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are the people who are already regarded as the high class, but the reason for this prediction is that they have job security which has become a big issue in Korea after IMF, as well as high salary. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: confidence about yourself and the situation that you are in
dictionaryExamples: the security of a long-term relationship
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One is the security of having your mom around all the time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: spending a lot of time sitting down or not being active
dictionaryExamples: a sedentary job/lifestyle
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Improving the sports facilities means encouraging the residents to include physical exercise in their daily routine. Considering the sedentary lifestyle most people have adopted this would be of great importance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to persuade someone to have sex with you
dictionaryExamples: She was seduced by her boss.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the reasons why Olivia leaves her husband is that she has been seduced by an Indian prince. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to persuade someone to do something they would not normally do
dictionaryExamples: I wouldn't have bought it but I was seduced by the low prices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes I was seduced into buying very "useful" things by some cunning and attractive commercials on the television. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to notice people and things with your eyes
dictionaryExamples: Turn the light on so I can see.
"I can see you!"
The teacher could see (that) the children had been fighting.
Jacqui saw the car drive up outside the station.
From the window we could see the children playing in the yard.
See  p. 23 for prices and flight details.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every time I went to Hendon Park, I saw so many people there. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used for saying goodbye to someone
dictionaryExamples: See you! Enjoy your vacation!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [This] is my new number (07782472751). See you. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: used for saying goodbye to someone you are going to meet again later/soon/tomorrow, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I'll see you later!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: See you soon. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: to meet or visit someone
dictionaryExamples: We're seeing friends on Friday.
No one has seen much of Daryl since he got married.
They see a lot of each other  on weekends.
My mother is seeing the doctor again next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I go to India every year to see my friends and family because I love them. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi

sense.def: to watch a movie, television program, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Did you see that documentary on TV last night?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would really like to go to see that movie with you. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to understand something
dictionaryExamples: I see (that) the club is planning a picnic.
I see what you mean.
They didn't see the need/any need  to notify their members in writing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you see what I mean? Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to find out information
dictionaryExamples: I'll just see what time the train gets in.
Let's see whether there is an early performance on Saturday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have looked in my calendar to see what time would be the best for you to come here. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to imagine or think about something or someone in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: I’ll see how I feel tomorrow.
I can’t see my brother as a businessman.
As I see it/things/the situation, we'll have to get extra help.
"Do you think there’ll be time to stop for lunch?" "We’ll see .
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I compare the members of my family with these qualities, then I have to say that I don't see them as my best friends. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: used to say that you will make a decision about something later
dictionaryExamples: "Dad, can I have a guitar?" "We'll see."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure I'd love to have four of them, but there's always the financial aspect. I'm just nineteen, I'll see... Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to wait to discover what will happen
dictionaryExamples: We'll wait and see what she says.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will just have to wait and see.  . . . . Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be the time or place where something happens
dictionaryExamples: This decade has seen huge technological advances.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the reason [that] has driven the strike is the whole country has seen a cut in the subsidies give[n] to unemployed people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used when you are giving an explanation about something
dictionaryExamples: I didn't know she was Welsh, you see.
You see, it was already late by that time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Family matters had to stay in the family, you see. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If you ask someone to see that something happens, you want them to make sure it happens.
dictionaryExamples: Could you see that everyone gets a copy of this letter?

sense.def: to believe that something will happen
dictionaryExamples: I can't see us finishing on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She could see herself doing everyday job[s], studying with the kids, cooking dinner, putting them to [bed] but she didn't feel there; her thoughts were where they always were trying to find hope to endure the agony. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to realize you are wrong or have been behaving stupidly
dictionaryExamples: We talked to her for an hour, but we couldn't make her see sense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ralph tries to make Jack see sense by showing him the conch which had been the symbol of leadership and also, friendship. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: believe to be what is good, correct, or necessary
dictionaryExamples: You can leave it here or take it home with you, whichever you see fit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am, therefore, expressing my willingness, through this letter, to participate in this endeavor in whatever way you may see fit. International English Language Testing System; C2; Tagalog

sense.def: to look old or be   in bad condition because of a lot of use
dictionaryExamples: This jacket has seen better days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the dense fog he managed to see a man standing nearby, whose clothes ha[d] definitely seen better days. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

blocks.phrasalVerb:
see off sb or
                see sb off

sense.def: to go to the place that someone is leaving from in order to say goodbye
dictionaryExamples: They came to see me off at the airport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She came to the station to see him off. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to understand that someone is trying to deceive you
dictionaryExamples: It didn't take long for us to see through his charm.

sense.def: to deal with a person or task that needs to be dealt with
dictionaryExamples: "These letters need to be mailed." "I'll see to them later."

Please see to it
                             that no one comes in without identification.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want to keep an animal happy and healthy, it is also important, in my opinion, to see to it that, for instance, the monkeys have real trees to climb in! First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a small round or oval object produced by a plant that a new plant can grow from
dictionaryExamples: Plant the seeds  about 1 inch deep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [For] several years, I have been very interested in flowers, fresh, dried and artificial and also different kinds of seeds. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the beginning of something
dictionaryExamples: the seeds of hope/change
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Charity workers are keen to contribute with their work, their hearts and the seeds of hope and peace they leave wherever they go. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to try to find or get something
dictionaryExamples: "Are you actively seeking work?" she asked.
The government is seeking ways to reduce the cost of health care.
Hundreds of people are seeking refuge/asylum in the embassy.
They suggested she seek advice from the legal department.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am seeking employment and [am] interested in your offer. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to try to do something
dictionaryExamples: They are seeking to change the rules.
The Senator has announced she will seek reelection.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jack never accepted Ralph as a chief and throughout the book he seeks to assume power. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: appearing to be something without really being that thing
dictionaryExamples: a seemingly harmless comment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You also claim that we did not reach our target figure - a statement seemingly based on pure assumption - which is completely incorrect. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to take hold of something quickly and firmly
dictionaryExamples: I seized his arm and made him turn to look at me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, I think that the wild beasts have the right to live free and seize their prey in order to feed themselves. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to do something quickly in order to use an opportunity
dictionaryExamples: You need to seize every opportunity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So we seize the opportunity to go to the sea. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to take control of a place suddenly by using military force
dictionaryExamples: Troops seized control in the early hours of the morning.

sense.def: not often
dictionaryExamples: I seldom drive my car into the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Alice was a quiet girl, she seldom talked, but he just couldn't stop talking. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to choose someone or something from a group
dictionaryExamples: There was a choice of four prizes, and the winner could select one of them.
You can select from among the offerings shown on this screen.
They have the option of selecting the school that they want their kids to go to.
He was selected to play for Australia at the age of only 18.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've been selected to play on the school football team and we've got a match tomorrow. Preliminary English Test; B1; Gujarati

sense.def: when someone or something is chosen
dictionaryExamples: the selection process
We need to make a selection from these applicants.
Success is achieved by the careful selection of projects.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The selection of films and plays was well made, but I would have appreciate[d] [it]  if there had been more. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a group of people or things that has been chosen
dictionaryExamples: Most schools would have a good selection of these books in their libraries.
The larger shops are able to stock a wide selection of goods.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a good selection of bar food. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: intentionally choosing some things or people and not others
dictionaryExamples: As a teacher she was very selective, accepting only a small number of highly talented pupils.
He seemed to have a very selective recall of past events.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the same time, this makes us extremely selective when it comes to the people we want working with us. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: your characteristics, including your personality, your abilities, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Now I’m feeling better, and I’m back to my old self again.
his real/true self
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: True recognition and happiness can't be derived from television or front covers but only from one's true self. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: the quality of being confident about yourself
dictionaryExamples: He spoke with remarkable self-assurance for such a young man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She would have to show self-assurance, determination to get the job, and give the feeling that she would be up to the task. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: confident about yourself
dictionaryExamples: She's a very self-assured young woman.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I assume that in order to reach success you must be shrewd, self-reliant, self-assured and above all assertive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: good knowledge and judgment about yourself
dictionaryExamples: She has a high level of self-awareness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Montag's friendship with Clarisse, a young girl who is sensitive towards humans and nature, serves as a catalyst in the commencement of the antagonist's self-awareness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: interested only in yourself
dictionaryExamples: Angela is a good kid but at times she can be self-centered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that we were so self-centered and pleased with our sel[ve]s that we forgot to look around. International English Language Testing System; C1; Czech

sense.def: being self-confident
dictionaryExamples: Since she left home, her self-confidence has grown.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, the reason for it is that not many people know how to prepare for [an] interview and gain self-confidence. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: feeling sure about yourself and your abilities
dictionaryExamples: He's a very self-confident young man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So when the day c[a]me, she felt much more self-confident and determined than before. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: nervous or uncomfortably aware of yourself and what people think about you or your actions
dictionaryExamples: He looked uncomfortable, like a self-conscious adolescent who's gone to the wrong party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Video equipment however is something we have been wanting for a long time, for the following reasons: [...] - to enhance interpretation of body language as well as spoken language; this aspect is often neglected but of major importance; - to record and play back the students while speaking a monologue or discussing among a group: this enhances their fluency and makes them less self-conscious and thus more confident while expressing themselves in a foreign language; - last but not least: to make learning more fun and thus attract more students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: the ability to control your emotions and actions even when you are very angry, upset, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He lost his temper, and displayed a total lack of self-control.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Doing that kind of job requires a lot of self-control. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the ability to make yourself do things that you do not want to do
dictionaryExamples: I don't have the self-discipline to be an athlete.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, some of her most noticeable characterictics are her courtesy, her self-discipline and the compassion that she shows for those who suffer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: confidence in yourself and a belief in your qualities and abilities
dictionaryExamples: She suffers from low self-esteem.
Most parents want their children to have high self-esteem.
