sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that the lack of self-esteem among men underlies the whole situation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: caring only about yourself and not other people
dictionaryExamples: It's very selfish of him to go away every weekend.
The judge told him: "Your attitude shows a selfish disregard for others."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found this sport very interesting, because you have to play in a team so you must not be selfish, you have to change your spirit. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the quality of being selfish
dictionaryExamples: I was appalled by his selfishness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  It seems to me that everywhere in the world, people are not necessarily aware of the fact that planet Earth is [the]  most precious gift we have. Greed and selfishness are also very common in Switzerland, even if this country might be already a few steps further [forward] than others. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: rich because you have earned a lot of money yourself
dictionaryExamples: a self-made millionaire
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the reasons I think my father is succes[s]ful in life is because he is a self-made man. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the quality of not needing help and support from other people
dictionaryExamples: These kids need to learn some self-reliance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When she finally faced "Mr. Right" for the second time this morning, she discovered she was a new woman, endowed with self-reliance and a high sense of her being, her self-esteem, magically empowered. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: able to do things yourself without depending on other people
dictionaryExamples: The children are beginning to be a bit more self-reliant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You must have a firm, outgoing personality, but be self-reliant and strong-willed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the feeling of pride in yourself and your character
dictionaryExamples: Having a job gave them back their self-respect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And this proves that professional activity is a source of self-respect and, eventually, leads to satisfaction. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: A self-service business or service is one in which you serve yourself and are not served by the people who work there.
dictionaryExamples: a self-service gas station
You can use the self-service checkout at the supermarket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went to have lunch in a self-service restaurant and in the afternoon I continued my visit. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: having everything that you need yourself and not needing help from others
dictionaryExamples: We hope to grow enough vegetables to be completely self-sufficient this winter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, though we consider the fact of having longer life expectancy an improvement, the society tends to marginali[z]e an old person and tends to [view] him or her as a burden, especially if this person is not self-sufficient. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to give something to someone else in return for money
dictionaryExamples: I sold him my car/I sold my car to him for $2000.
We'll be selling the tickets for $50 each.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell my computer. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to offer something for people to buy
dictionaryExamples: Excuse me, do you sell newspapers?
They sell drinks and snacks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have some malls which sell clothes and I love shopping there. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to be available for sale at a particular price
dictionaryExamples: The shirts are selling for $30 each.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I heard larger t-shirts are selling for €35. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: to be bought in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: His last book sold eight million copies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The single with her new song sold more than 15 million copies, now she was a powerfull star. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to persuade someone that an idea or plan is good
dictionaryExamples: I've been trying to sell the idea to my boss.

sense.def: to be bought quickly and in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: Their new game is selling like hotcakes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They will buy the products, which I'm sure will sell like hotcakes! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: If a supply of something sells out, or if it is sold out, there is no more of that thing to buy.
dictionaryExamples: The first issue of the magazine sold out within two days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the tickets were sold out and the stadium was nearly full. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: someone who sells something
dictionaryExamples: flower/newspaper/souvenir sellers
Do you think the seller will accept $160,000 for the house?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was then my mother remembered a toy seller had been selling toys in the place where we had been waiting in the station and that our suitcase[s] must have got mixed up. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: one of two periods of time that the school or university year is divided into
dictionaryExamples: fall/spring semester
The first semester ended in mid-January.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: My grandmother is [from] Germany. That's why everybody in my family should know German. I want to start next semester.  
 Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: a mark (;) used to separate parts of a sentence, or items in a list which already has commas
dictionaryExamples: Use a semicolon to separate the groups of items in your list.

sense.def: one of the two games in a sports competition that are played to decide who will play in the final game
dictionaryExamples: Who's in the semi-finals?
She's the youngest player ever to get through to a semi-final.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One Sunday morning we had to play the cup semi-final against [our] great rival. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a meeting of a group of people with a teacher or expert for training, discussion, or study of a subject
dictionaryExamples: I attended practically every lecture and seminar when I was a student.
I'm giving a seminar on the latest developments in genetic engineering next week.
a seminar room
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also need this job because I need money to attend some seminars. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to arrange for something to go to or be delivered somewhere or to someone
dictionaryExamples: Juan has just sent me a text message.
Send me an e-mail with the information.
I'll send her a letter/fax/package/postcard next week.
We'll send it by mail.
They sent her flowers for her birthday.
Maggie sends her love and hopes you'll feel better soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can use [the] internet to learn English, and sometime[s] I send e-mail. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Cantonese

sense.def: to make someone go somewhere
dictionaryExamples: We're sending the children to stay with my parents for a couple of weeks.
The UN sent relief workers to the region.
Who can afford to send their kids to college these days?
He was trying to explain but she became impatient and sent him away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should buil[d] more schools because we only have one, so we have to send our children away and none of us like that. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to cause someone or something to do a particular thing, or to cause something to happen
dictionaryExamples: The explosion sent the crowd into a panic.
The fan sent papers flying all over the room.
A gentle breeze sent the clouds drifting across the sky.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While we were singing a duet by Mendelssohn with my sister, a sweeping movement of my hand sent two pages of music flying toward the first row of seats. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

blocks.phrase: send shivers/a shiver down your spine

sense.def: to make you feel afraid or excited
dictionaryExamples: The sound of his voice sent shivers down my spine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Simply looking at her sent shivers down his spine - there was the love of his life, the dearest woman on good old Earth, that he's never met before. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

blocks.phrasalVerb: send sth back or send back sth

sense.def: to return something to the person who sent it to you, especially because it is damaged or not suitable
dictionaryExamples: I had to send the shirt back because it didn't fit me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I usual[l]y order my clothes [on the] Internet.  It's fast, easy and you don't have any problems send[ing] them back if they don't fit. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to send someone a message asking them to come to see you
dictionaryExamples: We had to send for a doctor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Immediately after his arrival he sent for Beadle. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

blocks.phrasalVerb:
send off sth or
                send sth off

sense.def: to send a letter, document or parcel by mail
dictionaryExamples: Have you sent off your application yet?

blocks.phrasalVerb: send sth out or send out sth

sense.def: to produce something in a way that causes it to spread out from a central point
dictionaryExamples: The laser sends out a red beam of light.
The bushes were sending out new shoots.
The smoke alarm sent out a high-pitched sound.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other side of the lake the placid grazing cows would munch their breakfast as the sun rose on the horizon, sending out a flood of colors across the sky. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: having a more important job or position than someone else
dictionaryExamples: a senior executive
We work in the same team but she's senior to me.
a senior government minister
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is also extrao[r]dinary in that she graduated from Harvard University and Tokyo University and used to work for the Ministry of the Foreign Affairs as a senior civil servant. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: relating to the fourth and final year of study in a high school, college, or university
dictionaryExamples: Alanna’s in her senior year of high school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They made a film about this guy in the senior class who is able to dance like a pro despite being hand[i]capped from [the] waist down. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tagalog

sense.def: relating to people who are older
dictionaryExamples: You can't use a senior ticket during rush hour - you have to pay full fare.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I got to the tickets desk before the show to buy my ticket I asked for a senior discount, and the woman told me there were no discounts available as I read on the advertising. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a student in the fourth and final year of study in a high school, college, or university
dictionaryExamples: The seniors are taking their exams today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One day my geography teacher gathered the seniors and the juniors in our class, plus the principal and other two or three teachers, so that they could listen to me making a speech on my beautiful home-country. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: someone over the age of 65
dictionaryExamples: Seniors get a discount.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But we have a lot of volunteers, people who love their city, first of all students and senior citizens. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a physical feeling, or the ability to physically feel things
dictionaryExamples: a burning sensation
I had no sensation of pain whatsoever.
The disease causes a loss of sensation in the fingers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I fel[l] into the water, I was shocked. I couldn't move my right leg, the sensation was horrible. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a strange feeling or idea that you cannot explain
dictionaryExamples: I had the odd sensation (that) someone was following me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly I had the sensation that something was wrong. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a lot of excitement, surprise or interest
dictionaryExamples: Their marriage caused a sensation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the poetry, she expressed her sad feeling, thinking of her brother who was in China as a soldier. It caused a sensation. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: done in a way that is intended to shock people
dictionaryExamples: sensational journalism
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that the journalists desired sensational news far too much and they exaggerated. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: very exciting or extremely good
dictionaryExamples: a sensational performance
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are up for some sensational fun, "New York-New York" is your place, with a crazy roller coaster soaring through the lobby and out into open air. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a feeling or understanding about yourself or about a situation
dictionaryExamples: Did you get any sense of what they might do?
Living out in the country gave us a great sense of freedom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to see how people fight for the pri[z]e. I like this sense of compet[it]ion that only sport[s] give! Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: the ability to understand funny things and to be funny yourself
dictionaryExamples: Carol has a wicked sense of humor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a very nice person with a very good sense of humor and moral values. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: good judgment, especially about practical things
dictionaryExamples: I hope they'll have the (good) sense/have enough sense to shut the windows before they leave.

There's no sense 
                      in waiting  - the next train isn't for two hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People should have the sense to dispose [of] all the waste properly. International English Language Testing System; B2; Tamil

sense.def: the ability to do something
dictionaryExamples: He's got a good sense of direction and hardly ever uses a map.
good business sense
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Animals are part of nature so they must be free [to] go where their sense of direction [leads them]. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: one of the five natural abilities of sight, hearing, touch, smell, and taste
dictionaryExamples: My cold is so bad I've lost my sense of smell/taste.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can enjoy a flight with all your five senses. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: to have a meaning or reason that you can understand
dictionaryExamples: He's written me this note but it doesn't make any sense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Eighty kilometres in the mountains just to [look at] views doesn't make any sense to me. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to be a good thing to do
dictionaryExamples: It makes sense to buy now while prices are low.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore it make[s] sense to use the innovation[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: one of the possible meanings of a word or phrase
dictionaryExamples: They are not immigrants, at least not in any sense that I understand.
The packaging is green - in both senses of the word.
Security defined in the broad/broadest sense  of the term means getting at the root causes of trouble and helping to reduce problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Empress was an ideal lady in every sense of the word. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: thinking about something in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: In a sense, he's right.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In a sense this is correct, since you have to leave your natural environment to visit a place where no human being is meant to survive. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to understand something that is difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: I'm trying to make sense of this document.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, it's during his journey that Stevens begins to make sense of his life, of all the years he spent as a butler, as the "perfect butler" who had to be loyal, silent and discreet. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to realize you are wrong or have been behaving stupidly
dictionaryExamples: We talked to her for an hour, but we couldn't make her see sense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ralph tries to make Jack see sense by showing him the conch which had been the symbol of leadership and also, friendship. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to feel or experience something without being able to explain exactly how
dictionaryExamples: Although she said nothing, I could sense her anger.
He sensed something was about to happen.
He sensed (that) his guests were bored, although they were listening politely.
Could you sense what was likely to happen?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By that time the widow could not walk and the widower could not see. When the widower sensed that the widow badly wanted to go, the widow clung on[to] the widower's back and [they] set off, [with her] telling him where to go. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: happening or done without a good reason
dictionaryExamples: senseless violence
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe after a thousand years of wars between Poland and Germany both sides have finally decided that fighting and killing is senseless. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: someone's feelings, or the ability to understand what other people feel
dictionaryExamples: his aesthetic sensibility
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the features mentioned above are extremely important but they mean nothing if your offspring lacks kindness, sensibility and ignores his family traditions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: showing good judgment
dictionaryExamples: a sensible approach/strategy/solution
a sensible person
I think the sensible thing to do is phone before you go and ask for directions.
It would be sensible to take an umbrella.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know it sounds strange but there's a sensible reason: money talks. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: in a sensible way
dictionaryExamples: She behaved very sensibly about it.
They very sensibly decided to stay at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As time goes [by], these kids quite don't understand the importance of using money sensibly and saving money. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: easily upset by the things people say or do
dictionaryExamples: Her reply showed that she was very sensitive to criticism.
He was very sensitive about his scar and thought everyone was staring at him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays we are not so sensitive. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: able to react very quickly and easily
dictionaryExamples: a sensitive measuring instrument
He has a very sensitive nose.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very sensitive to noise, especially at night, and tend to catch a cold even in summer. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: easy to damage and needing to be protected
dictionaryExamples: This part of Cape Hatteras is an environmentally sensitive area where sea turtles nest.
Kate's skin is very sensitive - she has to carefully check labels on soaps.

sense.def: A sensitive subject or situation needs to be handled carefully in order to avoid upsetting people.
dictionaryExamples: Job loss and rising  costs are sensitive issues.
The stolen car contained documents described as very sensitive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I knew that I could not cry and shout because it was too important and sensitive [a] problem for us. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: able to understand what people are feeling and deal with them in a way that does not upset them
dictionaryExamples: I want a man who's kind and sensitive.
Representatives of the company claim their plan will be sensitive to local needs.
In the movie, he plays a concerned and sensitive father trying to bring up two teenage children on his own.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One thing Bobby is good at is that he is bright and sensitive enough to protect you. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the ability to understand how other people are feeling and to be helpful and kind to them
dictionaryExamples: The police showed great sensitivity in their handling of the case.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is written with sensitivity, honest[y], sincerity and objectiveness. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the quality of being easily upset by things that people say or do
dictionaryExamples: I should have warned you about her sensitivity to criticism.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of her weaknesses would be her great sensitivity. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a group of words, usually containing a verb, that expresses a complete idea
dictionaryExamples: He's very impatient and always interrupts me mid-sentence.
Your conclusion is good, but the final sentence is too long and complicated.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ev[e]ry lesson, I read and write loads o[f] sentences. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: a punishment that a judge gives to someone who has committed a crime
dictionaryExamples: They each served a three-year prison sentence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is even worse th[a]n a real life sentence. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to give a punishment to someone who has committed a crime
dictionaryExamples: He was sentenced to 3 months in jail and fined $5000.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Soon afterwards he gets imprisoned again and is sentenced to death. Sydney takes his place and is executed instead of him. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a general feeling, attitude, or opinion about something
dictionaryExamples: nationalist/religious sentiments
My sentiments exactly!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We would discuss for hours on end, arguing most of the times, and never express our true inner sentiments. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: showing kind feelings such as sympathy, love, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a sentimental song
The British are very sentimental about animals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I do love Lighthouse Family's music - the sentimental lyrics and catchy tune[s] all flow with the black singer's magic voice. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: related to feelings and memories and not related to how much money something costs
dictionaryExamples: It wasn't an expensive ring but it had great sentimental  value.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It can be the value in money that make[s] people be attached to [a] possession or, rather, a sentimental or symbolic link. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: not connected to or touching anything else
dictionaryExamples: a separate compartment
I try to keep meat separate from other food in the fridge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But there was no choice, as all my friends [who] did go were already in separate rooms. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: different or new
dictionaryExamples: Use a separate sheet of paper.
The art department and the music school are in two separate buildings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I bought a lot [of] presents, so I needed a separate suitcase. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: not affecting or related to each other
dictionaryExamples: I asked him to turn his music down on three separate occasions.
I have my professional life and my private life and I try to keep them separate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She went to Lisbon, and we [ended up] living separate li[v]es. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to divide into parts, or to make something divide into parts
dictionaryExamples: I separated the class into three groups.
The north and south of the country are separated by a mountain range.
You can get a special device for separating egg whites from yolks.
The top and bottom sections are difficult to separate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Recently a new system has been introduced which enables us to separate the different kinds of waste, such as plastics, organics and batteries. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: to move apart, or to make people move apart
dictionaryExamples: I'll have to separate you two if you don't stop talking.
Somehow, in the rush to get out of the building, I got separated from my mother.
Perhaps we should separate now and meet up later.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I noticed that there w[ere] some [people] fighting, and we tried to separate them. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to start to live in a different place from your husband or wife because the relationship has ended
dictionaryExamples: My parents separated when I was four.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But his parents separated and John didn't see h[is] mother again, as well as his sister, after that day. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: not together
dictionaryExamples: Detectives interviewed the men separately.
I tend to wear the jacket and skirt separately rather than as a suit.
I think we'd better deal with these two points separately.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were living separately and missing each other. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when two or more people or things are separated
dictionaryExamples: During the war, many couples had to face long periods of separation.
The law requires the separation of garbage that can be recycled, such as newspapers and glass bottles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The separation from nature is dangerous for human being[s], it may result in the loss of the connection with the basis of human[ity]. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the decision of two people who were married to stop living together
dictionaryExamples: They decided on a trial separation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We lived for a time in peace but our happiness ceased because of his jealousy and fear [of losing] me, which was the cause of our daylong quarrels. There was no solution apart from separation. First Certificate in English; B2; Arabic

sense.def: the ninth month of the year, after August and before October
dictionaryExamples: the 23rd of September/September 23(rd)
We're leaving for France on September ninth/the ninth of September.
Claudia started school last September/is starting school next September.
My mother's birthday is in September.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My course started [i]n September. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a part of a movie or video game that shows one thing that happens
dictionaryExamples: I particularly enjoyed the dream sequence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, the rest of the game is not as [polished] as the opening sequence: indeed, it seems that the developers simply re-used the graphical engine of the prequel, without even revamping it: the result is truly disappointing. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a series of related events or things that have a particular order
dictionaryExamples: the sequence of events that led to his death
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They don't emerge from nowhere, as there was a certain sequence of events that has led to them, so having the full picture with past events influencing our present can help us to find efficient solutions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: the order that events or things should happen or be arranged in
dictionaryExamples: I got my slides mixed up and they appeared out of sequence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was the fourth summer in sequence that he had chosen this hotel to spend his holiday but this he had never experienced before. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: calm and quiet
dictionaryExamples: a serene face/smile
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoy looking at this image, which bears [the] skill of a 16th century artist: the mother's expression is solemn and tender as she looks at the boy, while Christ's face is completely serene and is lit with a faint smile. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a feeling of being calm and happy
dictionaryExamples: She sat there with an air of serenity about her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She strongly believes that art bring[s] peace, harmony, serenity and tranquility in their life, which could balance their emotions and help [them] to overcome difficulties. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: happening in parts that follow one after another in order or over time
dictionaryExamples: a serial drama/novel/story
She’s the librarian in charge of serial publications.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a cartoonist, Aoyama originally started to draw short stories for the entertainment pages of local newspapers.  However, an editor recogni[z]ed his talent, and sponsored him to create, and draw some longer, serial stories. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: describes a person who repeatedly commits the same crime, often using the same method, or a serious crime that is committed repeatedly by one person
dictionaryExamples: She wrote a thriller about a brutal serial killer.
serial offenders/criminals
serial murder/rape
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These pictures have never been broadcast because too many important people are involved in these serial killings. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a story in a magazine or on television or radio that is told in separate parts over a period of time
dictionaryExamples: I'm watching a serial set in Yorkshire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I have already mentioned the quality of the English language used is exceptional and I would like to congratulate all the pe[ople] that take part in the serial. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a group of television or radio programs that have the same main characters or deal with the same subject
dictionaryExamples: a comedy series
I missed the second episode of the series so I don't know what's going on now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like television series like Smallville. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: several things or events of the same type that come one after the other
dictionaryExamples: He had a series of tests, but they can't find anything wrong.
She gave a series of lectures at last year on contemporary writers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The aim of this report is [to] make a series of suggestions on which lessons and other activities should be filmed. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a set of books published by the same company which deal with the same subject
dictionaryExamples: They do a series on architecture throughout the ages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We read all of Poirot and [the] [Miss] Marple series. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: A serious problem or situation is bad and makes people worry.
dictionaryExamples: a serious illness
There were no reports of serious injuries.
The new tax regulations have landed some of the smaller companies in serious trouble.
A shortage of space has become a serious problem in a lot of schools.
He's been taken to hospital where his condition is described as serious but stable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know I have got [a] serious problem [with] my eyes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: not joking or intended to be funny
dictionaryExamples: Please don't laugh - I'm being serious.
He was wearing a very serious expression and I knew something was wrong.
On the surface it's a very funny novel but it does have a more serious underlying theme.
Is she serious about going to live abroad?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are taught how to act in both comic and serious parts. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: A serious person does not laugh often.
dictionaryExamples: I remember her as a very serious child.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, the new teacher is very serious, but this is ok. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: needing or deserving your complete attention
dictionaryExamples: That's an interesting job offer - I'd give it some serious consideration if I were you.
We've got some serious talking to do, you and me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it would be worthwhile to give serious thought to these animals. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: badly or severely
dictionaryExamples: seriously ill/worried
He wasn't seriously injured - he just got a few cuts and bruises.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is seriously ill with cancer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: in a way that shows that you are not joking
dictionaryExamples: Seriously now, did he really say that or are you just being silly?
You're not seriously thinking of leaving, are you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Seriously, Tom, I have noticed that you get angry very easily since your examinations started. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: to consider a person, subject or situation to be important or dangerous and worth your attention or respect
dictionaryExamples: The police have to take any terrorist threat seriously.
You don't take anything seriously, do you? It's all one big joke to you.
She wants to be taken seriously as an actress.
These young actors take themselves so seriously!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you take my suggestions seriously. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: someone who works and lives in someone else's house doing their cooking and cleaning, especially in the past
dictionaryExamples: They employed more than 50 servants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this book, the author [includ]es a detailed description of [the] two main characters: the rich English master PHILEAS FOGG and his French servant PASSEPARTOUT. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to give someone food or drink, especially guests or customers in a restaurant or bar
dictionaryExamples: Do they serve brunch on the weekend?
Breakfast is served between 7 and 9.
All recipes in this book will serve  4 to 5 people.
Serve the pie with vanilla ice cream.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We ate a lot because my mom served many kinds of food [at] my party. Key English Test; A2; Indonesian

sense.def: to be useful as something
dictionaryExamples: It's a very entertaining movie but it also serves an educational purpose.
The study also serves as a spare bedroom.
Those discussions only served to reinforce her fears.
He hopes his son's death will serve to warn others about the dangers of owning a gun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for replanting, it will serve to rejuvenate our forests around Agrinio. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to do work that helps society, for example in an organization such as the army or the government
dictionaryExamples: to serve in the army
to serve on a committee/jury
He served as mayor for 5 years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Women in the former GDR [ha]d the same rights and had to fulfill nearly the same duties (except the duty to serve in the army) as men. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to be in prison for a period of time
dictionaryExamples: Williams, 42, is serving a four-year jail sentence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It all came to me in prison where I was serving [a] two-year sentence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a central computer from which other computers get information
dictionaryExamples: a network/file server
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was my boss, [who] said "I'm in Australia, and I can't read my e-mail, the server at work crashed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a system or organization that provides something that people need
dictionaryExamples: the postal service
medical/social services
We will be operating normal rush-hour train service.
My brother runs a car service business that rents cars with drivers.
There is bus service to the airport every twenty minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I told him to phone the after-sales service. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: when people help you and bring you things in a place such as a restaurant or hotel
dictionaryExamples: The only trouble with this café is that the service is so slow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover there's excellent service, all the waiters are really nice and polite. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an amount of money charged for serving a customer in a restaurant, which is often paid directly to the waiter
dictionaryExamples: A 15 percent service charge is included for parties of six or more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The thing which annoyed me the most was [that] they have a 20% service charge, but I refused to pay it because there w[as] no service. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a government department that is responsible for a particular area of activity
dictionaryExamples: the diplomatic service
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was employed in the security service. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the armed forces, or work done in the armed forces
dictionaryExamples: military service
He joined the air force in 1964 and spent ten years in the service.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He finished his military service, and now he was on his way to his family, who had been waiting for him for a long time. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: the time you spend working for an organization
dictionaryExamples: He retired last week after 25 years' service.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my mind he is the perfect candidate, because due to his long service in the U.S. Army, where superiors are obliged to take care of their subordinates, he was in contact with young people from all kinds of ethnic [backgrounds] and social classes. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a period of time or a meeting arranged for a particular activity
dictionaryExamples: The 21-year-old runner twisted his ankle in a training session last Friday.
As the heads of state gathered, the press were allowed in for a photo session.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last week we had the normal two training sessions and a game against another club. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a problem that makes something happen later or more slowly than it should
dictionaryExamples: The project has suffered a series of setbacks this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A strong bond between you and your friends, with whom you can have discussions about personal setbacks, is another very vital point. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the position of a house or other building
dictionaryExamples: Their cottage is in a beautiful rural setting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [It is] a beautiful setting with old architecture, trees and glittering water. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the time and the place in which the action of a book, movie, play, etc. happens
dictionaryExamples: The play has its setting in a wartime prison camp.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The setting of "The Third Man" is Vienna after the Second World War. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If you settle an argument, you solve the problem and stop arguing.
dictionaryExamples: My father and I have agreed finally to settle our differences.
It took months to settle  the dispute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Caroline and her husband had had an argument last week, but as he was going to be away for a few days, they had finally settled their differences. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to start living somewhere that you are going to live for a long time
dictionaryExamples: After they got married, they settled in Kentucky.
He traveled around Europe for a year before finally settling in Toronto.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can understand why you have decided to settle near the Loire Valley, which is one of the greatest part[s] of France. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to decide or arrange something
dictionaryExamples: OK, that's settled. We're going to Spain.
They haven't yet settled when the wedding is going to be.
"The tickets are $60 each." "Well, that settles that - I can't afford that much."
I'd like to get this matter settled once and for all.
The details of the contract have not yet been settled.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really hope it will not take you long to settle the matter. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to move to a lower level and stay there
dictionaryExamples: The house had been empty for years, and dust had settled on all the surfaces.
Sand blown by the high winds had settled on the streets and lawns of the seaside town.
The contents of this package may settle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whenever I have cleaned my shel[ve]s you can just watch the dust settle on [them]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: If you settle a bill or a debt, you pay the money that you owe.
dictionaryExamples: I've got some bills to settle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many individuals are caught overspending when they check their credit card statements, later having to borrow from money lenders to settle their bills. International English Language Testing System; C2; Malay

sense.def: to become familiar with a place and to feel happy and confident in it
dictionaryExamples: She quickly settled down in her new house/job/school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He seemed to be such a nice guy and I was very happy to find you [have] settled down so well in your new life. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to start living in a place where you intend to stay for a long time
dictionaryExamples: Eventually I'd like to settle down and have a family, but not yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I guess the changes occur once the young couple decides to marry and settle down. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to become quiet and calm, or to make someone quiet and calm
dictionaryExamples: They settled down on the sofa to watch the movie.
Come on class, stop talking and settle down, please!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should welcome your relatives, make them settle down and ask them to wait a moment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to begin to feel relaxed and happy in a new home or job
dictionaryExamples: Are you settling in OK?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After you settle in, you'll find there's a lot of way[s] to save money on food. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the payment of money that is owed
dictionaryExamples: We enclose a check in settlement of your claim.

sense.def: an official agreement that finishes an argument
dictionaryExamples: a peace settlement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All employees working for the public transport went on strike a week ago, and there is no settlement in sight. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: an arrangement to end a disagreement without taking it to a court of law
dictionaryExamples: They reached an out-of-court settlement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hoping for a settlement without having to involve the courts, I remain. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a town or village which people built to live in after arriving from somewhere else
dictionaryExamples: An isolated settlement far from the big city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The traditional style of small living communities in tribes cannot be sustained, since the farmlands around a settlement cannot provide the people with sufficient food and work. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the number 7
dictionaryExamples: The restaurant opens for dinner at seven o'clock.
We're open seven days a week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tomorrow I'll finish my work at six o'clock, so I think that I'll can arrive your home at seven o'clock. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: the number 17
dictionaryExamples: sixteen, seventeen, eighteen
Is that a seventeen on the front of that bus?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is seventeen years old. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: 7th written as a word
dictionaryExamples: It's the seventh (of May) today.
Our team came in seventh.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The day of [the] art class is [the] seventh of May. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: the number 70
dictionaryExamples: sixty, seventy, eighty
This house was built seventy years ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have bought new shoes.  I bought them because there were very beautiful, and they cost only seventy dollars. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to be aged between 70 and 79
dictionaryExamples: Both my parents are in their seventies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After some minutes, an old man in his late seventies opened the door and told us in his trembling voice that Daisy wasn't at home. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the years 1970 through 1979
dictionaryExamples: I grew up in the seventies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The nineties is, indeed, a reverse of the seventies. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: some, but not a lot
dictionaryExamples: I've seen "Gone with the Wind" several times.
Several people have complained about the plan.
Several of my friends are learning English at language schools in Seattle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also got several books, a beautiful bag, a T-shirt, etc. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: extremely bad
dictionaryExamples: a severe chest infection/leg injury/toothache
This is a school for children with severe learning difficulties.
In parts of Africa there is a severe food/water shortage.
There is expected to be a severe frost tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their life was a severe financial struggle, and Tom's dream was to run somewhere far away. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a severe person is unfriendly or very strict
dictionaryExamples: She had her hair tied back in a severe style.
The teacher was a small, severe man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jane Eyre is sen[t] away to [a] school for orphans. [...] The atmosphere in school is no better, with little food and severe teachers. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: very seriously
dictionaryExamples: Their daughter was severely injured in a car accident.
severely disabled
Job opportunities are severely limited at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In spite of trying to repair it, it is still severely damaged. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: how severe something is
dictionaryExamples: Flights were cancelled owing to the severity of the weather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, we have to accept the severity of the environmental damage, but we should not give up our hopes for a better future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to make or repair clothes by joining pieces of cloth using a needle and thread
dictionaryExamples: My grandmother taught me to sew.
I made this skirt just by sewing two pieces of material together.
She sews all her children's clothes.
He sewed the badge neatly onto his uniform.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, I used to sew my clothes on my own. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: the activity of joining pieces of cloth together or repairing them with a needle and thread
dictionaryExamples: I'm not very good at sewing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I especially cherish the idea of finding myself in Camelot being a lady in waiting [to] Queen Guinevere - to spend my days reading, sewing, embroidering, learning about far off places and discoveries, adventures and the latest gossip from the court. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the state of being either male or female
dictionaryExamples: What sex is your cat?
Some tests enable you to find out the sex of your baby before it's born.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teacher gave me the application form about my name, age, sex, nationality and address. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: sexual activity between people
dictionaryExamples: She was complaining about all the sex and violence on television.
Most young people now receive sex education at school.
unprotected sex
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hate watching soap operas and t[h]rillers, because they contain too much violence and sex. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: people who are the other sex from you
dictionaryExamples: When you attend an all girls or all boys school, you don't study with members of the opposite sex.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is not only about trying to impress (preferably) a person of the opposite sex, but fashion also gives you a great chance to express yourself. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: relating to the activity of sex
dictionaryExamples: a sexual relationship
Most people remember their first sexual experience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before continuing with the story I would like to remind [you] that having sexual relationships was common to everybody in Brave New World. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: relating to being male or female
dictionaryExamples: He’s always believed in sexual equality.
Some steps have been taken toward ending sexual discrimination.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But we must not forget that there is still sexual discrimination when women apply for jobs higher up in [a] hierarchy. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: attractive or exciting in a sexual way
dictionaryExamples: sexy underwear
He's very sexy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Richard was only wearing Levis Jean[s] and a white T shirt but looked so sexy and handsome. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: looking messy and in bad condition
dictionaryExamples: shabby clothes/furniture
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With neither lift nor room service provided our guests had to stay in dirty and shabby rooms on the 4th floor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: not fair or not honest
dictionaryExamples: She received very shabby treatment from her employers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to such shabby arguments, my adversaries lost the favor of the population. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: an area where light from the sun is blocked and so it is darker and not as hot
dictionaryExamples: I'd prefer to sit in the shade.
The sun was hot, and there were no trees to offer us shade.
The children played in/under the shade of a large beach umbrella.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The shade from huge trees kept me cool and fresh. Preliminary English Test; B1; Singhalese

sense.def: a color, especially when referring to how dark or light it is
dictionaryExamples: a pale/dark shade of gray
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not only was it a beautiful day but the sky was a magnificent shade of blue as well. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a small amount
dictionaryExamples: He's perhaps a shade taller.

sense.def: a cover that stops too much light coming from the sun or from an electric light
dictionaryExamples: a lamp shade
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will like sitting there at dark wooden tables, under the light coming from red and white checked lamp shades hanging from the ceiling. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a dark area made by something that is stopping the light
dictionaryExamples: The tree had cast  a long shadow.
The children were playing, jumping on each other's shadows.
Jamie followed his mother around all day like a shadow.
This corner of the room is always in shadow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly I saw a shadow and as I turned over I noticed that something was moving in the trees. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

blocks.phrase: beyond/without a/the  shadow of a doubt

sense.def: If something is true beyond a shadow of a doubt, it is certainly true.
dictionaryExamples: He stole the money, without a shadow of a doubt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is beyond the shadow of a doubt that Douglas does not offer her this kind of life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to move backward and forward or up and down in quick, short movements, or to make something or someone do this
dictionaryExamples: A young boy climbed into the apple tree and shook the branches so that the fruit fell down.
Babies like toys that make a noise when you shake them.
Cory shook some powdered sugar on her French toast.
She shook her hair loose from its ribbon.
Every time one of these big trucks goes through the village, all the houses shake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was getting nervous and my hands began to shake. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to hold someone's hand and move it up and down when you meet them for the first time, or when you make an agreement with them
dictionaryExamples: The two leaders smiled and shook hands for the photographers.
I shook hands with him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I felt embarras[s]ed when all my friends thought they were my friends, so [they] all sh[ook] hands with them ex[c]ept me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If you are shaking, your body makes quick short movements, or you feel as if it is doing so, because you are frightened or nervous.
dictionaryExamples: She was shaking as she opened the letter.
Her voice shook as she spoke about the person who had jumped out at her.
I was shaking like a leaf.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She understood that it was absolutely foolish of her to stand [t]here shaking with fear. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to move your head from side to side to mean "no"
dictionaryExamples: I asked him if he wanted to come and he just shook his head.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He just looked at me shaking his head and got into his car and drove off. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If your voice shakes, you sound very nervous or frightened.
dictionaryExamples: He looked pale, and his voice shook as he spoke.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  "Excuse me, my name is Heathcliff Moore, I'm a musician," he approached the owner with shaking voice. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

blocks.phrasalVerb: shake off sth or shake sth off

sense.def: to get rid of an illness, something unpleasant, or something that is causing you problems
dictionaryExamples: I hope I can shake off this cold before the weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was capable of shaking off the criticism due to the fact that he believed strongly enough in himself, which I find quite remarkable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

blocks.phrasalVerb: shake up sth or shake sth up

sense.def: to cause large changes in something
dictionaryExamples: Technological changes have shaken up many industries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that their aim is to shake up public opinion in the most impressive way they can. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

blocks.phrasalVerb: shake up sb or shake sb up

sense.def: If an unpleasant experience shakes someone up, it makes them feel shocked and upset.
dictionaryExamples: The accident really shook him up.

sense.def: shocked and upset
dictionaryExamples: They were not injured in the accident, but they were badly shaken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that encounter with her old classmate she felt shaken and upset. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: not deep
dictionaryExamples: The stream was quite shallow so we were able to walk across it.
She told her children to stay in the shallow end (of the swimming pool).
Fry the onions in a shallow pan.
These beech trees have shallow roots.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A  heavy body plunged into the shallow water of harbo[r] No 14. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: not showing any interest in serious ideas
dictionaryExamples: He is a very shallow person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is shallow and superficial, and she finds it hard to relate to her husband. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: Something shameful is bad and should make you feel embarrassed and guilty.
dictionaryExamples: shameful scenes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  What a shameful way of wasting natural resources! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a liquid substance that you use to wash your hair
dictionaryExamples: an anti-dandruff shampoo
Directions: wet hair, apply shampoo and massage into a rich lather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the soap and the shampoo are in the bathroom. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the physical form of something made by the line around its outer edge
dictionaryExamples: a circular/rectangular shape
You can recognize trees by the shape of their leaves.
These old sweatpants are all stretched out of shape
These bricks are all different shapes.
Kim's birthday cake was in the shape of a train.
My bicycle wheel is bent out of shape.
This T-shirt has been washed so many times that it's lost its shape.
A triangle is a shape with three sides.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, it looks like yours, you know, the same size and shape. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: in good/bad, etc. health or condition
dictionaryExamples: She runs every day so she's in great shape.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am of the opinion that if you are in good shape and the distance is not too much, you should leave the car at home and use the bike. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to stay healthy and physically strong
dictionaryExamples: It's important to keep in shape.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We want to keep in shape, and we are interested in a gym - do you have one or is there one close to there? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: many different types of people or things
dictionaryExamples: We saw people there of all shapes and sizes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personal challenges come in all shapes and sizes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: not healthy or physically strong
dictionaryExamples: Since I stopped riding my bike, I've gotten out of shape.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I no longer run and it has been more than a year since the last time I raced, [so] I am out of shape. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to start to develop and become more clear or certain
dictionaryExamples: The project is slowly beginning to take shape.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is high time that their dreams took shape! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: to influence the way that something develops
dictionaryExamples: Many people are not able to shape their own destinies.
We’re worried that they will try to shape the issue in a way that doesn't reflect what’s really going on.
He was very influential in shaping the government's economic policy/strategy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All these experiences have shaped my personality and I am said to be sociable and understanding, especially when I am in contact with foreigners. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to have or use something at the same time as someone else
dictionaryExamples: Bill and I shared an office for years.
I share a house with four other people.
She's very possessive about her toys and finds it hard to share.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are two beds because I share my room with a friend. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to divide something between two or more people
dictionaryExamples: Do you want to a piece of pie with me?
We should share (in) the reward.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We shared one big cake. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: If two or more people or things share a feeling, quality or experience, they both or all have the same feeling, quality or experience.
dictionaryExamples: We share an interest in sailing.
All hospitals share some common characteristics.
I have an idea I’d like to share with you.
I don't share your views.
She knew that he was the person she wanted to share her life with.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her name is Gulia and I met her at the University. She is very nice, and we share many interests, so we gave each other our phone numbers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: If two or more people share an activity, they each do some of it.
dictionaryExamples: It’s a long trip – why don’t we share the driving
We shared the preparation for the party between us, so it wasn't too much work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ask your employer and other colle[a]gues to share the work. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to tell someone your problems/thoughts/ideas, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Would you like to share your thoughts with the group, Donald?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have received your letter asking for my opinion about the Conference and have decided to write and share some of my thoughts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a part of something that has been divided
dictionaryExamples: The total bill for the three of us comes to $90, so your share is $30.
We must make sure that everyone gets equal shares of the food.
Our candidate's share of the vote fell from 39 percent to 24 percent.
She's not doing her share of the work.
We must all accept some share of the responsibility.

sense.def: a lot of something and enough of it, usually something bad
dictionaryExamples: We've had our fair share of rain already this summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wasn't as if Jean hadn't seen his fair share of dead bodies, but these ones were far more, well, disgusting, than anything before. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: one of the equal parts that the value of a company is divided into when it is owned by a group of people
dictionaryExamples: She wants to buy shares of stock in that company.
She owns 2000 shares of General Electric.
The price of shares in that company fell again today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is no longer the consumer but the shareholder who must be kept happy, in order to keep the share price high, and the simple worker pays the price. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a large fish with very sharp teeth
dictionaryExamples: a great white shark
The movie "Jaws" is about a man-eating shark.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By the way, this ocean was full of sharks, our guide said. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: having a very thin or pointed edge that can cut things
dictionaryExamples: a sharp knife
sharp teeth/claws/fingernails
The point of this pencil isn't sharp enough.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My heart was broken by a knife, a sharp, hot knife, but I don't feel pain, I don't feel anything, I just want to die and forget about everything. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a sudden and very large increase or reduction in something
dictionaryExamples: a sharp drop in temperature
a sharp decline in the standard of living
There was a sharp rise/increase in the number of flu cases.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have in mind my recommendations you will see a sharp increase in the number of students. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: quick to notice and understand things
dictionaryExamples: a sharp mind
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is an elderly woman who seems to be very weak but with an extrem[e]ly sharp mind. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: A sharp image is very clear.
dictionaryExamples: a photograph in sharp focus
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Quite the opposite, FFIX features beautiful pre-rendered 3D landscapes, along with real time characters: words are useless for describing such an achievement: the colors are vivid, sharp, the animations are smooth... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a very big and noticeable difference between two things
dictionaryExamples: These luxurious surroundings were a sharp contrast to his home life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Always willing to accomodate the need of the customers, the service of "Zithos" draws a sharp contrast with the often insolent and disco[u]rteous conduct of employees in other restaurants. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a sudden, short, strong pain
dictionaryExamples: I felt a sharp pain in my leg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When she had dialed the number and the signals were coming through she felt rather dizzy and then a sharp pain in her stomach. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a sudden large change in the direction you are traveling
dictionaryExamples: The vehicle went off the road at a sharp bend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While my aunt was slowing down at a sharp bend, I distracted her [and] she lost control of the car. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: exactly at the stated time
dictionaryExamples: The performance will begin at 7:30 sharp.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to wake him up at 8:00 AM sharp. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to make something sharper
dictionaryExamples: to sharpen a knife/pencil
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, to write properly with a pencil, you need to sharpen it, but, for what purpose are you sharpening it? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to make something better or stronger
dictionaryExamples: Recent changes have sharpened competition between the airlines.
I hope this course will help me sharpen my computer skills.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, teachers and professors give us the opportunity to broaden our knowledge, sharpen our critical thought and in general to cultivate our mind and soul. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: quickly and suddenly
dictionaryExamples: Interest rates rose/fell sharply last month.
Sales sharply declined last month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the last few years, the trend of owning a [cell] phone has increased sharply. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: very upset
dictionaryExamples: She was absolutely shattered when she failed the exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How many times have we confessed to ourselves that we feel emotionally shattered just because we cannot buy the all the rage luxurious bag on which we set our eyes the other day? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to cut hair off your face or body with a razor
dictionaryExamples: John shaves twice a day.
I was surprised to see he had shaved off his beard
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The other men shave the man who is getting married. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: used to refer to a woman, girl or female animal that has already been mentioned
dictionaryExamples: I asked my mother if she'd lend me some money, but she said no.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is 23 years old. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: a small building, usually made of wood, used for storing things
dictionaryExamples: a garden shed
a tool/bicycle shed
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was hidden in a shed that hardly anybody ever entered. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to cry
dictionaryExamples: I shed a few tears when he left.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was too preoc[c]upied to talk to anybody and she had shed so many tears that she could cry no more. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to provide new information about something that makes it easier to understand
dictionaryExamples: As an economist, he was able to shed some light on the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A study of them might shed light on this unique process of adaptation, and may help improve it in the future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a farm animal whose skin is covered with wool
dictionaryExamples: This cheese is made from sheep's milk.
The farmer has several  long-haired sheep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Scotland is a beautiful country, there are a lot of loch[s] and sheep. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: used to emphasize how strong a feeling or quality is
dictionaryExamples: a look of sheer delight/joy
sheer determination/hard work
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mind was filled with nothing else but the sheer joy about soon becom[ing] a[c]quainted with something entirely new and completely unfamiliar plus the eager anti[c]ipation about meeting my host-family. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: used to emphasize the large size or amount of something
dictionaryExamples: The delays are due to the sheer volume of traffic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Allow me to start by saying that one day, which may not [lie] so far off in the future, people will visit the buildings which were formerly known as "Educational Institutions" like we visit museums [today] to gape at the sheer size of the Dinosaurs... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: very steep
dictionaryExamples: a sheer cliff face
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mountaineering takes you on a swaying j[o]urney through stark contrasts, from the serenity of a peaceful dense forest to sheer cliff edges and peaks. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a flat, horizontal board used to put things on, often attached to a wall or inside a cabinet
dictionaryExamples: a glass shelf
on the top/middle/bottom shelf
One wall had shelves from floor to ceiling, crammed with books.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I have left it on the shelf in your bedroom. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: the hard outer covering of some creatures and of eggs, nuts, or seeds
dictionaryExamples: Brazil nuts have very hard shells.
A piece of shell fell into the cake mixture.
the shell of a snail/crab/tortoise
a shell necklace
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mainly I collect books, postcards, dolls, silver bracelets and sea shells. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a place that protects you from bad weather or danger
dictionaryExamples: an emergency shelter
The city runs a homeless shelter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We all ran to hide [in] the little shelter we had built. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: protection from bad weather or danger
dictionaryExamples: We took shelter from the rain in a doorway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: John told me it was a [place] where we could find shelter. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to go under a cover or inside a building to be protected from bad weather or danger
dictionaryExamples: They took cover under a tree to shelter from the rain.

sense.def: a large, flat object that police officers and soldiers hold in front of their bodies to protect themselves
dictionaryExamples: The police protected themselves with shields.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The breed of white-skinned men that, every season, crammed in cars, campers, buses, boats or charter planes, leave their lands to ravage distant shores toting cameras and sun block as the barbarians of old held sword and shield. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to protect someone or something from something dangerous or unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: to shield your eyes from the sun
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, children raised by wealthy families are believed to be so "well-pampered" that they are shielded from the harshness of real problems - such as poverty or malnutrition. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to change an idea, attitude, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We are trying to shift the emphasis from curing illness to preventing it.
Media attention has shifted recently onto environmental issues.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since the 1990s, though, the situation has shifted. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to move to another place or position
dictionaryExamples: The wind shifted to the east.
She shifted her weight from one foot to the other.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even with the absence of cars in city centers, with people parking their cars in suburbs, we can now see new traffic problems, which have shifted from the city centers to suburbs. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: a period of work in a place such as a factory or hospital, or the people who do that work
dictionaryExamples: As the night shift leaves, the day shift arrives.
Are you on the night shift or the day shift?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I worked there in two shifts, in the mornings and in the evenings, for approximately 8-10 hours a day. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a change in something
dictionaryExamples: There has been a dramatic shift in public opinion on this matter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Proposal: Improving Zurich's transport and housing facilities. Census results of the last three decades have shown a shift in families' preferences on where to live. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: to produce bright light
dictionaryExamples: The sun was shining brightly through the window.
Is that light shining in your eyes?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather was good and the sun was shining. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: If a surface shines, it reflects light, and if you shine it, you make it reflect light.
dictionaryExamples: She polished her shoes until they shone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was so glad to see that little key shining in that box. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to do something very well, usually better than other people.
dictionaryExamples: It is in art that he really shines.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hard-working, intelligent, brave children can make the country shine in future. International English Language Testing System; C2; Kannada

sense.def: If your eyes or face shine, you look happy, healthy, or excited.
dictionaryExamples: His eyes were shining with excitement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For if we refer back to the poem, Mother Teresa certainly displays all of the qualities mentioned in that poem: on most of the photos showing her, she is smiling radiantly, her wrinkled face shining with bliss. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: A shiny surface is bright because it reflects light.
dictionaryExamples: beautiful shiny hair
shiny black shoes
a shiny silver dollar
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I prefer shiny tops and blue trousers. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a large boat that carries people or goods by sea
dictionaryExamples: a sailing ship
a merchant/naval ship
They boarded  a ship that was sailing  the next day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will go there by ship. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: a piece of clothing worn on the top part of the body, often made of thin material like cotton and fastened with buttons down the front
dictionaryExamples: a striped/white shirt
a short-/long-sleeved shirt
You've spilled something on your shirt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please wear your old shirt. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: to shake because you are cold or frightened
dictionaryExamples: She shivered  from the cold.
The poor dog - it's shivering!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was shivering not only because of the cold, but also because she had no idea what she was going to tell him. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a shaking of your body because you are cold, ill, or frightened
dictionaryExamples: "The temperature is down to 12 degrees," she said with a shiver.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No sooner had she open this letter than she felt a shiver of fear. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

blocks.phrase: send shivers/a shiver down your spine

sense.def: to make you feel afraid or excited
dictionaryExamples: The sound of his voice sent shivers down my spine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Simply looking at her sent shivers down his spine - there was the love of his life, the dearest woman on good old Earth, that he's never met before. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a big, unpleasant surprise
