dictionaryExamples: We got a nasty shock when he gave us the bill.
Her death came as a terrible shock to him.
They are still in  shock from the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was in shock. I read the letter again and again, the last part of the text said "Don't forget." Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a sudden, painful feeling that you get when electricity flows through your body
dictionaryExamples: I got a shock from the plug.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When their eyes [met] each others, both sensed some kind of electric shock, and they knew they were made for each other. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: a sudden movement caused by an explosion, accident, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Further shocks have been felt in the area today.

sense.def: to surprise and upset someone
dictionaryExamples: The ads were designed to shock - that was the whole point of the campaign.
Her painting might shock viewers.
The news of the accident shocked the family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They hardly could believe it, although that American woman always wants to shock them... First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: very surprised and upset
dictionaryExamples: After his announcement, there was shocked silence.

We were shocked to see smoke pouring out of the
                         roof.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was surprised and shocked. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: offensive, upsetting or immoral
dictionaryExamples: The book was considered shocking when it was first published.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The news was shocking but at the same time this  fact will change our life. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: a strong covering for the foot, often made of leather
dictionaryExamples: flat/high-heeled shoes
gym/tennis shoes
He put on/took off his new pair of shoes.
Hurry and tie your shoes.
a shoe store
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For your friend you can buy for example new shoes, trousers, maybe [a] hat. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to fire a weapon or injure or kill a person or animal by firing a weapon at them
dictionaryExamples: If he's not armed, don't shoot.
The kids were shooting arrows at a target.
An unidentified man was shot yesterday afternoon.
A policeman was shot last night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We really had a good time, but when we were coming back home a man, whose a face I couldn't see, shot Ana and she fell down on the street. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to try to score points in sports such as basketball by hitting, kicking, or throwing the ball toward the goal
dictionaryExamples: He shot from the middle of the court and still managed to score.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A[fter] I shot my first goal for this team they started to talk to me. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to use a camera to record a movie or video or to take a photograph
dictionaryExamples: We shot four reels of film in Egypt.
The movie was shot on location in Southern India.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Britney's was shot in a studio and she, hypothetically, was [o]n Mars. (762699; Certificate in Advanced English; Greece; C1 EFFECTIVE OPERATIONAL PROFICIENCY; 2000; Greek; Fail

sense.def: to move somewhere very quickly
dictionaryExamples: She shot across the road without looking.
She shot past me only inches from the finishing line.

sense.def: when a gun is fired, or when someone is injured or killed by a bullet from a gun
dictionaryExamples: We heard some shooting in the night.
There have been a number of shootings in the capital this week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He liked shooting very much and once [he went] [in]to the forest he didn't come back. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a store or other place where you can buy things or a service
dictionaryExamples: a gift/flower shop
a barber shop
a coffee shop
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have a part-time job as waitress in a coffee shop, and I don't really have  time to look for a history teacher. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Turkish

sense.def: to buy things in stores
dictionaryExamples: I like to shop at the Gap for clothes.
If I'm just shopping for food, I go to the local supermarket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to go out with you to shop [for] clothes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the activity of buying things from shops
dictionaryExamples: The store is open for late night shopping on Wednesdays.
My daughter and I go shopping together.
I was out shopping this afternoon.
I need to do some shopping on Saturday.
My granddaughter helps me with my grocery shopping.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She likes to go shopping with [a] friend. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bulgarian

sense.def: the area of land along the edge of the sea or a lake
dictionaryExamples: You can walk for miles along the shore.
We rode into the city along the shore of Lake Washington.
The boat was about a mile from (the)/off shore when the engine suddenly died.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were on the fourth floor, where you can see the se[a] shore and also the mountains behind. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: small in length, distance or height
dictionaryExamples: a short skirt
Her hair is much shorter than it used to be.
It's only a short walk to the station.
I'm really short but my brother's very tall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is quit[e] short, [and] she has got long, curly black hair, and black eyes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Others

sense.def: continuing for a small amount of time
dictionaryExamples: a short film/visit
He's grown so much in such a short time.
I work much better if I take a short break every hour or so.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's [a] short time but we are very busy because we do many exercises. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: A short book or other piece of writing has few pages or words.
dictionaryExamples: a short e-mail/letter
It's a very short book - you'll read it in an hour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sue This is a short note to tell you that I ha[ve] a new house. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to not have enough of something
dictionaryExamples: to be short of space/time
She ran a little farther and then stopped, feeling short of breath.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because I was short of money, I [said] yes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: describes a name that is used as a shorter form of a name
dictionaryExamples: Her name's Jo - it's short for Josephine.
Her name's Josephine, or Jo for short.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is even a strange disease called Chronic Fatigue Syndrom[e] (CFS for short). First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: only a short time before something happens
dictionaryExamples: I had to give a speech on very short notice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If required, I could additionally find time on week nights, however due to my professional duties I may have to cancel on short notice. International English Language Testing System; C2; German

sense.def: in a few words
dictionaryExamples: In short, we need more staff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In short, ancient Chinese poems, mainly [from the] Jang D[yna]sty, constitute [the] background for Chinese culture and set a touchstone for judgement in our life. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

blocks.phrase: to make a long story short

sense.def: to mention only the final result or point of something without going into other details
dictionaryExamples: To make a long story short, he never played baseball again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To make a long story short, my mother turned out to be an understanding person. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: cut sth short or cut short sth

sense.def: to have to stop doing something before it is finished
dictionaryExamples: They had to cut their vacation short when her mother was taken ill.

sense.def: to not reach a particular level, but only by a small amount
dictionaryExamples: Sales for the first half of this year fell just short of the target.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, it cannot be denied that public transport falls short of the target set during the planning process. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: to fail to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: His behavior falls short of what we expect.
She just fell short of the grades she needed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This routine was really wearing me out, but, I didn't want to fall short of my parents' expectations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to almost do something but decide not to do it
dictionaryExamples: She stopped short of accusing him of lying.

sense.def: when there is not enough of something
dictionaryExamples: There's a shortage of food and shelter for the earthquake survivors.
The long hot summer has led to serious water shortages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And there is a shortage [of] parking facilities. My opinion is that we need new parking facilities near to the city; parking docks, parking areas, etc.  First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a fault
dictionaryExamples: I like him despite his shortcomings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, there were a few shortcomings I would like to mention. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to become shorter or to make something shorter
dictionaryExamples: Smoking shortens your life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe we could shorten the free day to half a day and make use of the other half to bring them out for some sightseeing and familiari[z]ation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a short pair of pants that stop above or at the knees
dictionaryExamples: running/gym shorts
cargo/Bermuda shorts
He had on a pair of shorts and a T-shirt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Why don't you wear your old T-shirt with some faded jeans or shorts? Key English Test; A2; Kannada

sense.def: showing a lack of thought for what might happen in the future
dictionaryExamples: It’s shortsighted to spend all your money and not save for the future.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I think that it is a little bit shortsighted to project everything that seems not likely to be done during our “active” time as work[ers] in[to] the future "when we will have time enough." 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: lasting a short time, or relating to a short period of time
dictionaryExamples: short-term memory
a short-term weather forecast
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Setting up restricted areas for animals is a nice idea, but due to the overall pol[l]ution, [it is] only a short-term solution. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: when a bullet is fired from a gun or other weapon
dictionaryExamples: He fired four shots.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly he heard a shot and the lights went out. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when someone tries to score points in sports such as basketball by throwing or hitting the ball
dictionaryExamples: Roberts sank two foul shots to win the game.
Nadal's forehand shot down the line won him the match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I enjoy this sport because it forces me to improve my self control when playing: if I miss a shot, I have to stay very calm because it's the best way to achieve the next shot. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a photograph
dictionaryExamples: I got/took some really good shots of the harbor at sunset.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A] few months ago I had [the] chance to work abroad and see some of the Middle Eastern countries, where I took a lot of good shots. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to give advice
dictionaryExamples: I think you should see a doctor.
If you're annoyed with him, you should tell him.
You should change trains at Peterborough if you're going to Newcastle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should wear old clothes because we will get dirty. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: used to say or ask what is the correct or best thing to do
dictionaryExamples: "Should I apologize to him?"
Where should  we meet tonight?
There should be an investigation into the cause of the disaster.
I should have written to her but I haven't had any time.
It's getting cold in here. Should I  turn the heat up?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Should I call the police? Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say that you expect something to be true or that you expect something to happen
dictionaryExamples: My dry cleaning should be ready this afternoon.
If you follow these directions, you shouldn’t have any trouble finding our house.
I wonder what's happened to Annie. She should be  here by now.
That should be enough food for five people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have invite[d] all his friends, [so] we should be 28 people. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to ask or give the reason for something, especially when you are surprised or angry about it
dictionaryExamples: He wants me to give him my old car, but why should I?
Why shouldn't she get a new car if she wants one?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And personally I say "why should I read something in a book which I can watch on TV?" First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: one of the two parts of your body where your arms join your neck
dictionaryExamples: The baby laid his head on her shoulder.
Then she put her arm around my shoulder and said everything would be OK.
She glanced nervously over her shoulder to make sure no one else was listening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The name of the movie was Ghost Ship. It was a horror movie but it was so boring [that] she slept on my shoulder. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: someone who gives you sympathy when you are upset
dictionaryExamples: I always had a shoulder to cry on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am always there for her and I know I will always have a shoulder to cry on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

blocks.phrase: have a chip on your shoulder

sense.def: to blame other people for something bad that has happened to you and continue to feel angry about it
dictionaryExamples: She's always had a real chip on her shoulder because she didn't go to college.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suppose that I have a chip on my shoulder! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to say something very loudly
dictionaryExamples: "Look out!" she shouted.
I was angry and I shouted at him.
I shouted out her name but she didn't hear me.
I heard them shouting for help, but there was nothing I could do.
You don't have to shout, I can hear you.
"Is anybody home?" he shouted.
He shouted from the garage that he'd be finished in about half an hour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We shouted loud for the red team to win. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: when you say something very loudly or make a very loud sound with your voice
dictionaryExamples: He heard an angry shout.
shouts of anger
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only noise we could hear was the shouts of the hero[e]s fighting with terrible monsters coming from space... First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a tool with a long handle and a wide, metal part at one end used for digging and moving loose material
dictionaryExamples: a snow shovel
I need a shovel to dig a hole and plant the rose bush.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were equipped with a shovel and a bucket and dressed in shorts and T-shirt[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to let someone look at something
dictionaryExamples: I want to show you this new book I just bought.
He’s starting to show his age.
You should show that rash to your doctor.
Why won't you show me what you have in your hand?
These trees show the effects of acid rain.
He began to show signs of recovery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like showing my I.D. card every morning. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Turkish

sense.def: to give information in a book, on a website, on a piece of equipment, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The pictures show two different sports. Talk to your partner about which you would prefer and why.
The display shows the temperature on the right; air pressure is shown on the left.
Urban areas are shown in gray on the map.
The latest figures show a rise in home sales.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So it would be very kind of you to send me an information sheet or a brochure [about] your club and a timetable which shows the courses and the meetings. First Certificate in English; B2; German

blocks.phrase: show sb what to do/how to do sth

sense.def: to teach someone how to do something by explaining it or by doing it yourself while they watch
dictionaryExamples: She showed me how to use the new bookkeeping program.
Have you shown him what to do?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before the performance I [brought] the spectators to their seats and then a[n] instructor showed me how to [operate] the spotlights. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: If numbers, results, facts, etc. show something, they prove that it is true.
dictionaryExamples: Research shows that 40 percent of the program's viewers are aged over 55.
Sales figures showed a significant increase last month.
Your writing shows you can be a good writer.
She has shown herself (to be) a highly competent manager.
The diaries show (that) he was very insecure.
Our research has shown (us) how little we know about this disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Experiments have even shown some astonishing results, that apes for example have the same abilities as humans. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to express a feeling so that other people are able to notice it
dictionaryExamples: He finds it difficult to show affection.
She showed enormous courage when she rescued him from the fire.
I do not know how to show my thanks for all your help.
You should show your parents more respect/show more respect to your parents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think a face can show so much and some day I [hope] I could be[come] a photographer. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to be easy or possible to see, or to make something easy or possible to see
dictionaryExamples: The sadness really shows on her face.
Light-colored carpets show the dirt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their hair was turning gr[a]y and their faces showed [the] first wrinkles. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to go with someone and show them a place
dictionaryExamples: Alejandro offered to show her around Mexico City.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can take a few day[s] off work and show you around the city. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to try to make people admire your abilities or achievements in a way which other people find annoying
dictionaryExamples: She only bought that sports car to show off and prove she could afford one.
He's always showing off to his classmates.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can even show off a bit to your relatives and friends. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to arrive somewhere
dictionaryExamples: I invited him for eight o'clock, but he didn't show up until nine-thirty.
We were expecting thirty people to come, but half of them never showed up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took him to his father and then my friend, Maria, showed up. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: a television or radio program or a theater performance
dictionaryExamples: a TV show
a talk show
a variety/comedy show
I'd like to see a show while we're in London.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can see lots of traditional shows there, it will be very interesting for you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: an event at which a group of similar things are brought together for the public to see
dictionaryExamples: a fashion/flower show
We're going to the car/auto show on Saturday.
They put on a show of his work at the Museum of Modern Art.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I do not know if it is possible to make any change[s],  but we saw an ad in "Time Out" magazine last week about a fashion show which we would like to see. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: being shown to the public
dictionaryExamples: Her designs are currently on show at the Museum of Modern Art.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the facilit[ies] that really make[s] a difference is the Art Gallery, with its great exhibition on show, as well as the Art Library. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: the act of washing yourself while standing under a flow of water
dictionaryExamples: I want to take a quick shower before we go out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have to wake up [at] 7.30 AM. I run to the bathroom [to] take a shower. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: a piece of bathroom equipment that you stand under to wash your whole body
dictionaryExamples: He likes to sing in the shower.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And there are showers and [a] sauna you [will] be able to use any time after the gym. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a short period of rain or light snow
dictionaryExamples: thunder showers
a snow shower
There were showers on and off all afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well the weather was really good during the morning [but] [there were]  some showers during the afternoon. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to wash standing under a shower
dictionaryExamples: We all showered before breakfast.
I got up, showered, dressed, and ran out the door to catch the bus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Around six o'clock, she finally got up, showered, had breakfast and set off to work. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to give someone a lot of presents, praise, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He showered her with expensive gifts.
She was showered with compliments after her performance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As time passes the children start to see a pattern developing, every time that they request time or attention they are showered with expensive clothes or toys to compensate [for] the lack of it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: good at judging situations and making decisions which give you an advantage
dictionaryExamples: a shrewd politician
a shrewd business plan
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was only much later that I reali[z]ed what a shrewd investment on my parent's part this had been. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a small sea animal that you can eat, and which has a shell and ten legs
dictionaryExamples: The grilled shrimp is delicious!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has great food: fish, grill[ed] meat, shrimp and delicious cakes and cookies. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to become smaller, or to make something smaller
dictionaryExamples: Your sweater will shrink if you wash it at too high a temperature.
The company's profits have shrunk from £5.5 million to £1.25 million.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After 5 seconds I started shrinking until I was as small as the smallest toe on my foot. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to move your shoulders up and down to show that you do not care about something or that you do not know something
dictionaryExamples: I told him we weren't happy with it but he just shrugged his shoulders.
She just shrugged and said she didn't know.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Martina flushed to the root[s] of her hair and shrugged her shoulders. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to shake, usually because you are thinking of something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: The sight of so much blood made him shudder.
She shuddered at the thought of kissing him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She shuddered at the memory. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to close something, or to become closed
dictionaryExamples: Would you shut the door, please?
I can’t get this window shut.
Mary shut her book and put it down on the table.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The doors shut by [them]selves. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: If a computer or machine shuts down or someone shuts it down, it stops operating.
dictionaryExamples: Make sure you shut down your computer before you leave.
The crew shut down one of the four engines on the plane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was as happy as a lark. I shut down the computer and I called my mom to tell her about the good news. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: If a business or organization shuts down or someone shuts it down, it closes.
dictionaryExamples: The company plans to shut down four assembly plants and cut 10,000 jobs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A great [number] of zoos ought to be shut down. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to stop talking or making a noise, or to make someone do this
dictionaryExamples: I wish you'd shut up for a minute and listen to what the rest of us have to say.
Please just shut up! I’m trying to think.
My dad never stops talking. It's impossible to shut him up!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You must still remember that time we walked along the street, singing blues and rock, it's incredible the way that people shouted at us to shut up. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: closed
dictionaryExamples: Her office door was shut all day.
Her eyes were shut, but she was still awake.

sense.def: to not talk about something
dictionaryExamples: If you don't keep your mouth shut, there'll be trouble.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She made every effort to keep her mouth shut but it disturbed her to be the only one to know the truth, apart from her brother. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a bus, train, plane, etc. which travels regularly between two places, usually a short distance
dictionaryExamples: the Boston-New York shuttle
There's a shuttle service between the airport and the city center.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am convinced that a cent[e]r with less traffic and more pedestriani[z]ed areas will attract more other people. Especially if there is a parking opportunity outside of the cent[e]r with well-o[r]ganised shuttle buses to the cent[e]r. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; German

sense.def: not confident, especially about meeting or talking to new people
dictionaryExamples: He was too shy to ask her to dance with him.
Don't be shy - come join us.
a shy smile
Children can be shy around/with people they don't know.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was a little shy at first, but I ended up talking too much! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the state of being shy
dictionaryExamples: When I met the movie star, I was overcome with shyness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of them were encouraged by their work-fellows to overcome their initial shyness. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: a sister or brother
dictionaryExamples: I have three siblings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am also lucky to have a sibling, an older sister, who took great care of me when we were children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: not feeling well, or suffering from a disease
dictionaryExamples: a sick child
I feel sick.
I hope you don't get sick.
My boss was out sick most of last week.
Sarah called in sick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everybody went except Natalie because she was sick. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to be bored with or annoyed about something that has been happening for a long time
dictionaryExamples: I'm sick of people telling me how to run my life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Michael was sick of seeing the same story happen all over again. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: cruel and unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: He's got a sick mind.
a sick joke
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her sick mind was obsessed with the impunity that criminals were treated [with at] trials and with the corrupted jud[g][es that [hold] those trials, and decided she would kill all of them and put an end to the impunity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: likely to vomit
dictionaryExamples: I feel sick to my stomach.

sense.def: when you are sick
dictionaryExamples: I get motion sickness on a boat and sometimes on a plane, too.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The simpl[e] joy and happiness will help you to feel in good shape and keep away any sickness. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: one of the two parts that something would divide into if you drew a line down the middle
dictionaryExamples: He likes to sleep on the right side of the bed.
In Britain, cars drive on the left side of the road.
There is no money on my mother's side (of the family).
I could just see Joan on the far/other side of the room.
Children came running from all sides.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's an interest[ing] place because the Lake has a road through which cars can go to the other side of the Lake. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: a flat outer surface of an object, especially one that is not the top or the bottom
dictionaryExamples: The names of ships are usually painted on their sides.
My room is at the side of the house.
Please write on one side of the paper only.
Canadian coins have a picture of the Queen's head on one side.
Please use the side entrance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It cost 152 Euro. It's black with silver stripes on the sides. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: an edge or border of something
dictionaryExamples: A square has four sides.
There are trees on both sides of the road.
They were surrounded on every side by curious children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are going to paint one side of the room orange and the others w[h]ite. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the area next to something
dictionaryExamples: I have a small table at/by the side of  my bed.
He stood at/by her side  as she welcomed the guests one by one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Linda is by my side right now and she asks [me to] send you a warm hug. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: part of a situation that can be considered or dealt with separately
dictionaryExamples: She looks after the financial side of things.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I think for me the most important [thing] is to enjoy life - don't be worried [about] little things and always find the funny side of each situation. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a part of someone's character
dictionaryExamples: She has a very practical side.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact the film describes the actions of this politi[c]ian, also saying something not very "Politically Correct", but true: he reveals that no one is always good, everyone has a dark hidden side. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If two things or people are side by side, they are next to each other.
dictionaryExamples: We sat side by side on the sofa.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is not rare to see two people walking side by side, both talking on the phone. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If something moves from side to side, it moves from left to right and back again repeatedly.
dictionaryExamples: swinging from side to side
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I began to understand it when I went [to] Kenya in 1986, because I had the wonderful chance to look at the animals in their natural [surroundings], without being in a cage, walking nervously from side to side. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: one of the people or groups who are arguing, fighting, or competing
dictionaryExamples: Whose side is he on?
Whenever we argue he always takes Alice's side .
This is a war which neither side can win.
Don't be angry with me - I'm on your side.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you'll be on my side. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a way of considering something, especially when there is disagreement about it
dictionaryExamples: There are at least two sides to every question.
I've listened to your side of the story, but I still think you were wrong to do what you did.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This shows the other side of technology. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to find good things in a bad situation
dictionaryExamples: Look on the bright side - no one was badly hurt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am quite self-confident and I usually look on the bright side, as I am not [interested in] pessimistic thoughts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: A food served on the side is served separate from the other foods.
dictionaryExamples: I’ll have the salad with the dressing on the side.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A common meal in my country will include soup and rice, a main dish is usually served with beans on the side and corn tortillas, all this is full of vitamins and calcium. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to not use or deal with something now, but keep it for a later time
dictionaryExamples: She put the papers to one side, intending to read them later.

sense.def: in addition to your main job
dictionaryExamples: She does some freelance work on the side.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At work, they gave her the worst jobs to do. She knew she didn't have much choice but she still tried to find something else on the side. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the part of your family who are either your mother's relatives or your father's relatives
dictionaryExamples: They tend to be tall on my mother's side of the family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both on my father's side as well as on my mother's side of the family we formed a close knit group. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: the two areas of your body from under your arms to the tops of your legs
dictionaryExamples: Stand with your arms by your sides.
She lay on her side.

sense.def: If you have someone at/by your side, they support you and help you.
dictionaryExamples: With Dan at my side, I felt I could do anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She really needed someone by her side, someone to lean on and share her worries. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: another effect that a drug has on your body in addition to the main effect for which the doctor has given you the drug
dictionaryExamples: Headaches are one side effect of this drug.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now, we have come up with something called Phyto essence that is designed to overcome skin problems effectively without causing any harmful side effects. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: an extra result of a situation, especially one that you did not plan or expect
dictionaryExamples: One side effect of getting a new job is that I can cycle to work and I've lost a lot of weight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They seem to neglect the growing rate of unemployment and its possible side effects. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a path with a hard surface along one or both sides of a street that people walk on
dictionaryExamples: The sidewalk was blocked by a fallen tree branch.
a sidewalk café
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I was crossing the road I suddenly saw a beautiful woman [o]n the opposite sidewalk. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: in a direction to the left or right, not forward or backward
dictionaryExamples: The fence is leaning sideways.
If you would move sideways to the left, I can get everyone in the picture.
Take two sideways steps.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unaware of all the sideways glances and chatter that paused as she passed, she headed back toward the river. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to breathe out slowly and noisily, often because you are annoyed or unhappy
dictionaryExamples: She sighed deeply and sat down.
"I wish he was here," she sighed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having solid ground beneath her feet again she sighed with relief for having survived this adventure. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the sound that is made when someone sighs
dictionaryExamples: He read the letter and gave a deep sigh.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I entered the house with a deep sigh! First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: the ability to see
dictionaryExamples: If your sight is poor, you should not drive a car.
The old woman has lost her sight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had lost her sight although doctors didn't know if it was forever. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: places of interest, especially to visitors
dictionaryExamples: We spent a two weeks in Rome looking at all the sights.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have many plans, I want to show you all [the] remarkable sights in Georgia. Preliminary English Test; B1; Georgian

sense.def: when you see someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I faint at the sight of my own blood.
The child laughed at the sight of  the circus clown.
She hated/loathed the sight of  her former husband.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just think; drinking our cold beers against the sight of the pounding waves and feeling the wind on our faces. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: the area that it is possible for you to see
dictionaryExamples: Keep your bags in sight at all times.
Don't let the children out of your sight at the park.
Billy was hidden out of sight  behind a tree.
The castle came into sight  as we hiked up the hill.
We're looking for a house within sight of  the mountains.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Editor, This morning when I opened my newspaper, my eyes caught sight of an article called "Failure of festival", and I read it. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when you fall in love with someone the first time you meet
dictionaryExamples: We were happened to be seated at the same table, and it was love at first sight!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had first met the spring before and it was love at first sight. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when you first see or hear about something or someone
dictionaryExamples: It may, at first sight, seem a surprising choice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must admit that, at first sight, I did not feel like reading it, but later I made up my mind and decided to accept your invitation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to forget about an important idea or fact because you are thinking too much about other, less important things
dictionaryExamples: We mustn't lose sight of the original aims of this project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Little do we realize that in the process we lose sight of the fundamentals, which in this case is the protection of our environment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to decide to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: She's set her sights on becoming a doctor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This resemblance was the final silent argument that convinced Wormold to promise Milly the expensive and beautiful horse she had set her sights on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to see something suddenly, often only for a short time
dictionaryExamples: He caught sight of himself in the mirror.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All we could see were people bursting into tears when they caught sight of his coffin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the activity of visiting places that are interesting because they are historic, famous, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Did you do much sightseeing while you were in Paris?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to go sightseeing and eat Italian food. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: a symbol or message in a public place that gives information or instructions
dictionaryExamples: a stop sign
I saw a "For Rent" sign in the window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And it [is] easy to get there, just follow the sign. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: something which shows that something is happening or that it exists or is true
dictionaryExamples: Flowers are the first sign of spring.
There was nobody in the place, and I thought that was a bad sign.
His inability to handle the situation is a sign of weakness.
The fact that he's eating more is a sign that he's feeling better.
There's no sign of progress with the construction work.
Allie's work at school has shown signs of improvement.
There is every sign that the worst is over.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bride and the groom meet at the church because it's a bad sign if the groom sees the bride before the ceremony. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a movement you make to give someone information or tell them what to do
dictionaryExamples: She pointed to her watch as a sign that it was getting late and she wanted to leave.
He made the thumbs up sign, so I knew everything was OK.
Give me a sign when you're ready to head home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She looked at Paul and made a strange sign with her fingers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a written or printed mark which has a standard meaning
dictionaryExamples: + and - are mathematical signs.
Use a dollar sign in the chart instead of writing the word, for example use $14, not 14 dollars.
The sign for the British pound is £.

sense.def: If there is no sign of someone or something, you cannot see them.
dictionaryExamples: By eight o'clock, there was still no sign of Janne.
She said she'd left the book on the table, but there's no sign of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was supposed to come on Wednesday just like you told me but there was no sign of him. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to write your name on something to show that you created it or to show that you agree to it
dictionaryExamples: to sign a letter/form/check/contract/agreement
Sign here, please.
Jesse signed her name at the end of the letter.
He signed himself "Andrew Mahat."
She said the painting was by Picasso, but it wasn't signed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was signed "Fat Boy". Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: to arrange to take part in an organized activity
dictionaryExamples: I've signed up for evening classes at the community college.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are interested in other activities, just sign up for them [on] the notice board. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: a movement, light, or sound that gives information, or tells people what to do
dictionaryExamples: At a signal from their teacher, the children all held up their flags.
Don't move until I give the signal.
The whistle was a signal that the races had started.
The police officer gave us a signal to stop.
What's the signal for "stop"?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The signal was given. We started side by side but soon I overtook him. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a series of light waves or sound waves which are sent to a radio, television, cell phone, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I can't get a phone signal here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand you can face problems with signal transmission. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: to make a movement that gives information or tells people what to do
dictionaryExamples: He signaled left, then turned the truck slowly.
He was signaling  with an orange flag.
The police officer signaled for us to stop.
She signaled to the oncoming car that that it going the wrong way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He signalled his trust[y] and mostly silent cameraman to follow him and decided to go underground. (761364; Certificate of Proficiency in English; Spain; C2 MASTERY; 2000; Catalan; Pass

sense.def: your name written by yourself, always in the same way, usually to show that something has been written or agreed by you
dictionaryExamples: Please put your signature in this box.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought it was a joke but when I saw the signature I knew it was for real. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the importance or meaning of something
dictionaryExamples: I still don't understand the significance of his remark.
This is a development which has great economic significance for the region.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In spite of the progress achieved in promoting the social status of women, one should not overestimate the significance of these achievements to ordinary women's careers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: important or noticeable
dictionaryExamples: There has been a significant increase in the number of women students in recent years.
These measures will save a significant amount of money.
The talks between the USA and Russia were very significant for the relationship between the two countries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the most significant invention[s] is [the] computer. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a sign by the side of the road that gives information about routes and distances
dictionaryExamples: There are signposts at the edge of the parking lot showing which paths lead to the lake and which to the tent sites and the camp store.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were no signposts and there was no one to ask where he could find a place to stay. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: when there is no sound
dictionaryExamples: The three men ate in silence.
A loud crash of thunder broke the silence of the night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It isn't too big and [it's] quiet enough and I like it so much because of the silence and the beauty of this [place]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a period of time in which there is complete quiet or no speaking
dictionaryExamples: There were long silences during the discussion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The progress of the story is very slow, but the author is descri[b]ing hard conditions, hard characters [and] long silences, which is quite t[y]pical of his way [of writing]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a period of time when someone says nothing about a particular subject or when someone does not communicate with someone at all
dictionaryExamples: She ended her silence yesterday and spoke to a TV reporter about the accident.
I took his long silence to mean that I had offended him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How dared he call her after such a long silence and order her what to do? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Slovene

sense.def: without any sound
dictionaryExamples: The empty house was completely silent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The countryside, like Chianti, is peaceful and silent. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: without talking
dictionaryExamples: I have remained silent till now, Mike, but I have to tell you what I think.
The suspect was told that he had the right to remain silent.
So far, he's been silent about his plans for the future.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When they were there, Aunt Patience was obliged by her husband to go to her room and remain silent. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: without making any noise
dictionaryExamples: She wept silently as she read the letter.
He silently vowed to take revenge.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After waiting silently for two minutes, she dropped the phone. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a type of cloth which is light and smooth
dictionaryExamples: a silk dress
a silk shirt
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Normally, I would prefer my blouses to be made of cotton or silk, as these materials make me [feel] comfortable. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: showing little thought or judgment
dictionaryExamples: a silly question
a silly mistake
It was silly of you to go out in the sun without a hat.
I feel silly  in this dress.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They had some very silly games. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: small and not important
dictionaryExamples: She gets upset over such silly things.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Pe[o]ple are so worried about silly things, about how to make money or how to be popular and they forget about what really matters. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a valuable, shiny, gray-white metal used to make coins and jewelry
dictionaryExamples: We gave Alison and Tom a dish made of solid silver as a wedding present.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a beautiful ring, it was made of silver with a diamond on it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: made of silver, or of the color of silver
dictionaryExamples: a silver ring
My grandmother has silver hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I g[o]t bea[u]tiful presents, but my favorite is a silver ring. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: knives, forks, and spoons
dictionaryExamples: Do we have enough silverware for twelve people?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All [the] tablecloths are white and [the] silverware is beautiful. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If something or someone is similar to another thing or person, they have many things the same, although they are not exactly the same.
dictionaryExamples: My father and I have similar views on politics.
I bought some new shoes which are very similar to a pair I had before.
Paul is very similar in appearance to his brother.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can understand how you are feeling because at our age, every teenager has similar problems. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: when two things or people are similar, or a way in which they are similar
dictionaryExamples: I can see the similarity between you and your mother.
The book bears several striking similarities to last year's bestseller.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another similarity between the two was their appearance. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in a similar way
dictionaryExamples: The children were similarly dressed.
Cars must stop at red traffic lights; similarly, bicycles should stop too.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, in northeast China, Australian visitors can learn the specific tea culture from local people. [...] Similarly, Chinese visitors can know the Australian wine culture by visiting the wineries. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: easy to do or to understand
dictionaryExamples: The instructions were written in simple English.
It's simple to find our house.
I want an explanation, but keep/make it simple.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you need some help, I can help you with the organization of the titles and other simple things. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: plain or not complicated
dictionaryExamples: a simple life
a simple black dress
We had a simple meal of bread and cheese.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can eat simple food and drink good local wine. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used to describe the one important fact, truth, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We didn't go swimming for the simple reason that the water was too cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a very simple reason for me to choose live music. I really enjoy going to  places in w[h]ich you can see a good concert. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the quality of being simple
dictionaryExamples: The advantage of the plan is its simplicity.
The examination was simplicity itself.
I admire the simplicity of her designs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Video facilities are rated as quite good [by] the students, and computer programs have gained almost everybody's compl[i]ments for their simplicity and efficacy. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the process of making something more simple
dictionaryExamples: I think these rules need some simplification.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It might be a simplification and an exaggeration, but as the word says: "The road of excess leads to the tower of wisdom", and although the idea expresses itself in crude terms, I do think there is some truth to it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to make something less complicated and therefore easier to do or understand
dictionaryExamples: the new, simplified tax system
He tried to simplify the story for the younger audience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The technology has probably simplified life [i]n a way that no one could beli[e]ve was possible about 20 years ago. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to emphasize what you are saying
dictionaryExamples: We simply don't have the time.
The hunger in parts of Africa is terrible - there's simply  no other word for it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's simply unbelievable! First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: only
dictionaryExamples: A lot of people miss out on this opportunity simply because they don't know about it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very interested in fashion, simply because it is a style, an attitude, a way of life. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: in a way that is not complicated or difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: He explained it as simply as he could, but the class still didn't understand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Try to organize your work as simply as possible. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a model of something that can be used to teach someone how to do something, or the process of making such a model
dictionaryExamples: Students can study a computer simulation of these atomic processes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Civili[z]ation is one of the best-selling simulation games of all time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai

sense.def: If two or more things are simultaneous, they happen or exist at the same time.
dictionaryExamples: simultaneous translation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The people I most admire are simultaneous interpreter[s]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: at the same time
dictionaryExamples: Two children answered the teacher's question simultaneously.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The floods of information pour towards you and go through your brain simultaneously. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: something which is against the rules of a religion
dictionaryExamples: the sin of greed/pride
to commit a sin
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nurses and doctors in white or green overalls, smells of drugs and sweating patients, moans of pain during the night, all that was like sending me to hell for a sin I knew nothing about. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: something that you should not do because it is morally wrong
dictionaryExamples: You've only got one life and it's a sin to waste it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be a sin not to grasp the opportunities one is given. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: from a time in the past until a later time or until now
dictionaryExamples: A lot has happened since 1980.
England hasn't won the World Cup since 1966.
It was the hottest October since we began keeping records.

sense.def: from a time in the past until a later time or until now
dictionaryExamples: He's been much happier since he started his new job.
I've known Tim since he was seven.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was really surprised when I read the e-mail because I haven't heard from you since I visited you last year. Preliminary English Test; B1; Romansch

sense.def: because
dictionaryExamples: Since we've got a few minutes to wait for the train, let's have a cup of coffee.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since my mother has surgery tomorrow, I will not [be able to] come to your class. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: from a time in the past until a later time or until now
dictionaryExamples: Emma went to work in New York a year ago, and we haven't seen her since.
He started working for the company after graduation and has been there ever since.
I've long since  forgotten any Latin I ever knew.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was my grandmother who introduced me to teddy bears and she wanted me to love them as she did. When she died, I got all her bears and have been taking care of them ever since. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: honest and saying or showing what you really feel or believe
dictionaryExamples: He seems to be sincere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During these years I have also found her to be honest, sincere, hard-working and imagin[a]tive. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: used to add emphasis when you are expressing a feeling
dictionaryExamples: The family wishes to express their sincere thanks to all the staff at the hospital.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Again, sincere gratitude for your kind work. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the quality of being sincere
dictionaryExamples: There was no doubting his sincerity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His sincerity shines through from his poems and it still moves us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to make musical sounds with your voice
dictionaryExamples: The children sang two songs by Schubert at the school concert.
The singing of the birds woke us early this morning.
Will you sing us a song/sing a song for us?
We sang along to a CD as we drove.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We sang songs and danced. Key English Test; A2; Singhalese

sense.def: a person who sings, especially as a job
dictionaryExamples: Kiri Te Kanawa is a famous singer from New Zealand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is my favorite singer and I ha[ve] all his CD[s]. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: the activity of singing
dictionaryExamples: She's taking singing lessons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies are singing, dancing, skating, basketball and so on. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: not married
dictionaryExamples: a single woman/man/person
He's been single for so long now, I don't think he'll ever marry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He's 25 years [old] and single. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: for only one person
dictionaryExamples: a single bed
a single room
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [am] sell[ing] a single bed. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: someone who has a child or children, but no wife or husband living with them
dictionaryExamples: Many single parents find it difficult to arrange for child care.
single-parent families
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She's a single parent, with 3 children from Australia. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to emphasize that you are talking about each one of a group or series
dictionaryExamples: I call him every single day.
The decision affected every single one of them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But we used to play together every single day! Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: only one
dictionaryExamples: There was a single light in the corner of the room.
Not a single person offered to help her.
You haven't been listening to a single word I've been saying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The night was calm and not a single sound was disturbing her. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: The singular form of a word is used to talk about one person or thing. For example, "car" is the singular form of "cars" and "woman" is the singular form of "women."
dictionaryExamples: a singular ending/form/noun/verb
The word "woman" is singular.

sense.def: a word or form that shows that there is only one of something
dictionaryExamples: The singular of "children" is "child."
The word "teeth" is plural - in the singular it's "tooth."

sense.def: to go down or make something go down below the surface of water or a soft substance and not come back up
dictionaryExamples: The Titanic was a passenger ship which sank to the bottom of the ocean in 1912.
The boat filled with water and began to sink.
The legs of the garden chair sank into the soft ground.
The dog sank its teeth into  the ball and ran off with it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were so scared that the boat would sink... First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to move or make something move to a lower position or level
dictionaryExamples: The sun glowed red as it sank slowly below the horizon.
Student numbers have sunk considerably this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dora's face grew pale and she sank [into] a chair. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a bowl that is fixed to the wall in a kitchen or bathroom in which you wash dishes, your hands, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a bathroom/kitchen sink
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I put my watch on the sink in the bathroom. Key English Test; A2; Slovak

sense.def: to drink, taking only a small amount at a time
dictionaryExamples: She sipped her champagne.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reasons for my choice are far from being profound: maybe it is only the desire of going back to a time when wom[e]n [...] could spend all the time brushing their hair or sipping tea, without feeling guilty for wasting their time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: a small amount of drink taken into the mouth
dictionaryExamples: He took a sip of his coffee and then continued.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a regular afternoon, like all the other summer afternoons in the city, when you gasp for breath and are willing to reveal the secrets of your best friends for a sip of water. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: used as a formal and polite way of speaking to a man, especially one who you are providing a service to or who is in a position of authority
dictionaryExamples: Would you like to see the menu, sir?
"Did you hear what I said?" "Yes, sir."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, the man with the hat, sunglasses, and mask came to me and sa[id] "sir, what is your name?"Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: a way of beginning a formal letter to a man whose name you do not know
dictionaryExamples: Dear Sir, I am writing to...
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir or Madam, With reference to your advertisement in the Wall Street Journal [...] First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a piece of equipment that makes a loud sound as a warning
dictionaryExamples: a police siren
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Almost immediately he heard the police sirens wailing and saw two officers spring from the panda car. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a girl or woman who has the same parents as another person
dictionaryExamples: Sophie and Emily are sisters.
Emily is Sophie's younger/little/older/big sister.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was there with my parents and sister. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a woman married to your brother, or the sister of your husband or wife
dictionaryExamples: My sister-in-law is a great cook.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, I and a sister-in-law had to stay with our little sons without any entertainment at the hotel. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to be in a position with the weight of your body on your bottom and the top part of your body up, for example, on a chair
dictionaryExamples: Emma was sitting on a stool.
The children sat at the table by the window.
We sat by the river and had a picnic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [It] is so bor[ing], bec[a]use we just sit and listen to [the] teachers. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: to move your body into a sitting position after you have been standing
dictionaryExamples: She came over and sat beside me.
She sat down on the grass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After one or two hours dancing, I had to sit down and drink. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to make someone sit somewhere
dictionaryExamples: She sat me down and told me the bad news.
I thought we'd sit the children at the end of the table.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wasn't prepared at all when my parents sat me down to tell me that my mother had been diagnosed with cancer, more specifically, a brain tumor. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a Web site
dictionaryExamples: He visits a lot of music sites.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can visit [our] site [on the] Internet or phone us [at] 332679. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: a place where something is, was, or will be built, or where something happened, is happening, or will happen
dictionaryExamples: a building site
The site for the new school hasn't been chosen yet.
This is the site of the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I work as a civil engineer on a site. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: inside a factory, office building, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There are two restaurants on site.
They provide on-site childcare facilities for employees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A small period of training on site is required a few days before the beginning of the job itself and how many interesting people you will meet! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: the set of things that are happening and the conditions that exist at a particular time and place
dictionaryExamples: the economic/political situation
"Would you get involved in this dispute?" "It would depend on the situation."
I was in a situation where I didn’t have cash handy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a weird situation. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the number 6
dictionaryExamples: Look for a bus with a number six on the front of it.
"How many grandchildren do you have now?" "I have six (grandchildren)."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My place [has] six rooms. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Gujarati

sense.def: the number 16
dictionaryExamples: fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, seventeen
We've got sixteen (people) coming for lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi! My name is Ian and I'm sixteen years old. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: 6th written as a word
dictionaryExamples: I have to return my library books on the sixth (of July).
Jesse came in sixth in the 100 meters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The room I like best is room 8 because it's [on] the sixth floor and I can see many people in the street. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the number 60
dictionaryExamples: fifty, sixty, seventy
There are sixty (people) coming to the wedding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were about sixty people, I can't remember their names. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: to be aged between 60 and 69
dictionaryExamples: I started doing yoga in my sixties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is in her middle sixties, but still very active and lively. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the years 1960 through 1969
dictionaryExamples: I still love all that music from the sixties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another problem is the demoli[t]ion of old houses that took place during the sixties. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: how large or small something or someone is
dictionaryExamples: The size of those trees is amazing.
What is the size of that window?
The field was about four acres in size.
He had a lump on his head the size of  an egg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My new phone's got Bluetooth and camera.  I like its small size because I can take it everywhere. Key English Test; A2; Polish

sense.def: one of the different measurements in which things, for example clothes, food containers, etc. are made
dictionaryExamples: a size 14 dress
Do these shoes come  in children's sizes?
What size are you?/What is your size?/What size do you wear/take?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have a beautiful blue and white coat to sell, size 16. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: many different types of people or things
dictionaryExamples: We saw people there of all shapes and sizes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personal challenges come in all shapes and sizes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a boot with a metal part on the bottom, used for moving across ice, or a boot with  wheels on the bottom used for moving across the ground
dictionaryExamples: a pair of ice skates
a pair of inline/roller skates
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell a pair of skates that I bought two years ago. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: to move using skates
dictionaryExamples: The ice on the river is frozen enough to skate on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We skated [for] two or three hours. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a board with wheels on the bottom, that you stand on and move forward by pushing one foot on the ground
dictionaryExamples: I've got a new skateboard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I g[o]t a video game and a beautiful skateboard. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the activity of moving using a skateboard
dictionaryExamples: We're going skateboarding at the park later.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies are skateboarding [and] listening [to] the radio. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: the activity or sport of moving on skates
dictionaryExamples: ice/inline/roller skating
Do you want to go skating tomorrow?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like playing volleyball, reading books and going skating with my friends. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the structure made of all the bones in the body of a person or animal
dictionaryExamples: We found an old sheep skeleton up on the cliffs.
Her long illness reduced her to a skeleton.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the USA, they enjoy dressing up in costumes, most of the time as skeletons, wi[t]ches or ghosts. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: the smallest number of people that you need to keep an organization working
dictionaryExamples: The Red Cross has withdrawn all but a skeleton staff from the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The life-rescuing services are on call and a skeleton staff remains in all hospitals. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: doubting that something is true or useful
dictionaryExamples: They’re very skeptical of his motives.
He was skeptical about hiring a consultant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally, I am very skeptical about this society's capacity to solve the homeless problem. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a picture that you draw quickly and with few details
dictionaryExamples: He did a quick sketch of the cat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Picasso would start with a lot of preliminary sketches and then go on to paint his final picture where the main figures - a woman and a horse - are screaming in despair. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a short piece of acting about a funny situation
dictionaryExamples: They wrote most of their sketches themselves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a partly live show, but it also contains earlier recorded "sketches," often with funny stunts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Norwegian

sense.def: a short description of something without many details
dictionaryExamples: He gave us a quick sketch of the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having seen the call for new subject proposals I'm sending you a preliminary sketch of two new courses. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Czech

sense.def: to give a short description with few details, especially of an idea or plan
dictionaryExamples: I've sketched out some ideas for my new book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The way I would bring up my own children, right now I'm not too sure if I'm ever going to have one or even more, wouldn't differ a great deal from the way I sketched out at the beginning. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: one of a pair of long, thin pieces of wood or plastic that you wear on the bottom of boots to move over snow
dictionaryExamples: a pair of skis
ski boots
a ski club/resort
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We stayed one week in a chalet near the ski resort. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to move over snow on skis
dictionaryExamples: He skied down the hill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There're two very good places where we can ski, and they aren't crowded! Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: the sport of moving over snow on skis
dictionaryExamples: We're going skiing next weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Jim, I have left my coat at your house. It's important be[cau]se I'm going skiing tomorrow! Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: an ability to do a job or an activity well, especially because you have practiced it
dictionaryExamples: Ruth had great management skills.
He lacked skill as a painter.
Schools often do not provide students with marketable skills.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to improve my listening and speaking skills. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: having the abilities needed to do an activity or job well
dictionaryExamples: skilled workers/labor
a highly skilled photographer
My mother is a skilled at dressmaking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know you [need] some skilled people to build the boat and therefore I hope I can join your club to help you. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: good at doing something
dictionaryExamples: a skillful artist
You have to be very skillful to be a race car driver.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Laura was a very skillful pianist. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: done or made very well
dictionaryExamples: skillful use of language
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If the players do not play as a team, like fighti[n]g between players, refusing to pass balls to certain player[s], not follow[ing] the tactics made by the couch, it can easily [be] imagined that such a team can not have a good result or even a skillful match. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the outer layer of a person or animal's body
dictionaryExamples: dark/fair skin
skin cancer
Babies have soft skin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She's got blue eyes and fair skin. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the outer layer of a fruit or vegetable
dictionaryExamples: a banana/potato skin
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, I slipped on the banana skin, fell down and had an unpleasant accident. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to not do something that you usually do or that you should do
dictionaryExamples: I think I'll  skip lunch today - I'm not very hungry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He felt a bit sick and so he skipped the meal. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to avoid reading or talking about something by starting to read or talk about the next thing instead
dictionaryExamples: I usually skip the boring bits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This sharpen[s] your translating skills and your vocabulary (since you can't just skip words you don't understand even if you get the general idea). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a piece of clothing for women and girls that hangs from the waist and does not have legs
dictionaryExamples: She wore a skirt and blouse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the summer [you] don't need warm clothes, just [a] skirt and t-shirt and that's it. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hindi

sense.def: the part of your head that is made of bone and which protects your brain
dictionaryExamples: I fell and cracked my skull.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When she hit his head, like a batsman hitting a six, his skull crushed with an awfully crunchy noise. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the area above the earth in which clouds, the sun, and stars can be seen
dictionaryExamples: a blue/cloudy/dark sky
Can you see those birds high up in the sky?
White clouds dotted the sky.
We looked up at the sky when we heard the plane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will use white and light blue, like the sky. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to close with great force, or to make something close with great force
dictionaryExamples: The wind made the door slam shut.
Close the door carefully, don't slam it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once the door slammed behind her, the tears came... First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

blocks.phrase: slam sth down/onto/into, etc. / slam down/onto/into, etc. sth

sense.def: to put something somewhere or to hit something with great force
dictionaryExamples: She slammed the phone down.

He slammed on 
                      the brakes to avoid hitting a squirrel that had run out in front of his car.
The truck slammed into an oncoming car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then he slammed down the receiver. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: informal language, often language that is only used by people who belong to a particular group
dictionaryExamples: prison slang
