sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's because communication with natives and not experienced English teachers will probably make you enrich your idiomatic and slang vocabulary [rather] than your academic vocabulary. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to hit someone with the flat, inside part of your hand
dictionaryExamples: She slapped his face.
She slapped him across the face.
His friends slapped him on the back when he said he was getting married .
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She shouted and slapped my face. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: something someone does that insults or upsets you
dictionaryExamples: After all that hard work, losing my job was a real slap in the face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father noticed that and decided it was high time to take me down a peg or two. He used to work as a volunteer in [a] hospital for children dying for cancer. One day, he took me there. It was like a slap in the face - suddenly I saw a different world. It was a bleak world, without smiles and happy faces. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a hit with the flat, inside part of your hand
dictionaryExamples: She slapped her knee and laughed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course there will be moments where you have to mark out a border to the child by a firm grip on his arm or a slap on his bottom, but it shouldn't have to happen very often. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a mark (/) used in writing to separate words or numbers, often to show a choice of connection
dictionaryExamples: Visit us at cambridge.org/esl and enter a word in the Dictionaries Online search box.

sense.def: when a lot of people or animals are killed in a cruel way
dictionaryExamples: They were sickened by the slaughter they witnessed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I think this change must be appreciated both [because of] the fact that a vegetarian diet is healthier and [because] it prevents the slaughter of animals. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who is  owned by someone else and has to work for them
dictionaryExamples: I'm tired of being treated like a slave!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know you're lazy sometimes but don't worry you don't have to work [like] a slave. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: the system of owning slaves, or the condition of being a slave
dictionaryExamples: They campaigned for the abolition of slavery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the condition of slavery, the Greeks passed to life in a fully developed and democratic country. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to be in the state of rest when your eyes are closed, your body is not active, and your mind is unconscious
dictionaryExamples: Sleep well!
I couldn't sleep because of all the noise next door.
I slept late on Sunday morning.
How can Jayne sleep at night with everything she has on her mind!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I watch television, I read magazines or I sleep. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: to wait until the next day before making a decision about something important so that you can think about it carefully
dictionaryExamples: I didn't know what to say to Laura, so I decided to sleep on it.

sense.def: to not have any sleep
dictionaryExamples: I was so excited last night - I didn't sleep a wink.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, due to the fact that I hadn't slept a wink the previous night, I began to fall asleep. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to have sex with someone
dictionaryExamples: She accused him of sleeping with her friend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Liza dreams of becoming a "real actress" and plays a very naive character who is willing to sleep with anyone who might lead her to success. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: the resting state in which the body is not active and the mind is unconscious
dictionaryExamples: I have to get some sleep - I'm exhausted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that, I was very tired and went home to get some sleep. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to succeed in sleeping
dictionaryExamples: I was so worried, I couldn't get to sleep at all last night.
I usually sit up in bed and read for a while before going to sleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since it's quite hot here I bought a fan, I have to use it at night otherwise I can't get to sleep. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: a period of sleeping
dictionaryExamples: He fell into a deep sleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need a sunny and friendly bedroom that give[s] me a relax[ing] sleep.  Because a good sleep is [an] important thing to begin a new day. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to worry about something
dictionaryExamples: I know she's angry with me, but I'm not losing any sleep over it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [There] was just one house, a magnificent mansion behind a high fence, that bothered me a bit. No one from there came to meet me. But in the hassle of the first few weeks I was simply too busy to lose any sleep over it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: feeling tired and wanting to go to sleep
dictionaryExamples: The heat had made me sleepy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I felt sleepy [during] the film, but Yoshie enjoyed [it]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: quiet and with little activity
dictionaryExamples: a sleepy little town
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't know much about it because it never got into my remote, sleepy village. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the part of a jacket, shirt, etc. that covers your arm
dictionaryExamples: short/long sleeves
The sleeves are too long for me.
You'd better roll your sleeves up or you'll get them dirty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also bought you a pink chiffon dress.  It's a new fashionable one with high collar and short sleeves. (2125172; Preliminary English Test; Thailand; B1 THRESHOLD; 2006; Thai; Pass

sense.def: to have a secret plan
dictionaryExamples: They were worried he might have another nasty surprise up his sleeve.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, I would never hit them - parents should always have something up their sleeve to find a humane solution. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: thin in an attractive way
dictionaryExamples: a slender woman with long, red hair
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On stage then appeared what I had dreamed of being, when I was a little girl, a princess-looking creature with long black hair, slender body and slow movements. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a flat piece of food that has been cut from a larger piece
dictionaryExamples: a slice of bread/cake
cucumber/lemon slices
Would you like another slice of pizza?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I kept a slice [of] the cake for you! Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a part of something, such as an amount of money
dictionaryExamples: We agreed before we made the deal that we'd both take an equal slice of the profit.
The movie presents us with a fascinating slice of history.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It [is] difficult to know that now[a]days we can kill each other only for an idea or for a slice of land. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to cut something into thin, flat pieces
dictionaryExamples: Slice the mushrooms and fry in butter.
Could you slice me a very thin piece of cake/slice a very thin piece of cake for me?

sense.def: small and not important
dictionaryExamples: a slight improvement
We're having a slight problem with our computer system.
I haven't the slightest idea what he's talking about.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To conclude, today's way of eating is not really healthy, but we can notice a slight improvement. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a little
dictionaryExamples: She's slightly taller than her sister.
I'm slightly upset that she forgot my birthday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I guess I look slightly different now, after all it has been two years since you last saw me. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: Someone who is slim is thin in an attractive way.
dictionaryExamples: a slim figure
He's slim and of average height.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is tall and slim. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: small and not as much as you would like
dictionaryExamples: There's a slim chance he'll succeed.

sense.def: to slide by accident and fall or almost fall
dictionaryExamples: She slipped on the ice.
Careful you don't slip - there's water on the floor.
The razor slipped while he was shaving and he cut himself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But then I slipped and fel[l] down. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to put something somewhere quickly or secretly
dictionaryExamples: She slipped the letter into an envelope and sealed it.

sense.def: to go somewhere quietly or quickly
dictionaryExamples: I'll slip out of the room if I get bored.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mission was to slip out of the ballroom and take pictures of the papers about the plans of Britain regarding the war. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to slide out of the correct position
dictionaryExamples: The photo had slipped from the frame.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She said, "I got a letter from the hotel today. The diary was in it. It had slipped between the beds." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If something slips your mind, you forget about it.
dictionaryExamples: I meant to tell her Nigel had phoned, but it completely slipped my mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was something but it slipped my mind before I reached it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: If someone's power or the possibility of them winning or achieving something slips away, it disappears.
dictionaryExamples: Down to ten men, the team was determined not to let victory slip away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I immediately saw my dream slip away. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to leave secretly
dictionaryExamples: He slipped away from the party as soon as he could.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, my mother sometimes behaved like a hen looking out for her little ones for fear one of us could slip away. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If someone slips away, they die.
dictionaryExamples: Despite their care, he slipped away in the night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This can sometimes ease the burden of watching someone you love slip away.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If a period of time slips away, it seems to pass quickly.
dictionaryExamples: As the months slipped away, I began to forget what he looked like.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are pressed to make money and their major concern seems to be the time that always slips away. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If a remark slips out, you say it without intending to.
dictionaryExamples: I didn't mean to tell anyone you were getting married - it just slipped out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could not understand how these words had slipped out of my mouth. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to make a mistake
dictionaryExamples: These figures don't make sense - have we slipped up somewhere?

sense.def: smooth and wet and difficult to hold or walk on
dictionaryExamples: Be careful - the floor's slippery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We arrived at the mountain at seven o'clock [in] the morning and because the previous night it [had been] raining, the rocks were slippery. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a short phrase that is easy to remember and is used to make people notice something
dictionaryExamples: an advertising slogan
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our slogan is "BE CREATIVE." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: a surface or piece of land that is high at one end and low at the other
dictionaryExamples: There's a steep slope to climb before we're at the top.
a mountain/ski slope
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During [the] daytime, we all went up to the slopes for skiing. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a long, narrow hole that you put something into, especially money
dictionaryExamples: Put the coin in the slot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Instead of inserting a coin, you put your card in a slot and then dial the number. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a period of time that you allow for something in a plan
dictionaryExamples: The TV program is being moved to a later slot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Customers will also be able to choose the date and even the time slot for the delivery. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: doing, moving or happening without much speed
dictionaryExamples: a slow runner/driver/reader
She's a very slow eater.
We're making slow but steady progress with the decorating.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know about the concert [and] I like slow music. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: not exciting
dictionaryExamples: I find his films very slow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The begin[n]ing of the movie is slow, but the last hour is incredible. Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: be slow to do sth; be slow in doing sth

sense.def: to take a long time to do something
dictionaryExamples: The government has been slow to react to the problem.
The ambulance was very slow in coming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But in the Third World, where birth rates are explosive, the governments, and even more the people, are slow to grasp the problem and act on it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to become slower or to make something become slower
dictionaryExamples: Traffic slows to a crawl  during rush hour.
The pilot was asked to slow his approach to the runway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having said that, I do agree that it is unavoidable to have increasing prices on [oil], in an attempt to slow the rate of depletion of this resource that is not unlimited. (2250618; International English Language Testing System; Sri Lanka; C2 MASTERY; 2007; Tamil; 8

sense.def: to become slower, or to make someone or something become slower
dictionaryExamples: Slow down, you two, you're walking too fast!
If I run with Christina she tends to slow me down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly a car slowed down not far from him. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If someone slows down, they become less active.
dictionaryExamples: The doctor told me I should slow down and not work so hard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I just can't understand why you don't slow down a bit. Have a bit [of] fun, enjoy life! First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: at a slow speed
dictionaryExamples: Could you please speak more slowly?
He walked slowly across the room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I rang in the bell, my friend slowly opened the door. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: little in size or amount
dictionaryExamples: They live in a small apartment near Times Square.
We teach the children in small groups.
a small dog/house/car
I'd rather live in a small town than a big city.
Would you like a large or small cola with your burger?
That jacket's too small for you.
Only a small number of applicants are successful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a small vill[a]ge where my grandad live[s]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: A small child is very young.
dictionaryExamples: Looking after small children can be very tiring.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I live wit[h] my wife and my small daughter who [is] 2 years old. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: not important or serious
dictionaryExamples: a small mistake
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I'm OK, but I have a small problem! I forgot my books there yesterday, and tomorrow I'll have a test, and I really need to study.  
 Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: intelligent
dictionaryExamples: Ginny is a very smart kid.
Why don't you fix it if you're so smart?
He's smart enough to know he can't run the business without help.
Quitting that job was a smart move.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is [a] very kind, smart, and good person, besides, [he] is a good son. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: having a clean, tidy and stylish appearance
dictionaryExamples: a smart suit/jacket/uniform
She wore a smart silk blouse and pinstriped pants.
He is quite a smart dresser.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the ceremony all the guests are dressed in smart clothes, but don't buy a new suit because with the black one you have, it will be OK. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: using computers or information stored in electronic form
dictionaryExamples: a smart phone
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some telephones are only operated by "smart cards." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to break into a lot of pieces with a loud noise, or to make something break into a lot of pieces with a loud noise
dictionaryExamples: Some kids smashed her window.
She dropped her cup and it smashed to pieces on the stone floor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then the two men tried to smash the door [down]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to make a happy or friendly expression in which the corners of your mouth curve up
dictionaryExamples: He smiled and shook my hand.
When he smiled at me I knew everything was all right.
I couldn't help smiling when I thought of how pleased she was going to be.
He smiled politely as Mary apologized for being late.
He smiled to himself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But he began to smile and explained what [had] happen[e]d to him. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a happy or friendly expression in which the corners of your mouth curve up
dictionaryExamples: Amy had a big smile on her face.
She has a nice smile.
He gave me a smile.
It's nice to be able to bring a smile to people's faces.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has short dark brown hair, green eyes and [a] wonderful smile. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: air pollution in a city that is a mixture of smoke, gases, and chemicals
dictionaryExamples: Smog hung over the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This will reduce smog and pollution, which has become an increasing problem for Castlecross. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to breathe smoke into your mouth from a cigarette
dictionaryExamples: Please don't smoke in the classroom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like the pause between lesson[s]. We go outside [to] smoke and fool about. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: the gray or black gas that is produced when something burns
dictionaryExamples: cigarette smoke
a tiny smoke-filled waiting room
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The boys I met were smoking a lot!! I hate smoke! Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: someone who smokes tobacco regularly
dictionaryExamples: a cigarette/pipe smoker
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can go for a walk, (which is good for you), eat well-balanced food and try not to smoke (if you are a heavy smoker). First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: when someone smokes a cigarette or regularly smokes cigarettes
dictionaryExamples: Smoking is not permitted in the theater.
He wants to give up/stop smoking.
No smoking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like too much smoking in the college. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: filled with smoke or giving off a lot of smoke
dictionaryExamples: a smoky bar/room
a smoky fire
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was dark, smoky, scruffy and overcrowded! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: having a regular surface that has no holes or lumps in it
dictionaryExamples: soft, smooth skin
a smooth wooden table
Mix together the butter and sugar until smooth.
The road ahead was flat and smooth.
This cream will help to keep your skin smooth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sand is so smooth and the water is so clean! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: happening without problems or difficulties
dictionaryExamples: Her job is to help students make a smooth transition from high school to college.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that this is what we need to work with; finding smooth, "tailor-made" solutions. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: happening without any sudden movements or changes
dictionaryExamples: The plane made a smooth landing.

sense.def: without any problems or difficulties
dictionaryExamples: Everything was going smoothly before Darren arrived.
All the machinery was running smoothly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope everything goes smoothly. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: without any sudden movements or changes
dictionaryExamples: The car accelerated smoothly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: John felt strange unity with his car; the car reacted very smoothly and instantly to every movement he made. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to take something into or out of a place in an illegal or secret way
dictionaryExamples: He was arrested for smuggling cocaine into Britain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Somehow they manage to get themselves trapped in a vicious circle of crime, under the influence of a magician who forces them to smuggle jewels for him. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a small amount of food that is eaten between meals, or a very small meal
dictionaryExamples: I had a big lunch, so I'll only need a snack for dinner.
Fresh or dried fruit makes an good snack.
Many snack foods are high in salt, sugar and fat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I prefer to see [the movie] on Friday and after it we can have a snack, OK? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a long, thin creature with no legs that slides along the ground
dictionaryExamples: He's terrified of being bitten by a snake.
a snake bite
snake venom
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You would see a panda that was sent from China recently and a snake with two heads as well. Key English Test; A2; Burmese

sense.def: if something long and thin snaps, it breaks making a short, loud sound, and if you snap it, you break it making a short, loud sound.
dictionaryExamples: The twigs snapped as we walked on them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In January of this year, her right Achilles tendon snapped during a competition and it was uncertain whether she would be able to ski, let alone compete again. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to suddenly move to a particular position making a short, loud noise, or to make something do this
dictionaryExamples: The suitcase snapped open and everything fell out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, it was one of those automatic locks, that snap shut as soon as you close the doors, and, after a while he apparently found out that he was trapped inside the cupboard and couldn't get out. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to say something suddenly in an angry way
dictionaryExamples: I was snapping at the children because I was tired.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your job can be stressful enough without somebody snapping at you all the time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to suddenly be unable to control a strong feeling, especially anger
dictionaryExamples: She asked me to do the work again and I just snapped.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Something snapped in her, she told herself, "Let's quit my boring job, and make a fresh start!!" Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to take something or someone quickly and suddenly
dictionaryExamples: Bill snatched the telephone from my hand.
The child was snatched from his bed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He snatched the controls out of her hands and threw them on the floor. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: a type of light comfortable shoe that is suitable for sports activities
dictionaryExamples: a pair of sneakers
He wore jeans, a gray golf shirt, and white sneakers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mike, I have left my sneakers in your room. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: When you sneeze, air and often small drops of liquid suddenly come out of your nose and mouth in a way you cannot control.
dictionaryExamples: Cats make him sneeze - I think he's allergic to them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were sneezing all the time and had a fever. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to breathe air in through your nose in a way that makes a noise
dictionaryExamples: You were sniffing a lot - it sounds like you have a cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly we heard something sniffing. Something was approaching us coming from the darkness. It was a bear.

sense.def: to breathe air in through your nose in order to smell something
dictionaryExamples: He sniffed his socks to see if they needed to be washed.
Dogs love sniffing each other.
Jack crushed the fresh herbs between his fingers and sniffed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That puppy was the cutest thing: tiny body, with floppy ears, a curious wet nose that wanted to sniff everything on its way, and huge cheerful eyes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: someone who thinks they are better than other people because they are in a higher social position
dictionaryExamples: My aunt is such a snob!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being stylish, whether it concerns cornflakes or shoes, to [the] degree of not having your own opinion, seems to be a pattern of behavior typical of a teenager or a total snob. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: like a snob
dictionaryExamples: a snobbish attitude
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mary's friends seemed to be snobbish and artificial in their manners to Michael. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to breathe in a very noisy way while you are sleeping
dictionaryExamples: He was snoring so much it kept me awake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know, we can live together as long as you don't snore like you did last time. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: soft white pieces of frozen water that fall from the sky when the weather is cold
dictionaryExamples: Outside the snow began to fall.
Let's go and play in the snow!
A blanket of snow lay on the ground.
Her hair was jet-black, her lips ruby-red and her skin as white as snow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like England bec[a]use I like we[a]ther like snow. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Cantonese

sense.def: If it snows, snow falls from the sky.
dictionaryExamples: It's snowing.
It's starting to snow.
It had snowed overnight and a thick white layer covered the ground.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is raining and snowing all the time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to be unable to leave a place because there is too much snow
dictionaryExamples: We were snowed in for two days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After being snowed in the following morning, we headed off to Las Vegas. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to have too much work
dictionaryExamples: I'm snowed under at school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During late winter evenings when you are snowed under at work, this positive change is what keeps you going. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a large board that you stand on to move over snow
dictionaryExamples: I rented a snowboard for the day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, I missed my snowboard, so the surfboard, the waves, the sand and the sun were filling this empty place in me. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a sport in which you stand on a large board and move over snow
dictionaryExamples: I love snowboarding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I recommend you to go to St Moritz, [w]here you can do a lot of int[e]resting things like snowboarding, walking and so on. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: used to emphasize the quantity, quality or amount of something
dictionaryExamples: The house is so beautiful.
Don't be so stupid!
I didn't know she had so many children!
Thank you so much for all your help.
I've never seen so many people in one place before!
I'm so tired (that) I could sleep in this chair!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you so much for [your] help! Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to refer to something that has just been mentioned, especially to give a short answer to a question
dictionaryExamples: "I hope they'll get here on time." "I hope so too."
"Do you think he's upset?" "I don't think so."
James is coming tonight, or so he said.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've just watched the Rugby World Cup final with my dad. Did you watch it? I hope so, because it was just fantastic. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used after a list of things to show that you could have added other similar things
dictionaryExamples: She plays a lot of tennis and squash and so on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like watching television, playing [on] the computer, reading book[s] and so on. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

blocks.phrase: so did we/so have I/so is mine, etc.

sense.def: used to say that someone else also does something or that the same thing is true about someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: "We saw the new Star Trek movie last night." "Oh, so did we."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My eyes went watery and so did hers but then we laughed at each other. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: until now
dictionaryExamples: So far only seven people have entered the race.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So far I like it here very much. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: approximately
dictionaryExamples: "How many people were at the party?" "Fifty or so, I guess."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well you told me about your situation and after thinking a lot, I thought you should go with them for a week or so, and then just take a plane and come to Barcelona to visit me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: if this is the case
dictionaryExamples: It might rain this afternoon. If so, we'll have to have the party indoors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you are interested, and if so, I'll see you next summer. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: in order to
dictionaryExamples: I always keep fruit in the fridge so as to keep insects off it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be interested in having skiing lessons too so as to improve my level w[h]ich I consider is not very high. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: if you do this, or if this is done
dictionaryExamples: They want to build a completely new school, but to do so would cost far too much.
I would strongly advise you against taking out a loan of this size. To do so would be a great risk to your business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is generally believed that if [a] better education is provided, children are better prepared for adult life. To do so, money is essential. International English Language Testing System; C1; Japanese

sense.def: used to emphasize that something surprising is true despite what you have just said
dictionaryExamples: Car prices have gone down a lot, but even so, we couldn't afford to buy one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure many of [these things] happened due to bad luck, but even so, there are some arrangements that, I bel[ie]ve, can easily be improved. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

blocks.phrase: so as not to do sth

sense.def: used for saying what the purpose of an action is
dictionaryExamples: He went in very quietly so as not to wake the baby.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, I think we should plan some other kind of activities in case of bad weather and we should have more than one bus with us so as not to waste time in case it breaks down. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that something has not been useful or successful
dictionaryExamples: "The computer crashed again." "So much for modern technology."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, so much for my virtues since I can't keep my big mouth shut. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say that there are limits to something
dictionaryExamples: There's only so much help you can give someone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The effects of a longer life span have many side ef[f]ects such as an increase in the world's population and, since there is only so much food, m[any] more people are st[ar]ving to death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that you were right and that someone should have believed you
dictionaryExamples: He's lazy?  I told you so, didn't I?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: See, I told you so", Azman said with a grin. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

blocks.phrase: every once in a while / every so often

sense.def: sometimes, but not often
dictionaryExamples: You meet some really interesting people every once in a while.
He went into town every so often to buy supplies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And likewise, common sense tells us it doesn't matter that oranges from Spain contain 0.01% more vitamin C than those from Florid[a], as long as we eat them every once in a while. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: used to say that something has gone well until now
dictionaryExamples: It's the first time I've done any decorating, but so far, so good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So far, so good, only no one told us they held this point of view before the actual christening took place. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to explain that the words you are using do not have their usual meaning
dictionaryExamples: I do have a blog, so yes, I am a writer, so to speak.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maintaining a good working relationship with your colleagues is one of the critical factors in keeping the company you work for afloat, so to speak. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: used to say that something is the reason why something else happens
dictionaryExamples: I was tired so I went to bed.
Greg had some money so he bought a bike.
My knee started hurting so I stopped running.
I was lost so I bought a street map.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to change my school, so I have to sell all my books. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: used at the beginning of a sentence to connect it with something that was said or happened previously
dictionaryExamples: So, there I was standing at the edge of the road . . .
So, just to finish what I was saying earlier . . .
So, who do you think is going to win the election?
So, what time do you want to leave?
So that's the plan.
So we leave on the Thursday and get back the next Tuesday, is that right?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I remember you said that you want to help me. So, can you buy the items for me and then I['ll] pay you? Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: in order to make something happen or be possible
dictionaryExamples: He put his glasses on so that he could see the television better.
I deliberately didn't have lunch so (that) I would be hungry tonight.
Leave the keys out so (that) I remember to take them with me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Could you please give me some extra exercises so that I can cover the work I missed? Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If you soak something, or let it soak, you put it in a liquid for a period of time.
dictionaryExamples: Soak the bread in the milk.
He left the pan in the sink to soak.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was just enjoying [the] warm sand, soaking my feet in cold water, when his shadow obscured the sun.  First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: If liquid soaks somewhere or soaks something, it makes something very wet.
dictionaryExamples: The rain soaked my clothes.
The ink soaked through the paper onto the table.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Oh Chris just look at your new suit - its all soaked through." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrasalVerb: soak up sth or soak sth up

sense.def: to enjoy the effects of an experience
dictionaryExamples: We arrived early at the festival to soak up the atmosphere.
I spent two weeks in Greece soaking up the sun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like a lazy rest, so I took advantage of [the] sunny weather and sandy beach and soaked up the sun all day long. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: completely wet
dictionaryExamples: My shirt was soaked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now it is a pleasure to drive in a warm and dry car, looking at the soaked bicycle riders as you quickly drive by them. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: completely wet
dictionaryExamples: You're soaking - why didn't you take an umbrella?
The dog was soaking wet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we arrived at the camp, and we were soaking wet. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a substance that you use for washing
dictionaryExamples: a bar of soap
liquid soap
soap and water
a soap dish
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think the soap and the shampoo are in the bathroom. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a series of television or radio programs that continues over a long period and is about the lives of a group of characters
dictionaryExamples: I watch all the soaps.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when I'm watching TV, I prefer soaps. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a series of television or radio programs that continues over a long period and is about the lives of a group of characters
dictionaryExamples: She enjoys watching soap operas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you like soap operas? Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: to increase to a high level very quickly
dictionaryExamples: House prices have soared.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not only has the interest from the public soared, but the competitions have also become commercially exploited and are today an integral part of our modern "brand and lifestyle" society. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to move quickly and smoothly in the sky, or to move quickly up into the sky
dictionaryExamples: The birds were soaring high above.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Through the windows, a colorful bird could be seen, soaring, swooping, hovering, before disappearing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: increasing very quickly
dictionaryExamples: soaring property prices
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is due to soaring house prices, especially in urban areas. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to cry in a noisy way
dictionaryExamples: The child sobbed through the first day of school but played there happily by the end of the first week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly one of our group member[s] started to sob. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: Someone who is sober is not drunk.
dictionaryExamples: She remained sober all evening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Emma's father was a very wealthy man who had millions in the bank but he was also a violent drunk who was rarely sober. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: Someone who is sober is serious and thinks a lot.
dictionaryExamples: He was in a sober mood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We rarely see each other and our care[free]ness and "joie de vivre" gave way to a more sober at[t]itude towards life, we all have our jobs and our own destiny to take care of. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: Clothes or colors that are sober are plain and not bright.
dictionaryExamples: a sober, gray dress
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Peter wore a blue suit and a sober tie. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to show that this is an informal, little known, or new name that something or someone is know as
dictionaryExamples: Married taxpayers are hit hard by the so-called marriage penalty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are lots of so-called workaholics who suffer from heart-attacks, high-blood-pressure or general nervousness. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used to show that you think a word that is used to describe someone or something is wrong
dictionaryExamples: These so-called experts don’t know anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This so-called "Perfect Evening" was so disappointing, as well as discouraging [us from] coming to your Circle Theatre again. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a game in which two teams of players kick a round ball and try to score goals
dictionaryExamples: a soccer player/team/club/shirt
He plays soccer for a local team.
Are you coming to the soccer match?
I'm a big soccer fan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have a lot of hobbies, like playing soccer, playing computer [games], playing basketball and reading books. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: Someone who is sociable enjoys being with people and meeting new people.
dictionaryExamples: Rob's very sociable - he likes his parties.
I had a headache and I wasn't feeling very sociable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are all friendly, cool, outgoing, [and] sociable. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: relating to the things you do with other people for enjoyment when you are not working
dictionaryExamples: I had an active social life when I in college.
The language school organizes social events for the students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I recommend [this] because there [is] more social life, nightlife, more fun and face[-to-face] experiences. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: relating to society and the way people live
dictionaryExamples: social services
social issues/justice/problems
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are ecological, technical, and social problems. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a political system in which the government owns important businesses and industries, and which allows the people to share the money and opportunities equally
dictionaryExamples: He is an opponent of socialism.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In his opinion, that would be a fatal mistake (his latest book is "The fatal arrogance: the error of socialism"). Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: someone who supports socialism
dictionaryExamples: My parents are socialists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was the first time in history that socialists were a majority in the government. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to spend time enjoying yourself with other people
dictionaryExamples: I don't usually socialize with my colleagues.
I hope Alex is actually doing some work while in college - he seems to spend all his time socializing!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having a [chance] to relax and to socialize with other students after attending classes would be hig[h]ly appreciated. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: using Web sites to meet people and talk to them
dictionaryExamples: He spends a lot of time on social networking sites.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They tend to subscribe [to] different social-networking websites to communicate with people from all around the world and discuss different issues. International English Language Testing System; B2; Arabic

sense.def: a large group of people who live in the same country or area and have the same laws, traditions, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a civilized/multicultural society
Societies change over the course of time.
There's a danger that we will end up blaming innocent children for society's problems.
We must also consider the needs of the younger/older members of society.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: You know that we live in a multiracial society and it is very important to respect each other. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: an organization for people who have the same interests or aims
dictionaryExamples: an amateur dramatic society
Zoological societies protect and study wild animals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I read an article about the "Riding Society of Warlingham" in the local newspaper and I was fascinated by its ideas. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a piece of clothing that you wear on your foot inside your shoe
dictionaryExamples: a pair of socks
wool/cotton socks
ankle/knee socks
Put on your shoes and socks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got a watch, gloves, socks and a pair of shoes. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a long, comfortable seat that is large enough for two or  more people
dictionaryExamples: We bought a new leather sofa.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's under the sofa or maybe in the bathroom. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: not hard or firm
dictionaryExamples: a soft pillow
soft cheese
I like chocolates with soft centers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a small pillow. Oh, it's so soft and I never sleep without it. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: smooth and pleasant to touch
dictionaryExamples: soft skin/hair
soft leather
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it, because it has got big eyes and very soft fur. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: not forceful, loud or easily noticed
dictionaryExamples: a soft voice/sound/music
She likes soft pastel colors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They keep playing soft music to entertain the customers. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hindi

blocks.phrase: have a soft spot for sb/sth

sense.def: to like someone or something a lot
dictionaryExamples: I've always had a soft spot for her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would definitely like to return there because I really enjoy museums and as I have always had a soft spot for art, I can say that, that Foundation is my cup of tea. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a cold, sweet drink that does not have alcohol in it
dictionaryExamples: Are there any soft drinks for the children?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can make some sandwiches or sell some soft drinks [to] help with the concert. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: in a quiet or gentle way
dictionaryExamples: She spoke so softly it was hard to hear her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before go[ing] to bed, they kissed me softly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: the quality of being soft
dictionaryExamples: Just feel the softness of the baby's skin!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The room has only a few lamps and the furniture is worn down and has lost its softness. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: programs that you use to make a computer do different things
dictionaryExamples: He's written a piece of software which calculates your tax returns for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Hla, I've left my computer software book at your home. Key English Test; A2; Burmese

sense.def: the top layer of earth that plants grow in
dictionaryExamples: light/heavy/sandy soil
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many couples with young children and old people prefer fresh grass and natural soil to concrete and cement in a city. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: relating to, or involving the sun
dictionaryExamples: solar energy
a solar cell/panel
solar heating
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It will save a lot of electricity as solar energy is used. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a member of an army
dictionaryExamples: French/Cuban/Turkish/Chinese/American soldiers
Soldiers were patrolling the streets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My grandfather beg[a]n to talk: it happened when I was young. I used to be a soldier, part of the quick respon[se] forces. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: only or not shared with anyone else
dictionaryExamples: My sole purpose is to make the information more widely available.
The sole survivor of the accident was found in the water after six hours.
She has sole responsibility for the project.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Creating a library for this sole purpose would be ideal for our school's language department. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: only and not involving anyone or anything else
dictionaryExamples: I bought it solely for that purpose.
It seems he's not solely to blame for the accident.
The product's success cannot be explained solely by the popularity of the ads.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The interviewe[e] doesn't see the people answering the questions and has to decide solely from the answers given on whom to go out with. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: hard and firm, without holes or spaces
dictionaryExamples: solid ground/rock
a solid object
a solid structure
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having solid ground beneath her feet again she sighed with relief for having survived this adventure. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: strong and not easily broken or damaged
dictionaryExamples: solid furniture
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [If] you have an accident, you have less chance [of] get[ting] hurt if you are sitting in [a] big, solid vehicle. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: not a liquid or a gas
dictionaryExamples: Liquid and solid waste is collected in the tank.
Freeze the mixture for about 3 hours or so until solid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of the total amount of electrical power produced in the world, solid fuel is by far the most important contributor (44%). International English Language Testing System; C1; Swedish

sense.def: gold/silver/wood, etc. with nothing added
dictionaryExamples: a solid silver bracelet
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dark marble is easy to keep clean and the solid brass handles look luxur[ious]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: Solid information, proof, etc. is based on facts and you are certain that it is correct.
dictionaryExamples: This provided solid evidence that he committed the crime.
The drama course gives students a solid grounding in the basic techniques of acting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It may help you, because you have a solid background and plenty of theoretical information which you could use in practi[c]e. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: agreement and support between people in a group who have similar aims or beliefs
dictionaryExamples: Several professors joined the march to show solidarity with their students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the people were dancing, singing, laughing and enjoying their time in the company of these beautiful children from poor African streets, with a great sense of solidarity. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: A solitary person or thing is the only person or thing in a place.
dictionaryExamples: a solitary figure/runner
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What is more, a star should remain with the people despite her or his celebrity, and bear in mind the old and perhaps worn-out, but none the less true comparison: a general without a faithful army is just a solitary soldier amid the field. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: A solitary activity is done alone.
dictionaryExamples: solitary walks
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a month-long solitary journey through India. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: being alone
dictionaryExamples: He went upstairs to read the letter in solitude.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You'll find true solitude and a place for serious contemplation of life's big questions. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: done alone by one person only
dictionaryExamples: a solo performance/flight
to sail/fly solo
He used to play with a group but now he has gone solo/has a solo career.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They all started with a solo car[e]er. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a piece of music for one person or one instrument
dictionaryExamples: a trumpet solo
Parker's solo on "A Night in Tunisia" was so amazing that the pianist backing him simply stopped playing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were amazing, the drummer was so fast - when he was playing the drum solo, I couldn't even see his hands and his drum sticks. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the answer to a problem
dictionaryExamples: There's no easy solution to this problem.
She just seems so unhappy and I don't know what the solution is.
You'll find the solution to the puzzle on the back page.
They help you talk through your problems but they don't give you any solutions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was pleased with the solution. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to find the answer to something
dictionaryExamples: to solve a problem
to solve a mystery/puzzle
Just calm down - shouting won't solve anything!
This strategy could cause more problems than it solves.
Police are still no nearer to solving the crime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will help me to solve this problem, won't you? Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: used to refer to an amount of something without saying exactly how much or how many
dictionaryExamples: There's some cake in the kitchen if you'd like it.
Here's some news you might be interested in.
Some stories he wrote were made into movies.
Could you give me some idea of when the building work will finish?
I've got to do some more work before I can go out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think if you make some pasta with garlic and onion sauce, [that] will be great. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a large amount or number of something
dictionaryExamples: It'll be some time before we meet again.
It was some years later when they next met.
We discussed the problem at some length.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's some years ago now, sixteen years I think. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: used to refer to a particular person or thing without stating exactly which one
dictionaryExamples: Some lucky person will win more than $1,000,000!
Some jerk locked the door.
There must be some way you can relieve the pain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe you hate the memory of these boring literature classes at school, but I'm sure each of you is interested in some subject or other. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to refer to an amount of something without saying exactly how much or how many
dictionaryExamples: I can't eat all this chocolate, would you like some?
If you need more paper then just take some.
"Would you like to have dinner with us?" "No thanks, I've already had some."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you don't have [any old clothes], I will lend you some. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to refer to part of a larger amount or number of something and not all of it
dictionaryExamples: In some cases it's possible to fix the problem right away.
Some of you here have already met Imran.
Have some of this lemonade - it's very good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please bring some of [your] music with you. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: someone
dictionaryExamples: Can somebody feed the cats?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left my cell[ph]one [in your house] and it is important because I need to call somebody now. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: in a way or by some means which is not known or not stated
dictionaryExamples: It won't be easy, but we'll get across the river somehow.
Somehow or other, we'll get the money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't know exactly what happened but somehow I managed not to fall in [the lake]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: for a reason which is not clear
dictionaryExamples: I know what we're doing is legal, but somehow it doesn't feel right.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I did not know who was talking to me but somehow I knew that it must be an urgent matter. Why else [w]ould a stranger wake me in the middle of the night? First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used to refer to a single person when you do not know who they are or when it is not important who they are
dictionaryExamples: There's someone outside the house.
Someone must have seen what happened.
Eventually someone in the audience spoke.
You'll have to ask someone else.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's very important you send it back to me because I have to phone someone right now. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to refer to a place when you do not know exactly where it is or when it is not important exactly where it is
dictionaryExamples: The only time I’ve been to Florida I was on the way someplace else.
I'd like to go someplace quiet for vacation this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tourists also need someplace to stay. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: used to refer to a thing when you do not know what it is or when it is not important what it is
dictionaryExamples: There's something in my shoe.
Can I read you something else?
You should take something for that cold.
We thought there must be something wrong because we hadn't heard from you.
Something's happened to upset him but we don't know what it is.
Is there something you'd like to say?
Don't just stand there, do something.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I need something, I go shop[p]ing. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: used to show that what you have just said is only an example or you are not certain about it
dictionaryExamples: Why don't you go to a movie or something?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We sho[u]ld [go to] a café after, and then we can go [to] dinner or something like that. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: be/have something to do with sth/sb

sense.def: to be related to something or a cause of something but not in a way which you know about or understand
dictionaryExamples: It might have something to do with the way it's made.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, it has something to do with politics, but as you know, I don't understand a word of it because I don't care about it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: to be a thing which is important, special, or useful
dictionaryExamples: The President visiting our hotel - that would really be something.
It's not much but it's something.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My God I thought this woman sure was something. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: similar to or approximately
dictionaryExamples: He paid something like $18,000 for his car.
The town’s Algonquian name means something like "water over a white bottom."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To their minds it is still something like an obligation and this may be attributed to the pressure their parents and teachers used to put on them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to describe a person or thing in a way which is partly true but not completely or exactly
dictionaryExamples: It came as something of a surprise.
He has a reputation as something of a troublemaker.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, while he had an intense social life, I used to be something of a hermit. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: on some occasions but not always or often
dictionaryExamples: Sometimes we take food with us and sometimes we buy food when we're there.
Sometimes it's best not to say anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We sometimes have classes in [the] library [or the] computer room. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: slightly
dictionaryExamples: The resort has changed somewhat over the last few years.
She's somewhat more confident than she used to be.
We were somewhat tired after our long walk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We found the written article to be somewhat inaccurate, since several facts were mistaken and others were blown out of proportion. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to refer to a place when you do not know exactly where it is or when it is not important exactly where it is
dictionaryExamples: The last I heard, he was living somewhere in Florida.
You must have put their letter somewhere!
I'm looking for somewhere to eat/stay.
Can we go somewhere else to talk - it's very noisy here.
Wouldn't you like to go to Disneyland or somewhere?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I think we should go somewhere else to have a drink after the film. Key English Test; A2; Vietnamese

sense.def: approximately
dictionaryExamples: The temperature will be somewhere around 90° again today.
It will take us somewhere between three and four hours to get to Madrid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The gathering will take place somewhere betwe[e]n the first and second week of the month, so you can come somewhere around then. First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian

sense.def: your male child
dictionaryExamples: This is our son Raja.
We have two sons and three daughters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love my son and my girlfriend. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: a usually short piece of music with words which are sung
dictionaryExamples: to sing/perform a song
a love/folk/pop/country song
We bought a CD of Cole Porter songs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We sang a song at the party. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: your daughter's husband
dictionaryExamples: My son-in-law helped me repair the fence.

sense.def: making you feel calm or in less pain
dictionaryExamples: We listened to some soothing music.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The appropriate "lounge" music would only add to the soothing and relaxing effect that this scenery would have on us and would probably go unnoticed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: well-educated and having experience of the world or knowledge of culture
dictionaryExamples: She was smart and sophisticated.
Sophisticated readers understood the book’s hidden meaning.
He was European and to the students seemed very sophisticated.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her conversation was very sophisticated. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: A sophisticated machine or system is complicated and advanced or made with great skill.
dictionaryExamples: I think a more sophisticated approach is needed to solve this problem.
sophisticated equipment/technology/software
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These days we can use [a] computer, television [or other] sophisticated equipment. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: painful, especially when touched
dictionaryExamples: I've got a sore throat.
My feet are sore from all that walking.
All the dust made my eyes sore.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll miss the class, because I've got a sore throat. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a subject that causes disagreement or makes people angry when it is discussed
dictionaryExamples: Money is a sore point with him at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although it is not a new phenomenon, it is more common - and a sore point - in our Society that, old people live alone and without any help. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when someone feels very sad
dictionaryExamples: He expressed his sorrow at the news.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Perhaps being smart and over-achieving may sound like an offer that is too tempting to turn down, but it is as much of a burden as it is a blessing. These qualities bring forth the worst in one's peers, leading to loneliness and sorrow. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: used to apologize for something you have done
dictionaryExamples: Oh, I'm sorry - I didn't see you there.
Tom, I'm really/so sorry about last night - it was all my fault.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi! Yes, of course I can go for dinner tomorrow, but I [will be] a little late, sorry about that. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to show sympathy or sadness for a person or situation
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry (that) you had such a difficult journey.
We were both sorry to hear you've been ill again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was sorry that you couldn't come to my birthday party. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: to feel sympathy for someone because they are in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: I feel so sorry for the kids - it must be really hard for them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, I feel sorry for her and I wonder: what would I do if I were her? Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: used to show politeness when refusing something or disagreeing
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry but I think you've made a mistake.
I'm sorry, I don't agree.
I'm sorry, but I just don't think it's a good idea.
Sorry, you can't go in there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sorry but I can't tell you the starting date right now, [although] I think it's around [the] 15th of July. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: a type of something
dictionaryExamples: We both like the same sort of music.
I'm going to have a salad of some sort.
What sort of shoes will I need?
This sort of camera is very expensive.
Plants of this sort need lots of sun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like rap and techno but I don't know if everybody love[s] this sort of music! Key English Test; A2; Others

sense.def: many different types of something
dictionaryExamples: They had all sorts of jewelry for sale.
We saw all sorts  of animals in the park.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like all sorts of music but I prefer urban music! Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: used to show that what you have just said is only an example from a larger group of things
dictionaryExamples: They sell souvenirs, postcards, that sort of thing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also enjoy using new clothes for the first time, but I prefer buying other stuff like electronic devices or that sort of thing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to describe something approximately
dictionaryExamples: It's a sort of pale orange color.
They were sort of waving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I sort of felt like I had done my part to make the concert a suc[c]ess. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to arrange things into different groups or types or into an order
dictionaryExamples: Paper, plastic and cans are sorted for recycling.
I'm going to sort these books into ones to keep and ones to give away.
You can use the computer to sort the newspaper articles alphabetically, by date, or by subject.

blocks.phrasalVerb: sort out sth or sort sth out

sense.def: to successfully deal with something, such as a problem or difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: Did you get your schedule sorted out yet?
There are a few things I need to sort out at work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reason why I can't do that late in the evening is that they need the car themselves then, to sort out some last things before the wedding. First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian

sense.def: to organize or arrange things that  are not neat
dictionaryExamples: I need to  sort out my closet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To keep myself busy I started to sort out the files on my desk. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: popular music with a strong beat that expresses deep feelings, originally performed by African-Americans
dictionaryExamples: Their records are a mixture of soul and jazz.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really like listen[ing] to Hip Hop, R 'n' B, soul and love songs. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: the part of a person that is not their body and which some people believe continues to exist after they die
dictionaryExamples: She suffered greatly while she was alive, so let us hope her soul is now at peace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you meet her you can understand her spirit in writing is coming from her soul. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a person
dictionaryExamples: I didn't see a soul when I went out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unlike a year ago, she did not tell a soul. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: something that you hear or that can be heard
dictionaryExamples: They could hear the sound of a bell tolling in the distance.
She stood completely still, not making a sound.
Sound can travel over very large distances in water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can help with the decoration, the lights and the sound. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: how something seems to be, from what you have been told or heard
dictionaryExamples: I like the sound of the beef in red wine sauce.
He's really enjoying college, by the sound of it.

sense.def: completely safe and without injury or damage
dictionaryExamples: After three days lost in the mountains, all the climbers arrived home safe and sound.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, by the time you read this letter I'll probably be safe and sound in Liverpool. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to seem good, interesting, strange, etc. from what is said or written
dictionaryExamples: Your job sounds really interesting.
I know it sounds silly, but I'll miss him when he's gone.
You're going skiing with three friends? That sounds like fun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How about painting the floor with white paint and the walls wit[h] black paint?  I think it sounds fun. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to seem like something, from what you have heard or read
dictionaryExamples: That sounds like a really good idea.
It sounds like you've got a sore throat.
It sounds as if they had a good holiday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It sounds like your new trousers are very nice. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to seem angry, happy, rude, etc. when you speak
dictionaryExamples: He sounded very depressed when we spoke on the telephone yesterday.
At the press conference, he sounded at his most relaxed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He sounded so excited! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the music used in a movie or a television program
dictionaryExamples: The film's soundtrack includes music by Bob Marley.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first time I heard it was in a movie, named "8 Mile." This song was the soundtrack of that movie. First Certificate in English; B2; Georgian

sense.def: a usually hot, liquid food made from vegetables and sometimes meat or fish cooked in water
dictionaryExamples: chicken/tomato/vegetable soup
Would you like a bowl of soup?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to eat soup, eggs, meat and salad. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: having a sharp, sometimes unpleasant, taste or smell, like a lemon, and not sweet
dictionaryExamples: sour cream
sweet and sour sauce
These plums are a bit sour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it is possible because your pork-chop was as tough as old boots and the salad dressing was sour! First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: where something comes from
dictionaryExamples: a source of heat/energy/light
Oranges are a good source of vitamin C.
Experts are trying to track down the source of the contamination in the water supply.
We walked up the river to its source in the hills.
Money is often a source of tension and disagreements in young married couples.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fish is a great source of vitamins. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who gives information to the police, newspapers, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The story came from a source within the government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the next report, I advise you to get the correct information from the source. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: the direction that is toward the part of the earth below the equator, opposite to north, or the part of an area or country that is in this direction
dictionaryExamples: The points of the compass are north, south, east and west.
The best beaches are on the south of the island.
Canberra is/lies to the south of Sydney.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am in Toulon, in the south of France.  Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: the part of an area that is further toward the south than the rest
dictionaryExamples: We live in the south of the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best place in Poland to spend [a] holiday is the south of the country. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: in or forming the south part of something
dictionaryExamples: the south side of Chicago
the South China Sea
These plants grow well on a south-facing wall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went to a Safari Park near Birmingham, [and to] Cambridge, London, and the south part of England. Key English Test; A2; Korean

sense.def: towards the south
dictionaryExamples: The Mississippi river flows south.
They drove south toward the coast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a large window facing south so that it's bright and warm. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: the direction that is between south and east, or the southeast part of a country
dictionaryExamples: We live in the southeast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The south and the southeast are the [backbone] of [the] Brazilian economy so there are lots of malls, department stores and very [good] nightlife. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: in the southeast, or facing toward the southeast
dictionaryExamples: She lives on the southeast side of town.

sense.def: in or from the south part of an area
dictionaryExamples: a southern route
the Southern Hemisphere
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Later we went to the "Waldsee", in the southern part of Freiburg. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the direction that is between south and west, or the southwest part of a country
dictionaryExamples: The wind was coming from the southwest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I remember the day we went to Sarlat, a lovely town in the southwest of France. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in the southwest, or facing toward the southwest
dictionaryExamples: The district is in the southwest corner of the state.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I live in [a] village in [the] southwest part of Poland. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: something which you buy or keep to remember a special event or holiday
dictionaryExamples: I kept the ticket as a souvenir of my trip.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a well-known place near the hotel were you can buy souvenirs and chocolates. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to put seeds into the ground
dictionaryExamples: to sow seeds/crops
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Farmers had to plo[w], sow and harvest cotton on their own, using their labor and hands. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: a substance made from beans and used to make many foods
dictionaryExamples: This milk is made from soy.

sense.def: an empty area which is available to be used
dictionaryExamples: Is there any space for my clothes in that closet?
I've got to make (some) space for Mark's things.
When the roads are wet, you've got to leave plenty of space between you and the car in front.
We found a parking space close to the museum.
The blank space at the end of the form is for your name.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to s[ell] my stereo because in my room there isn't space for it. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the area outside the earth's atmosphere, where the planets and the stars are
dictionaryExamples: space exploration/travel
travel in outer space
Who was the first human being in space/the first to go into space?
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: In the museum, there were a lot of interesting things, such as [a] telescope (very big), space ship, and some clothes for wearing in space. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: that which is around everything that exists and which is continuous in all directions
dictionaryExamples: He was absent-mindedly staring/gazing into space.
Virtual Reality aims to give us artificial worlds to explore, outside normal space and time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just think of this one example when you go to visit a zoo and you see the elephant or the tiger or lion walking up and down and up and down in their "prison" and staring into space. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: large and with a lot of space
dictionaryExamples: a spacious apartment/office
