sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rooms are spacious enough but they are very cold and that means that during the winter we have to wear many clothes in order to stay warm. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: emails that you do not want, usually advertisements
dictionaryExamples: Most of the emails I receive are spam.

sense.def: a very small, bright piece of burning material
dictionaryExamples: The fire was caused by a spark from a cigarette.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the last spark ceased to glow, all the people stood up and sang the Canadian national anthem. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a small idea or event which causes something bigger to start
dictionaryExamples: a spark of hope/inspiration
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And with this spark of enthusiasm for faster food, some (to me unknown) genius came up with the [m]icrowave oven, designed to cook most things in under 5 minutes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to cause an argument, fight, etc. to start happening
dictionaryExamples: to spark a debate/protest/riot
The politician's controversial speech sparked criticism even from his supporters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please notice that I am not blaming alcohol as the origin of the problem, rather, I am blaming it because it sparks off a reaction that worsens the problem. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: with small amounts and scattered over a large area
dictionaryExamples: This whole area is very sparsely populated.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A lot of these young people usually come from sparsely populated areas and want to move to a major city in order to be where things are happening. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to say something using your voice
dictionaryExamples: Would you mind speaking more slowly, please?
If she tells Julie what I said, I'll never speak to her again.
She spoke of her sadness over her father's death.
Everyone speaks very highly of  the new director.
He's old enough to speak for himself.
I went with Alex - speaking of  Alex, have you seen his new haircut?
Speaking as  a mother of four, I can tell you that children are exhausting.
Sue speaks with an American accent.
For five whole minutes, neither of them spoke a word.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like speaking also because I speak to everybody. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: to be able to talk in a language
dictionaryExamples: He speaks fluent French.
How many foreign languages do you speak?
I couldn't speak a word of  Spanish when I got there.
I couldn't figure out what language they were speaking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't speak English prop[e]rly. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: to talk about something
dictionaryExamples: Ted will speak about careers in education.
In the interview she spoke of her sadness at her mother's death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They filmed the teachers speaking about this event, and the beautiful paintings made by the students. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used to explain that you are talking about something in a general/personal, etc., way
dictionaryExamples: Well, generally speaking, it's quicker if you take the train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Generally speaking, the best way to keep fit is to live a healthy life. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to deliver a formal talk to a group of people about a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: She was invited to speak at a conference in Madrid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [O]n behalf of all its members, I would like to invite you to speak at one of our meetings. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to express the feelings, opinions, etc., of another person or a group of people
dictionaryExamples: I've been chosen to speak on behalf of the whole class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I speak for many when I say that school wouldn't be what it is, if it were not for the great men and women who sacrifice so much of their time so that we students can stimulate our minds and learn more. International English Language Testing System; C1; Norwegian

sense.def: used to explain that the words you are using do not have their usual meaning
dictionaryExamples: I do have a blog, so yes, I am a writer, so to speak.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maintaining a good working relationship with your colleagues is one of the critical factors in keeping the company you work for afloat, so to speak. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If something speaks for itself, it is clear and needs no further explanation.
dictionaryExamples: The school's excellent record speaks for itself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the one hand the economic success of sports events speaks for itself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If something speaks volumes, it makes an opinion, characteristic, or situation very clear without the use of words.
dictionaryExamples: She said very little, but her face spoke volumes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although there is always something a country is famous for, cooking is what speaks volumes of its inhabitants and the region. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to say exactly what you think without worrying if it will upset anyone
dictionaryExamples: She has very strong opinions and she's not afraid to speak her mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His father is even more eccentric, speaks his mind and has no manners at all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to not speak to someone because you have argued with them
dictionaryExamples: My brother and I aren't on speaking terms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just imagine how many are those who hate their relatives or at least one of their relatives and aren't even on speaking terms with them or him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to speak in a louder voice so that people can hear you
dictionaryExamples: Could you speak up? We can't hear at the back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I read it far too fast and in a voice that was hardly a[udi]ble, and people started to shout that they couldn't hear me and that I should speak up; it was terrible! First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: the part of a radio, CD player, etc. which the sound comes out of
dictionaryExamples: I bought some new speakers for my CD player.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can give you 6, big, high quality speaker[s] for the concert. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: someone who can speak English/Spanish, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He's a fluent Russian speaker.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I'm going to be an English speaker sooner than I expected. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: someone who makes a speech to a group of people
dictionaryExamples: a good public speaker
Please join with me in welcoming our guest speaker tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The speaker told me many things about feeding birds. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: better or more important than usual things
dictionaryExamples: a special friend
The car has a number of special safety features.
I'm cooking something special for her birthday.
Is there anything special that you'd like to do today?
I have a suit for special occasions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got many presents from my friends, and I got a special present from my dad [-] it was a new bike Key English Test; A2; Indonesian

sense.def: a price which is lower than usual
dictionaryExamples: There's a special offer on sunglasses  this week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, they have stopped their special offer "1 month [for Euro] 100" and I know that you want to stay fit. As soon as they make a new offer I will let you know and then you [can] join us! Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: different from normal things, or used for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: You need to use a special kind of paint.
Some of the children have special needs.
Kevin goes to a special school for the blind.
Firefighters use special breathing equipment in smoky buildings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He stepped into a small, handmade, wooden canoe - it['s] call[ed] Hakaro. It's a special kind of canoe. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: treatment that is better than usual
dictionaryExamples: I don't expect special treatment - I just want to be treated fairly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know, an Austin Healey needs special treatment. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: someone who has a lot of experience, knowledge, or skill in a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: a software specialist
She's a specialist in modern French literature.
She's a specialist in childhood illnesses.
a leading cancer/eye specialist
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now, fully equipped and powerful computers can be so small and mobile that some specialists predict that new devices will replace [the] book. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to spend most of your time studying one particular subject or doing one type of business
dictionaryExamples: She hired a lawyer who specializes in accident cases.
a restaurant that specializes in seafood
I enjoy studying medicine, and I hope to be able to specialize in the future.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I study economics and finance, specializing in insurance. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: Her wheelchair was specially designed for her.
The opera "Aida" was specially written for the opening of the Cairo opera house in 1871.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm thinking [of] get[ting] a beautiful long black wool coat specially made for you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a special study area, work, skill, or product of a person, business, or place
dictionaryExamples: Her specialty is heart surgery.
The company’s specialty is high-performance cars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They provide courses the whole year round at all levels, although Business English is their specialty. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a group of plants or animals that share similar characteristics
dictionaryExamples: Mountain gorillas are an endangered species.
Over a hundred species of insect are found in this area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I wrote an article about saving endangered species. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to refer to a particular thing and not something general
dictionaryExamples: English for specific purposes
The disease seems to be specific to  certain types of plants.
Is there anything specific you need from the store?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We need to see animals, study them, and in some cases find out why specific types of animals can't live in the nature which we have spoiled. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: exact or containing details
dictionaryExamples: Could you be more specific about the problem?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To be more specific, our students discovered that the majority of your exhibits did not function at all. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: for a particular reason, purpose, etc.
dictionaryExamples: They're designed specifically for children.
She bought it specifically to wear at the wedding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I specifically chose to travel with you since your travel brochure promised a half-day trip to St. Andrews, where I was to meet my friend Ann. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: exactly or in detail
dictionaryExamples: I specifically told them that she doesn't eat meat.
The law specifically prohibits acts of this kind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: More specifically, students have to complete numerous questions with very long answers for four different subjects, and the time available for each subject is three hours. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a detailed description of how something should be done, made, etc.
dictionaryExamples: They are made exactly to the customer's specifications.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Translating technical specifications prepared by no[n]-native speakers can often cause serious problems. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to state or describe something clearly and exactly
dictionaryExamples: He said we should meet but didn't specify a time.
The peace treaty clearly specifies the terms for the withdrawal of troops.
He didn’t specify how much was spent on advertising.
My contract specifies (that) I must give a month's notice if I resign.
The loan must be repaid within a specified period/by a specified date.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You did not specify what kind of work you are supposed to do either in a restaurant or in a museum. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an animal, plant, etc. used as an example of its type, especially for scientific study
dictionaryExamples: This is one of the museum's finest specimens.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Plant life to is being given a hard time, as the would-be mountain explorers walk off the designated [paths] and wreak havoc in the wilderness, destroying many priceless specimens. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: extremely good, exciting, or surprising
dictionaryExamples: a spectacular view
The show was a spectacular success.
He scored a spectacular goal in the second half.
There was a spectacular sunset last night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is located in a tall building and has a spectacular view. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: someone who watches an event, sport, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The stadium was packed with cheering spectators.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At midnight sharp, fireworks covered the concert hall and I, as well as the rest of [the] spectators, felt the excitement and delight I've never felt before. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: all the different ideas, opinions, possibilities, etc. that exist
dictionaryExamples: He has support from across the whole political spectrum.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the other [end] of the spectrum of opinions you can find some people who need to park in the city for business matters, like a local shopkeeper I talked to, who is afraid of losing customers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: the set of colors into which light can be separated
dictionaryExamples: The colors of the spectrum can be seen in a rainbow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, at dawn, the sun slowly rises, producing a spectacular spectrum of colors, ranging from deep purple to blinding yellow. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to guess possible answers to a question when you do not have enough information to be certain
dictionaryExamples: The police refused to speculate about the cause of the accident.
The newspapers have speculated that they will get married next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One can speculate endlessly without any inkling of what the subject involves and will never be able to be sure whether there is any truth behind their contemplations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: when people guess about something without having enough information to be certain
dictionaryExamples: She has dismissed the claims as pure speculation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I seriously urge your organi[z]ation to base your reports on hard facts instead of speculation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: someone's ability to talk, or an example of someone talking
dictionaryExamples: People who suffer a stroke may experience a loss of speech.
His speech became slurred and indistinct.
Some expressions are used more in speech than in writing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reason why I de[c]ide[d] to join [the] English class is because of my English speech, I should talk more fluently but I'm trying my best. Preliminary English Test; B1; Gujarati

sense.def: a formal talk given usually to a large number of people on a special occasion
dictionaryExamples: I had to give/make a speech at my brother's wedding.
The Governor of New York delivered a rousing speech to the national convention.
Did you hear her acceptance speech at the Oscars ceremony?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest that if you want to invite someone to give a speech, you have to invite athletes. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the right to say or write what you want
dictionaryExamples: They fought for the right to free speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Music, especially punk-music, symbolizes freedom of speech. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: unable to speak because you are so angry, shocked, surprised, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I couldn't believe what he was telling me - I was speechless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last year, I had the opportunity to visit Chania [again] with my family and I was speechless when I understood that everything has undergone rapid change, because of tourism. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: how fast something moves or happens
dictionaryExamples: high/low speed
a speed of 25 miles per hour
They came racing down the hill at top speed.
You should reduce speed as you approach a red light.
It was the speed at which it all happened that shocked me.
This electric drill has two speeds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So we left at full speed!!! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: very fast movement
dictionaryExamples: I get a real thrill from speed.
He put on a sudden burst of speed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every summer I [do] watersports because I like water. I'm very good at swimming and I like the speed of some watersports. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: having all the most recent information about a subject or activity
dictionaryExamples: The course should bring you up to speed with the latest techniques.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart [from] this you can keep yourself up to speed with what's happening around the world on various fronts. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: to drive faster than you are allowed to according to the law
dictionaryExamples: She was exceeding the speed limit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are three ground rules you have to follow: stop at stop signs, don't exceed the speed limit and don't be in the way of other cars. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to write down or tell someone the correct letters that are used to make a word
dictionaryExamples: "How do you spell 'receive'?" "R E C E I V E."
Shakespeare did not always spell his own name the same way.
Our address is 1520 Main Street, Albuquerque - shall I spell that (out)  for you?
I think it's important that children are taught to spell.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then she made us spell our names. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: forming words with the correct letters in the correct order, or the ability to do this
dictionaryExamples: Will I be marked wrong if I use British spellings rather than American?
The computer program corrects spelling as you write.
Your essay is full of spelling mistakes/errors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to ask my teacher to help m[e] mor[e] [with] writing because I have [a] very [b]ad problem [with] spelling and gram[m]a[r]. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Albanian

sense.def: to use time doing something or being somewhere
dictionaryExamples: You need to spend at least 20 minutes on each exercise.
We like spending time together.
I spent an hour waiting for the bus.
How long do you spend on your homework?
I spent the weekend studying.
You can spend the night here if you like.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are going to spend [the] weekend in Paris. Key English Test; A2; Slovak

sense.def: to use money to buy or pay for something
dictionaryExamples: How much did you spend?
Young people seem to spend a lot of money on clothes.
We spent a fortune when we were in New York.
We spent a lot of money on our vacation but we had a great time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I spent 500 dol[la]rs [on] this mobile phone. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: the money which is used for a particular purpose, especially by a government or organization
dictionaryExamples: government spending on health care
spending cuts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "If I become Prime Minister, the first issues on my political agenda will be to curb government spending on armaments, to reorgani[z]e the bureaucratic system, to reduce the rate of unemployment," he told me the last time I saw him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a subject or area of knowledge, work, etc.
dictionaryExamples: the political sphere
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a very big crew, all of them very good in their sphere of work. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Bulgarian

sense.def: a substance made from a plant, which is used to give a special taste to food
dictionaryExamples: Cinnamon, ginger and cloves are all spices.
Spices are widely used in South Asian cooking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's very delicious with some spices and many kinds of salad. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: something that makes something else more exciting
dictionaryExamples: A scandal or two adds a little spice to office life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yes, we just have to believe in ourselves, add a little spice to our days and face the world - no matter which world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: containing spices that have strong flavor and are hot to the taste
dictionaryExamples: Do you like spicy food?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like spicy food, it's not good for my stomach. Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: a small creature with eight long legs which catches insects in a web
dictionaryExamples: a spider's web
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is afraid of spiders. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to pour liquid or another substance somewhere without intending to, or to fall or flow out of a container in  a way that is not intended
dictionaryExamples: I spilled coffee on my silk shirt.
You spilled something down your tie.
Let's see if I can pour the juice into the glass without spilling it.
He dropped a bag of sugar and it spilled all over the floor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I'm going to buy [a] new [r]ug, because [a] few days ago,  I spilled [some] ju[i]ce. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: If something spins or you spin something, it turns around and around quickly.
dictionaryExamples: The car spun across the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the valve of the reservoir is opened, it passes through a pipe and it makes the turbine spin. International English Language Testing System; C1; Malayalam

sense.def: If you spin around, or someone spins you around, your body turns quickly to face the opposite direction.
dictionaryExamples: She spun around to see what had happened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt this pleasant drift immediately and spun around, being afraid that she would see someone at the doorway. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a vegetable with large, dark green leaves and a strong taste
dictionaryExamples: spinach lasagne/salad
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The embarrassing moment came when I saw the first dish: carrots with spinach! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the long structure of bones down the center of your back, which supports your body
dictionaryExamples: She injured her spine in a riding accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I use this cent[e]r because my doctor recommended [I] follow a very specific type of exercise to correct problems that I have [with] my spine. International English Language Testing System; C1; Spanish

blocks.phrase: send shivers/a shiver down your spine

sense.def: to make you feel afraid or excited
dictionaryExamples: The sound of his voice sent shivers down my spine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Simply looking at her sent shivers down his spine - there was the love of his life, the dearest woman on good old Earth, that he's never met before. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the way people think and feel about something
dictionaryExamples: The players have a very strong team spirit.
As rock musicians in the 1960s, they were very much part of the spirit of the age/times.
We acted in a spirit of cooperation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition to [that], you should invite athletes who have experience in sports to speak about team spirit and the role that sports [have] in our life. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: feeling good/excited/unhappy, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The whole class was in good spirits that day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was in high spirits until I got my paper back. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a form of a dead person such as a ghost
dictionaryExamples: an evil spirit
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought the house could have ghosts or spirits and because of this, I tried to convince myself that it ha[d] been [my] imagination, but suddenly the lights went out. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the part of a person which is not their body, which some people believe continues to exist after they die
dictionaryExamples: I believe my spirit will live on after I die.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to tell [José San Martin] that even if he could not reach his goal, without him, we would still [be] a dependent country. Furthermore, that his spirit was, is and will be in our hearts and minds.  Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a strong alcoholic drink, such as whisky or vodka
dictionaryExamples: I don't often drink spirits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There will be [starter]s, meat, fish, desserts... and a lot of Rioja's wine, of course! Champagne and spirits too. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: relating to deep feelings and beliefs, especially religious beliefs
dictionaryExamples: Traditional ways of life fulfilled both economic and spiritual needs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to get in contact with the amazing spiritual life in [India]. There is no other country in the world with so many different religions and sects. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: in a way that relates to deep feelings and beliefs, especially religious beliefs
dictionaryExamples: We returned from our vacation refreshed both physically and spiritually.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This view of life and work is not right, according to my beliefs, since being rich can lead to happiness, but may also lead you to poverty, spiritually speaking. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to force liquid out of your mouth
dictionaryExamples: I don't like to see people spitting in public.
He took a mouthful of coffee and then spat it out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Eric could ride a horse like nobody else, he could spit the furthest and climb the highest trees, and one year Eric broke his leg and had to be taken to [the] hospital in an ambulance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: If a liquid splashes or you splash a liquid, drops of it hit or fall on something.
dictionaryExamples: Water was splashing from a hole in the roof.
Unfortunately some paint splashed onto the rug.
She splashed her face with cold water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But in some towns we stayed [in],  there were public swimming pools so we could even splash in the water. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to move in water so that drops of it go in all directions
dictionaryExamples: The children splashed through the puddles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So we were splashing around and then went to dry ourselves. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: the sound of something falling into or moving in water
dictionaryExamples: They sat listening to the splash of raindrops on the lake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [M]y friend, the mechanic Alex, heard a strang[e] noise, a very powerful splash in the sea, [and] a lot of water came into the boat. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a drop of liquid that has fallen on something, or the mark made by it
dictionaryExamples: There were several small splashes of paint on the carpet.
Add a splash of lemon juice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And at precisely 6pm, the sky is painted with a splash of orange and there you can enjoy one of the best sunsets in the world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to get a lot of public attention
dictionaryExamples: The movie made quite a splash in the US.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, it is no use splashing your money [around on] expensive gifts because this behavior shows that you are not happy but your purpose is to make a splash. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: very good or very beautiful, special, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a splendid idea
a splendid view
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as interviewing sports personalities is concerned, it would be a splendid idea to interview Gerry Armstrong because he would be able to inform students about football, as he is a very good player. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: great beauty, or something that causes admiration and attention
dictionaryExamples: It took several years to restore the building to its original splendor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, when I came back, I would be able to show this ancient civili[z]ation to the world in all it's glory and splendor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to divide into smaller parts or groups, or to divide something into smaller parts or groups
dictionaryExamples: The prize was split between Susan and Kate.
Split the grapefruit in half .
The teacher split the children (up)into three groups.
The woman split her head open  when she was thrown from the horse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion we might just split a full-time salary. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to share something by dividing it into smaller parts
dictionaryExamples: The cost of the wedding will be split between the two families.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sharing is cheaper since you always split the bills two or more ways and in your own place you cook your own food. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: If something splits or if you split it, it comes apart so that there is a long, thin hole in it.
dictionaryExamples: His shorts split when he tried to jump the fence.
Her shoes were splitting apart at the sides.
The wooden floor had cracked and split in the heat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It made a satisf[y]ing crashing noise as the frame and glass split. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If a group of people splits, or something splits them, they disagree and form smaller groups.
dictionaryExamples: This issue could split the Republican Party.
The people are split on the issue of hunting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This debate has affected a lot of discussions and split public opinion. International English Language Testing System; C1; Russian

sense.def: If two people who are married or have a relationship split up, they end it.
dictionaryExamples: They've split up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I asked her about the family and about her. She had recently split up with her boyfriend, Joe. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to stop something from being enjoyable or successful
dictionaryExamples: He tried not to let the bad news spoil his evening.
The oil spill spoiled five miles of coastline.
I haven't seen the movie yet, so don't spoil it for me by telling me what happens.
You'll spoil your appetite if you have cake now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nothing was able to spoil my holiday! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If you spoil a child, you let them have anything they want or do anything they want, usually making them badly behaved.
dictionaryExamples: Her children are completely spoiled.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Are rich kids inevitably spoiled? Will all poor kids learn the value of a dollar? I believe that this is only a common yet fallacious stereotype. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a man who is chosen to speak officially for a group or organization
dictionaryExamples: He was the spokesman for their organization.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Becoming spokesman or woman for a good cause will lead to more popularity of and more attention for the cause. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: someone who is chosen to speak officially for a group or organization
dictionaryExamples: She was the spokesperson for the group.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the local community spokesperson, my ability to plan, initiate and execute the cleaning of rivers, within our local community as a start, will be beneficial to the "Protect our river" requirements. International English Language Testing System; C1; Malay

sense.def: to give money to someone to support an activity, event, or organization, sometimes as a way to advertise your company or product
dictionaryExamples: The Rotary Club sponsors Little League baseball in the summer.
She is doing a ten-mile walk to raise money for cancer research and she asked me if I'd sponsor her for $2 a mile.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The whole [event] is organized by university students and is sponsored by local firms. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: a person or organization that gives money to support an activity, event, etc
dictionaryExamples: Corporate sponsors support many public TV programs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The party starts at 7:30 p.m and it is organi[z]ed by Mr. Arm who is the sponsor of the conference. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: when someone gives money to support something
dictionaryExamples: We wanted to set up a youth center, and asked local businesses for sponsorship.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The aim of this proposal is to explain the reason why our company can sponsor our country's tennis championship and outline the benefits we will gain from this sponsorship. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: an object with a handle and a round, curved part at one end, used for eating and serving food
dictionaryExamples: Could I have a spoon, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can I give you some knives and spoons [for] the cake? Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a game or activity which people do to keep healthy or for enjoyment, often competing against each other
dictionaryExamples: Football, baseball, basketball, and hockey are all team sports.
I enjoy winter sports like skiing and skating.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like when I must play golf.  I don't like this sport. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: relating to sports
dictionaryExamples: sports equipment
He only reads the sports section of the newspaper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should go there because in a big school there are more possibilities of making new friendships and you can choose [from] a wide range of sports activities. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: stylish and suitable for people who are active
dictionaryExamples: a sporty new car
He looks very sporty in that new jacket.

sense.def: a small, round mark which is a different color from the surface it is on
dictionaryExamples: He had a spot on his tie.
I wore that skirt with the green spots.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This lamp is green with yellow spots on it and in my opinion it's perfect for my room. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: a  place
dictionaryExamples: This looks like a nice spot for a picnic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lake Frene is just a lake, there's nothing to do and it's a crowded spot. First Certificate in English; B2; French

blocks.phrase: have a soft spot for sb/sth

sense.def: to like someone or something a lot
dictionaryExamples: I've always had a soft spot for her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would definitely like to return there because I really enjoy museums and as I have always had a soft spot for art, I can say that, that Foundation is my cup of tea. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: immediately
dictionaryExamples: I accepted the job on the spot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And when it was Meredith's turn to tell her about her impending wedding, she felt she was going to have a heart attack on the spot. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to ask someone a question that is difficult or embarrassing to answer at that time
dictionaryExamples: Sorry to put you on the spot, but I really need an answer.

sense.def: to see or notice something or someone
dictionaryExamples: I've just spotted Malcolm - he's over there, near the entrance.
If you spot any mistakes in the article just mark them with a pencil.
Darryl spotted a woodpecker high on the tree.
I soon spotted what was wrong with the printer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is very easy to spot because there is a big sign [for] the hotel next to the building. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: completely clean
dictionaryExamples: By the time I'd finished, the whole room was spotless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sitting in her armchair, Ann reali[z]ed that she was by herself for the first time after many difficult weeks spent with her mother in a spotless bedroom of a Swiss hospital. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: your husband or wife
dictionaryExamples: Is his spouse still living?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It might be that the object in question reminds the owner of a beloved person, a deceased relative, a lost love, [or] a trip with his or her spouse. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: liquid in a container which forces it out in small drops
dictionaryExamples: hair spray
spray paint
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Actually, there was an attempt to cut down on using and producing sprays which destroy the ozon[e] layer. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to force liquid out of a container in many small drops
dictionaryExamples: The fields are sprayed with pesticides.
She sprayed a little perfume on her wrists.
Vandals had sprayed graffiti on the wall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I quickly helped [the] others to decorate  the hall - we blew up as many balloons as we c[ould] and sprayed them with gold and silver. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to gradually affect a larger area
dictionaryExamples: The fire spread very rapidly because of the strong wind.
It started off as cancer of the liver but it spread to other areas of the body.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seemed that the fire might spread more. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: If information spreads, or if someone spreads it, it is communicated to many people.
dictionaryExamples: News of his victory spread quickly.
Have you been spreading gossip about them again?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The news spread all over the village. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to cover an area
dictionaryExamples: The suburbs spread for miles in every direction.
Our offices are spread (out) over a very wide area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has about 500 [in]habitants, who live in 128 houses, which are spread over a big area. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to arrange something over a large area, especially something that was folded
dictionaryExamples: I spread a blanket over his legs.
We spread the map on the floor.
He spread the cards out on the table.
She spread out her towel on the sand and lay down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She looked at all the diaries that were all spread out around her on the bed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to move a soft substance across a surface so that it covers it
dictionaryExamples: What I really like is hot, buttered toast spread  with strawberry jam.
He spread a thin layer of glue on the paper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] British are astonished when they see Catalans rubbing their bread with ripe tomatoes. Likewise Spaniards feel surprised when Europeans spread butter on it instead. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to arrange for something to happen over a period of time and not at once
dictionaryExamples: The payments will be spread over two years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This would both spread the cost and make the whole plan more workable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If people spread out, they move from being close together in a group to being in different places across a larger area.
dictionaryExamples: They spread out to search the whole area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They don't dare to spread out in the space. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when something moves to cover a larger area or affect a larger number of people
dictionaryExamples: Jazz records fostered the spread of American culture.
More should be done to stop the spread of this disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is true that these days people have much more choice in entertain[ment], the spread of computers and video games is just one example. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a chart produced on a computer which helps you to do business calculations and planning
dictionaryExamples: She prepared a spreadsheet with the new sales information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be very interested in joining your club, in order to learn how to use basic software like word processing, spreadsheet or database software. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the season of the year between winter and summer, when the weather becomes warmer and plants start to grow again
dictionaryExamples: spring flowers/weather
Many bulbs flower in (the) spring.
Janet's coming over for a couple of weeks next spring.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can come in spring. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: a place where water comes out of the ground
dictionaryExamples: hot springs
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also there is a hot spring beside a river. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to jump or move somewhere suddenly
dictionaryExamples: The cat sprang onto the sofa.
I tried to shut the door, but it kept springing open.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, we heard a clap of thunder and all of us sprang to our feet. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If something springs to mind, you suddenly think of it.
dictionaryExamples: Mention fashion and Kate’s name immediately springs to mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A musical event that clearly springs to mind is a Rolling Stones concert in Parken, Copenhagen, which I attended in June 1998. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to come from or be the result of something
dictionaryExamples: Her remarkable poise springs from her early theater training.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Here again, the musicians are concentrated on the energy and beauty of their surroundings and their lyrics spring from everyday observations, thus greatly enhancing the potential of small things. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to appear suddenly
dictionaryExamples: A lot of new hotels have sprung up along the coast recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  A number of new budget airlines have sprung up in Europe [over] the last several years. International English Language Testing System; C2; Sindhi

sense.def: to gently drop small pieces of something over a surface
dictionaryExamples: Sprinkle the cake with sugar before serving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Near the cathedral, in an impos[ing] Baroque building, there is the collection of modern Tinguely's fountains. Built with recycled materials, thousands of pieces move aimless[ly], sprinkling water everywhere. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to encourage someone to do something or something to happen
dictionaryExamples: Spurred on by his fans, he won the next three games easily.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It may spur them on [to] achieving more in the future. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

blocks.phrase: on the spur of the moment

sense.def: If you do something on the spur of the moment, you do it suddenly, without planning it.
dictionaryExamples: On the spur of the moment we decided to go to London for the day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In reality, many people buy things on the spur of the moment only to discover later that they, in fact, do not [meet] their expect[at]ions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: someone who secretly tries to discover information about a person, country, etc.
dictionaryExamples: His father was a British spy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a spy story. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to secretly try to discover information about a person, country, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He was accused of spying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, some countries have fears about foreigners coming from underdeveloped countries and may consider some of them as a source of troubles including crimes, spying and maybe terrorism. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: to secretly watch someone
dictionaryExamples: He spied on her through the keyhole.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Edmund starts spying on Charles to find out which his weaknesses are. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to waste time, money, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He squandered all his money on alcohol and drugs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By a quirk of fate, one day I reali[z]ed that her parents were oblivious to the places that she visited or the products she squandered her money on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a shape with four equal sides and four 90° angles
dictionaryExamples: First draw a square.
It's a square-shaped room.
When cooled, cut the chocolate brownies into squares.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm writing to you because I bought some new shoes.  I liked them because they have black and white little squares and they're very co[m]fortable. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: an open area with buildings around it in a city or town
dictionaryExamples: Many New York theaters and hotels are near Times Square.
A band was playing in the town square.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Go up the street and turn left [at] the square. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: having the shape of a square
dictionaryExamples: The recipe recommends that you use a square cake pan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I bought a pr[et]ty dress and a square bag. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to crush something into a flat shape
dictionaryExamples: He accidentally sat on her hat and squashed it.

sense.def: to push someone or something into a small space
dictionaryExamples: The kids were all squashed into the back seat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My idea of fun is not getting up at seven o'clock in the morning to take a bus where we are squashed by lots of rude people we don't even know. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a sport in which two people hit a small rubber ball against the four walls of a room
dictionaryExamples: a game of squash
a squash court/racket
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the club you can play golf, tennis, squash and football. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to make a short, high sound
dictionaryExamples: His shoes squeaked loudly as he walked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The wood of the drawer squeaked. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: making short, high sounds
dictionaryExamples: a squeaky voice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He pushed open the squeaky wooden entrance doors, noticing the smell of fresh cyan[-]colored paint. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to press something firmly
dictionaryExamples: She squeezed his hand and said goodbye.
Cut the lemon in half and squeeze the juice into the bowl.
The baby loves that doll because it laughs when you squeeze it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It must have been nine o'clock and I was there, sitting [i]n my armchair, squeezing a cushion in my arms. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to move somewhere where there is very little space
dictionaryExamples: She squeezed through a narrow gap in the wall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are [a] huge [number] of workers every morning trying to squeeze through the tiny door. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: to succeed in getting someone or something into a small space or object, often by pushing or forcing
dictionaryExamples: We have four people in our car, but we could squeeze one more person in the back.
I must have put on some weight - I can only just squeeze into my jeans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the end of the day, I would not only be carrying [a] pile of shopping bags but also trying to squeeze in between other passengers on the train on my way home. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

blocks.phrasalVerb: squeeze sb/sth in or squeeze in sb/sth

sense.def: to manage to do something or see someone in a short period of time or when you are very busy
dictionaryExamples: While we're in Australia, we're hoping to squeeze in a trip to the Barrier Reef.
I'm very busy this week but I could squeeze you in at 2:30 on Tuesday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, the acquisition of two more TV sets and video cassette players would be extremely desirable as at the moment we have great difficulty in squeezing in video lesson[s] in the timetable having only one video class[room] available. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to push a knife into someone
dictionaryExamples: She was stabbed in the arm.
The victim had been stabbed to death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She raised the knife high in the air and stabbed it right into her stomach. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: when something is not likely to change or move
dictionaryExamples: political/financial stability
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Yugoslavia sport was an important factor contributing to the overall stability of the federation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Slovene

sense.def: not likely to change, become worse, or end suddenly
dictionaryExamples: Prices have remained fairly stable in recent years.
The doctor said his condition was stable.
a stable relationship
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is due to [the] low economic development of this country, which is nowadays relatively stable. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: mentally calm and not easily upset
dictionaryExamples: He's not a very stable person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Children with [a] good coping mechanism are emotionally stable in facing their problems. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: a building where horses are kept
dictionaryExamples: We put the horses in their stables.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not only is the noise they make so unbearable that we cannot sleep or drop off in the afternoon, but your pilots seem to enjoy low-flying raids over our stables, thus disturbing our horses. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a large building with rows of seats on many levels that surrounds an open area of land on which sports are played
dictionaryExamples: Yankee Stadium
a football stadium
Thousands of fans packed the stadium.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The town has a wonderful zoo with a lot of animals and a great stadium [for] soccer game[s]. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the group of people who work for an organization or for a manager within an organization
dictionaryExamples: There is a good relationship between staff and pupils at the school.
She joined the staff of the Smithsonian Institution in 1954.
The coaching staff feel we need to focus more on defense.
He is on  the editorial staff of the magazine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I told my father to tell the staff of the hotel. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: the raised area in a theater where actors perform
dictionaryExamples: Hamlet is on stage for most of the act.
The orchestra went on/off stage to great applause.
The opera singer returns to the London stage  this summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can clean the stage, build the light[ing] and connect the P.A. (Power Amplifier). Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: a period of development, or a particular time in a process
dictionaryExamples: The project is in its final stages and should be completed by August.
They did the last stage of their journey on foot.
Our marriage is going through a difficult stage at the moment.
Their youngest child is at the stage where she can say individual words but not full sentences.
I'm not tired at the moment but I will need a rest at some stage  during the walk.
At this stage, most children are able to read simple words.
Andrew spends all his spare time playing with his computer but it's probably just a stage he's going through.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At that stage of our holiday, we stayed quiet [for] some days in order to rest a bit after all those hours of driving. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to organize and produce a performance of music or a play, etc.
dictionaryExamples: They staged a free concert in Central Park.
The local theater group is staging a production of the musical "Grease."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My daughter's nursery school staged "Buratino." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to walk as if you might fall
dictionaryExamples: He staggered drunkenly towards the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Drearily and wearily they carried on, sometimes squelching through the mud, sometimes staggering on loose rocks. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: very shocking and surprising
dictionaryExamples: He earns a staggering amount of money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, it is expected to rise to a staggering 98% in 2010. International English Language Testing System; C1; Thai

sense.def: a dirty mark on something that is difficult to remove
dictionaryExamples: a blood/grass stain
You can remove a red wine stain from a carpet by sprinkling salt over it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I reali[z]ed that I had a stain on my trousers. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to leave a dirty mark on something which is difficult to remove, or to become dirty in this way
dictionaryExamples: That juice stained my shirt.
This carpet is practical because it doesn’t stain easily.
Tomato sauce stains - it's really hard to get it out of clothes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I may [make] a request, please, try not to spoil my best white tablecloth.  And if you do stain it, don't use the bleach! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to permanently spoil something such as someone's reputation
dictionaryExamples: Several politicians have had their reputations stained by the scandal.
The country's history is stained with the blood of countless innocent men and women.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All those "mistakes", to put it kindly, stain the public image of our association AND the hospital. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a set of stairs and the structure around them
dictionaryExamples: a spiral staircase
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The second floor can only be accessed by an outside staircase or a pole that runs through the second floor, like those at fire fighters' stations. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a set of steps which lead from one level of a building to another
dictionaryExamples: Go up the stairs and her office is on the right.

He stood at the foot
                              of the stairs and called out, "Breakfast's ready!"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have left my backpack in your house. I think it is near the stairs. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a set of stairs connecting one floor to another in a building
dictionaryExamples: The elevator was broken so we had to climb six flights of stairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He descended a long flight of stairs and reached a door. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: old and not fresh
dictionaryExamples: stale bread
Cake goes stale quickly if it's not covered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, the food was nothing special - the bread for breakfast was stale and the rice for dinner was cold. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: a large table or a small shop with an open front from which goods are sold in a public place
dictionaryExamples: In the village market, the stalls are piled high with local vegetables.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know, there's a big commercial square near my house where traders, along with shops, set up stalls every day and sell an enormous variety of lifestyle products ranging from CDs and instruments to furniture and clothes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: the physical or mental energy that allows you to do something for a long time
dictionaryExamples: Marathon runners need a lot of stamina.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a healthy strong girl with stamina. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a small, official piece of paper that you buy and stick onto a letter or package before you mail it to show that you have paid for postage
dictionaryExamples: Do we have any stamps? I need to mail this letter.
I'll buy stamps while I'm at the post office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobby is collecting stamps. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to put a mark on an object either by printing on it or pushing into it with a small tool
dictionaryExamples: It is necessary to stamp your passport.
Milk containers are stamped with a sell-by date.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was only a small sign stamped on the door, saying that it was "closed for repairs". First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to put your foot down on the ground hard and quickly, often to show anger
dictionaryExamples: "No!" she shouted, stamping her foot.
The audience started jeering and stamping their feet.
He stamped on my foot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I missed him so, that even if he w[o]uld pout and stamp his feet I would beam at him tenderly and kiss him gently on his cheek. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: an opinion or belief about something, especially if you say it in public
dictionaryExamples: What's their stance on nuclear energy?
They are adopting/taking a very tough stance on drugs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For all the above-mentioned reasons, and as president of the local youth club, I would like to express my stance on this subject and offer viable solutions to the local council. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be in a vertical position on your feet
dictionaryExamples: He's standing over there, next to Karen.
Granny says if she stands (up) for a long time her ankles hurt.
Stand still and be quiet!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will stand at the front of my house. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: to rise to a vertical position on your feet from sitting or lying down
dictionaryExamples: I get dizzy if I stand up too quickly.
Everyone please stand.
As a sign of politeness you should stand up when she comes in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All [the] class stood up and sang "Imagine". Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to hate someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I can't stand him.
She can't stand doing housework.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't stand small schools, so, I hope the large[r] one is the better. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be in or to put something in a particular place or position
dictionaryExamples: His walking stick stood by the door.
You'll have to stand the sofa on its end to get it through the door.
The room was empty except for a lamp standing in one corner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As he stepped forward I knelt down and pulled his leg, so that he fell over and hit a small table standing beside the sofa. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: if a building stands, it has not been destroyed.
dictionaryExamples: After the earthquake not a single building was left standing in the village.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The city was filled of magnificent monuments, some of them still standing today. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to be at a particular level, amount, height, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Inflation currently stands at three percent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was overtaken by furniture and equipment, which stood at 23[%] in 2001, but only at 15% in 1981. International English Language Testing System; C1; German

sense.def: to be able to accept or deal with a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: She couldn't stand the pressures of the job.
The pain was more than he could stand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, last week we had a meeting and we decided to complain about that because nobody could stand the situation any more. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If it stands to reason that something happens or is true, it is what you would expect.
dictionaryExamples: It stands to reason that a child who is constantly criticized will have little self-confidence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So it stands to reason that there is no place for Piggy in Jack's world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to be in a particular state or situation
dictionaryExamples: The house stood empty for years.
As things stand right now, there’s no telling who will win.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The cottage next to ours stood empty. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: If someone stands trial, they appear in a law court where people decide if they are guilty of a crime.
dictionaryExamples: Berenson will stand trial next month in the county court.
to stand trial for treason
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was going there in order to arrest Christians and bring them to Jerusalem to stand trial for their treason. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be in a situation where you can get/lose money or an advantage
dictionaryExamples: He stands to gain a fortune if the company is sold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: International tourism should be encouraged, rather than reduced, because countries that are still developing stand to gain a lot from visitors from other parts of the world. International English Language Testing System; C1; Efik

sense.def: what someone thinks about you, how they expect you to behave, and how they are likely to behave
dictionaryExamples: He didn’t even send me a birthday card, so I guess I know where I stand.

sense.def: what your opinion is about something
dictionaryExamples: The Senator has made it clear where she stands on these issues.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From where I stand, some action must be taken urgently because the problems are constantly exacerbating. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to have a chance of success or of achieving something
dictionaryExamples: He doesn’t stand much of a chance in the election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If this measure were taken, the outcome would be of fundamental importance for the currently unemployed because they will stand a chance of finding a job and making a living. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: as something is now, without changes in it
dictionaryExamples: The law as it stands is very unclear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion, this debate is rooted in a deeper questioning of society's foundations: some people see society as it stands today as inherently flawed, an amorphous group of people who follow and worship anyone that gives them pleasure. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to refuse to change your opinion or give in to an argument
dictionaryExamples: I kept trying to get my grandmother to find  a smaller house, but she stood her ground.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She said she would stand her ground, and never, never [falt]er. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you will not stand for something, you will not accept a situation or a particular type of behavior
dictionaryExamples: I wouldn't stand for that sort of behavior from him, if I were you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Much as I admire the performance of the new aircraft today, I understand your need to fly and test new technologies, but I will not stand for it any longer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to move a short distance away from something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Please stand back - then all of you will be able to see what I'm doing.

sense.def: to support or be loyal to someone
dictionaryExamples: The boy’s friends stood by him, firmly convinced of his innocence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I promise I'll stand by you. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to support or represent a particular idea or set of ideas
dictionaryExamples: This party stands for low taxes and individual freedom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She said she would stand her ground, and never, never stagger. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If one or more letters stand for a word or name, they are the first letter or letters of that word or name and they represent it
dictionaryExamples: "GMT" stands for Greenwich Mean Time.

sense.def: used with "not" to say you will not accept a situation or a particular type of behavior
dictionaryExamples: Maybe you think his behavior is OK, but I won’t stand for it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Much as I admire the performance of the new aircraft today, I understand your need to fly and test new technologies, but I will not stand for it any longer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to do something that someone else was going to do because they cannot be there
dictionaryExamples: She stood in for me when I was sick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I will be away these two days, I have asked Mr. Ryman's secretary Sandy, to stand in for me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to be much better than other similar things or people
dictionaryExamples: One candidate stood out from the rest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those small fishing villages will always stand out in my memory. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to be easy to see or notice
dictionaryExamples: The bright blue letters really stand out on the page.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Why wasn't that money spent in trying to make them more bearable to [look at], [rather] than making them stand out even more? First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

blocks.phrasalVerb: stand up sb or stand sb up

sense.def: to fail to meet someone you have arranged to see
dictionaryExamples: I was starting to think I'd been stood up when he finally arrived.

sense.def: to defend or support a particular idea or a person who is being criticized or attacked
dictionaryExamples: It's high time we all stood up for our rights around here.
Don't be bullied, learn to stand up for yourself and what you believe in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He decides to stand up for black rights and becomes an important leader. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to defend yourself against a powerful person or organization when they treat you unfairly
dictionaryExamples: He wasn't afraid to stand up to bullies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They say that the best things in life are for free, courage, hope, love for freedom and the power to stand up to others, defending one's own rights. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a table or small structure from which goods are sold or shown
dictionaryExamples: a hot dog stand
Visit our stand at the trade fair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What I aimed for was to get in touch with as m[any] interesting companies as I could, and I really did it because there were lots of stands with a good choice of companies, ranging fro the biggest ones (IBB or Siemens, for example) to other smaller but also interesting. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: to publicly defend something or stop something from happening
dictionaryExamples: It's about time someone made a stand.
She’ll no doubt take a strong stand against raising taxes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We cannot simply stand by while our greenery is being [destroy]ed, so I am making a stand. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a piece of furniture for holding things
dictionaryExamples: a music/hat stand
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We go backstage, the audience is still clapping and the people in the orchestra are beating with their bow[s] on the music stand[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: a level of quality, especially a level that is acceptable
dictionaryExamples: safety standards
His work was below/above standard.
She sets very high standards for herself.
That’s not their usual high standard of service.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I hope that my ideas will help to improve [the] standards of this café and will bring more customers [in] the future. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: how much money and comfort someone has
dictionaryExamples: a low/high standard of living
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think we would have a better standard of living if we had this situation. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a level of behavior, especially a level that is acceptable
dictionaryExamples: high moral standards
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to my moral standards, adults should not take advantage of children's lack of experience and they should certainly not incite them to tell lies and betray others. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: usual rather than special, especially when thought of as being correct or acceptable
dictionaryExamples: a standard contract
This is a standard medical text.
These are standard procedures for handling radioactive waste.
The meter is the standard unit for measuring length in the SI system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It should be a standard price. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: a particular way of thinking about a situation or problem
dictionaryExamples: to look at something from a political/religious standpoint
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From a moral standpoint it can be argued that the income distribution that comes from such incredible payments is unacceptable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a famous singer, actor, sports person, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a rock/movie/basketball star
Kids wanting to be stars come to Hollywood.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I really liked it because lots of soccer stars were there and both teams played very well, but Brazil won, of course. 
 Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a ball of burning gases that you see as a small point of light in the sky at night
dictionaryExamples: Stars twinkled/shone in the night sky.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, it's really big, with two windows to see the garden [in the] morning, and the stars at night. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a shape or symbol with four or more points
dictionaryExamples: star-shaped
How many stars  does this restaurant have?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has pink flowers and blue stars. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: used to show how good a restaurant or hotel is
dictionaryExamples: a five-star hotel
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also the facilities were great and people started building houses, and the small village became an attractive town with museums, universities, wonderful beaches, five-star hotels and other beautiful facilities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: someone or something that is better than all the others in a group
dictionaryExamples: He is one of our star players.
She was the star of the English class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He led Brazil to win two more World Cups, and in both of them he was the star player, the black prince. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: If a film, play, etc. stars someone, or if someone stars in a film, play, etc., they are the main actor in it.
dictionaryExamples: Ben Kingsley starred in the film "Gandhi."
The novel was turned into a film starring Meryl Streep.
The school play stars children in the seventh and eighth grades.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As we both love romantic comedy, we decided to see  Notting Hill [together], which starred Julia Roberts and Hugh Grant. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when someone is very famous for acting, singing, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She is heading for stardom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The phenomenon of stardom is a complex one. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: to look at someone or something for a long time and not move your eyes
dictionaryExamples: Don't stare at people like that, it's rude.
Chuck sat quietly for hours staring into the distance, thinking of what might have been.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: David had seen her once before in a park, staring at him. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to begin doing something
dictionaryExamples: When do you start your English course/your new job?
We'll be starting (the class) at six o'clock.
Can you start  on Monday?
They started building the house in January.
I'd just started to make my lunch when the phone rang.
The speaker started with a description of her journey to China.
You could start by cleaning the kitchen.
He started his working life as an engineer but later became a teacher.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Ramesh, I start my class at 9:30 am. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: to begin to happen or to make something begin to happen
dictionaryExamples: His mother started the craft market at the community center.
Fire Department officials believe the fire was started by arsonists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that we started a discussion about social life. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: If a business or other organization starts, or if someone starts one, it is created and starts to operate.
dictionaryExamples: She started her own software company.
We started up an opera theater company that toured all over the South.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was the first time in many years he had the opportunity or time to think over his situation and life. He had started his company fifteen years ago and had been successful. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If you start a machine or an engine, you switch it on, and if a machine or engine starts, it begins to work.
dictionaryExamples: The car wouldn't start.
Do you know how to start the lawn mower?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The car would not start and it was impossible to get a taxi because it was Saturday evening, so the only thing we could do was to run all the way to the school. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: used before saying the first thing in a list of things
dictionaryExamples: To start with, we need better computers. Then we need more training.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is some information I should tell you about. To start with, the T.V. repairman didn't come on Wednesday morning as expected. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to begin by doing something, or to make something begin by doing something
dictionaryExamples: She started off the meeting with the monthly sales report.
I'd like to start off by thanking you all for coming today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We started off the trip by driving to the foot of the mountain, where there was a village. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to begin your life, or the part of your life when you work, in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: My dad started out as a sales assistant in a department store.
