sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a beautiful, talented wom[a]n who started out as a small actress in her own country, climbing up to become the fully-recognized celebrity that she is now. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the beginning of something
dictionaryExamples: We were doubtful from the start.
They announced the start of a new commercial venture.
The weather was good at the start  of the week.
The event got off to a bad/slow/shaky start.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My first experience was a good start, I could understand everything that the teacher said and I was also able to communicate with the other students, of course there are still mistakes which I will try to improve. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an advantage that you have over someone else when you begin something
dictionaryExamples: I'm grateful for the start I had in life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With a better start in life these children will be less likely to end up on the street again. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the state of having no food for a long period
dictionaryExamples: These people are dying of starvation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While a few decades ago people used to die from starvation even in industriali[z]ed countries like France, nowadays the situation has changed and food can be found so easily that it has become an increasing source of health-related problems when exceeded. International English Language Testing System; C2; Italian

sense.def: to become ill or die because you do not have enough food, or to make someone ill or die because they do not have enough food
dictionaryExamples: Many people have starved to death in parts of Africa.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People were starving to death and various crimes took place. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: ill or dying because there is not enough food
dictionaryExamples: starving people
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What shocked me most was the misery and poverty: thousands of homeless people roaming the streets starving and cold. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: very hungry
dictionaryExamples: I'm absolutely starving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've always been greedy, but [at] that moment, while my Chemistry teacher was explaining a difficult lesson, I was really starving. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a part of a large country with its own government, such as in Brazil, Mexico, or the US
dictionaryExamples: Alaska is the largest state in the US.
Representatives are elected from each state.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have time, you will enjoy walking in the mountains at Miras Gerais, which is an important Brazilian state. The sunset there is wonderful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the condition that something or someone is in
dictionaryExamples: The building is in a terrible state.
After the accident I was in a state of shock.
The kitchen was in its original state, with a 1920s sink and stove.
It's a sad state of affairs when our rivers are so endangered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people say TV can be harmful because it keeps our mind in a passive state. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a country or its government
dictionaryExamples: The drought is worst in the central African states.
Britain is one of the member states of the European Union.
The government was determined to reduce the number of state-owned industries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I opted, since I must talk about my country's history, to choose an event not from the [w]hole history of the Greek nation, but from that of the independent Greek state (kingdom or republic, it depends [on] the period), which ha[d] a life of about 270-280 years. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to officially say or write something
dictionaryExamples: Our warranty clearly states the limits of our liability.
His will states (that) the property is to be sold.
Please state why you are applying for this grant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Mr Thomas, I've read your advertis[e]ment in [the] last issue of "The Traveller", [where] you state that you are looking for people to work on your campsites with English-speaking tourists. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: provided, created, or done by a state in a country, or by the government of a country
dictionaryExamples: a state government/legislature/law
a state school/college/university
state control
state funding
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Here in Argentina the rules at school depend on the school.  In general, the rules at private schools are much [strict]er than the ones at state schools. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: something that someone says or writes officially
dictionaryExamples: The candidate made a statement to the press.
He produced a signed statement from his client.
We were not surprised by their statement that the train services would be reduced.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Editor Referring to your article of today, I want to correct some statements [made]. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a piece of paper that shows how much money you have put into your bank account and how much you have taken out
dictionaryExamples: I always check my statement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My collection consists of original, pre-WW2 hand-written documents - anything from love letters to bank statements, chores lists handed out to servants to pre-nuptial agre[e]ments, as long as it is hand-written, [it] finds its way to my archives. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: using the newest ideas, designs, and materials
dictionaryExamples: It is a computer system that uses state-of-the-art technology.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is the impressive and simply state-of-the-art graphics that entice the player to spend hours in front of the screen. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a building where trains or buses stop so that you can get on or off them
dictionaryExamples: a train/bus station
Dad met me at the Metro station.
Our office is near the subway station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will meet you at the bus station. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: a company that broadcasts television or radio programs
dictionaryExamples: a radio/television station
The reception is not very good - try to tune in to another station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last week I was [listen]ing to my favorite radio station and they announced a new sports club. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a fact in the form of a number that shows information about something
dictionaryExamples: The city’s most surprising statistic is its crime rate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wom[e]n have always been as bright and educated as men - statistics show that in Germany there are more women entering for exams at the universities than there are men. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: relating to statistics
dictionaryExamples: There is no statistical evidence to support his claims.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I just wondered why your newspaper didn't stick to the statistical figures and the pie chart we announced on the next day [after] the fund-raising activity. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a collection of facts in the form of numbers that show information about something
dictionaryExamples: The statistics show that, in general, women live longer than men.
According to government/official statistics, skin cancer is becoming more common.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to statistics based on the questionnair[e], the majority of students feel the most enthusiasm for [their] English class. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a model that looks like a person or animal, usually made from stone or metal
dictionaryExamples: a statue of a boy
They planned to put up/erect a statue to the President.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After, we passed in front of the statue of the president. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: an accepted or official position, especially in a social group
dictionaryExamples: The association works to promote the status of retired people as useful members of the community.
There has been an increase in applications for refugee status.
The success of her book has given her unexpected celebrity status.
Applicants should have a degree or a qualification of equal status.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their status and income were shadowed by the state. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Slovene

sense.def: something that people want to have because they think it will make people admire them
dictionaryExamples: For him, a big car is an important status symbol.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jobs now play a very important role as status symbols. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to remain in a place, job, etc. and not leave
dictionaryExamples: I have a meeting at three so I can’t stay long.
James had to stay after school to complete the assignment.
They need an assistant who is willing to stay for six months.
She’s come back home to stay.
Because of the snow, schools have been closed and children told to stay home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the break times, I prefer to stay [in] the classroom just [to] read the French-English dictionary, so I learn or discover many other words that I can use in my speech. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto

sense.def: to live or be in a place for a short time as a visitor
dictionaryExamples: I stayed in Montreal for two weeks then flew home.
I’ll be staying overnight at my sister’s house.
My sister is staying with us this weekend.
They said they'd stay at/in a hotel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last week I went to visit Egypt for 10 days.  I stayed in Cairo 5 days.  It's [a] good town but it's very busy. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Arabic

sense.def: to continue to be in a particular state
dictionaryExamples: The supermarket stays open late.
I was tired and couldn't stay awake.
They stayed friends, even after they moved to different countries.
You need to stay focused - your mind can wander during a long drive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people prefer to stay dry [rather] than be caught by the rain. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to remain in the same place and not leave there
dictionaryExamples: He told me to stay put while he went to get the car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was extremely stressful and she didn't like the working conditions and atmosphere at work, but as it was [difficult] to find another job, she stayed put. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to remain away from something or to avoid something
dictionaryExamples: Stay away from the edge of the cliff.
Those buildings are being torn down - you should stay away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The place is small and with a lot of trees if you prefer to stay away from the hot summer sun or if you feel like having a picnic. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: to remain at a place when other people leave it
dictionaryExamples: Francine went on ahead and I stayed behind to wait for Annie.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: The tourists were to stay behind, waiting for his return, so they all made themselves comfortable as well as they could. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to remain somewhere for a longer time than expected or after other people have left
dictionaryExamples: His boss asked him to stay on as manager for another year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus it can be seen in the novel that Olivia left her husband for another man and that she was determined to stay on in India in spite of her friends judging her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to not come home at night, or to go home late
dictionaryExamples: My folks don't let me stay out late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, I like it so much because we have no school and we can stay out for as long as we want. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to not become involved in an argument or discussion
dictionaryExamples: It's better to stay out of their arguments.
You don't know anything about this, so just stay out of it!

sense.def: to spend the night somewhere instead of returning to your home or continuing your journey
dictionaryExamples: Why don't you stay over and drive back in the morning?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We stay[ed] over in a hotel and the next morning Tom brought me home. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to go to bed later than usual
dictionaryExamples: We stayed up (late) to watch a movie on TV.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Vegas, we were staying up all night gambling. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a period of time that you spend in a place
dictionaryExamples: Did you enjoy your stay in Tokyo?
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I hope my stay in London will be an interesting experience, because I pa[i]d a lot for this trip. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: at a gradual, regular rate
dictionaryExamples: Prices have risen steadily over the last two decades.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Towns are growing steadily and as a result of this animals disappear because we destroy forests, lakes, etc. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: happening at a gradual, regular rate
dictionaryExamples: Manufacturers have seen a steady increase/decline in profits.
We've seen a steady stream of visitors to the museum this summer.
Progress has been slow but steady.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is also a steady rise in underweight [young girls] today. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: still and not shaking
dictionaryExamples: You need steady hands to be a dentist.
Make sure you hold the ladder steady.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know very well you have steady nerves but what is strong can turn weak as well. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: not changing
dictionaryExamples: She drove at a steady speed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once on the road, keep a steady speed (not too slow, not too fast) and try to look confident.

sense.def: a job that is likely to continue for a long time and pay you regular money
dictionaryExamples: I wish he'd get a steady job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They now had steady jobs, she reasoned; their time [in] college had been turbulent and not quite happy and they had badly needed a mother figure to see [it] through, but that time was over now. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a thick, flat piece of meat or fish
dictionaryExamples: steak and potatoes
a tuna/salmon steak
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was at the club and we had a steak and games at the pool. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to secretly take something that does not belong to you, without intending to return it
dictionaryExamples: She admitted stealing the money from her employers.
The number of cars which are stolen every year has risen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All my friends gave me lots of presents, but I like the bike best. I like it because my bike was stolen. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: the hot gas that is produced when water boils
dictionaryExamples: Steam rose from the simmering stew.
a steam engine
the age of steam
The pump is driven by steam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've been interested in trains, in particular steam trains, since my childhood. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to get rid of your anger, excitement, etc. by being noisy or using a lot of energy
dictionaryExamples: The children need to run around and let off steam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that listening to it on a daily basis will be an ideal way for us to relieve the day's pressure and let off steam. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a very strong metal made from iron, used for making knives, machines, etc.
dictionaryExamples: steel pipes
a stainless steel sink
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The object that I would choose is without any doubt my Katana, my Japanese Sword. It is a weapon that reminds me of my childhood games. I also like the form, and the cool steel of the blade. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: A steep slope, hill, etc. rises up high in a sudden, quick way.
dictionaryExamples: a steep slope
It's a steep climb to the top of the mountain, but the view is worth it.
The castle is set on a steep hill/hillside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the slope was terribly steep and I didn't dare to ski down. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: A steep increase or fall in something is very big and quick.
dictionaryExamples: There has been a steep increase/rise in prices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Company A starts the year 1990 with a profit figure of five million dollars, there is a steep rise, and profits reach to up to ten million dollars by year 1995. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: to control the direction of a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: She carefully steered the car around the potholes.
This car is very easy to steer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After an hour she could keep [her] balance but she still had problems steering, but that didn't matter. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to avoid someone or something because they are unpleasant or dangerous
dictionaryExamples: Steer clear of Tony this morning - he's in a bad mood.
Davis steered clear of politics because of all the problems his father had had as governor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Eating healthy doesn't mean starving, eating plants or steering clear of meat. International English Language Testing System; C1; Latvian

sense.def: a wheel that you turn to control the direction of a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: He took both hands off the steering wheel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After leaving your house on Monday morning, I gripped the steering wheel, fixed my eyes firmly on the road, and bravely drove my way up to Scotland. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: one of the movements you make with your feet when you walk
dictionaryExamples: Sophie took her first steps when she was eleven months old.
He rose to his feet and took a couple of steps toward her.
With every step, her feet hurt her more and more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to run but with my first step, I kicked something that fell to the floor. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: one of the surfaces that you walk on when you go up or down stairs
dictionaryExamples: Mom took a picture of us sitting on the front steps of the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I go down four steps and I am [o]n the beach! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: one of the things that you do to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: What's the next step in the instructions?
We must stay one step ahead of our competitors.
Most people believe that the decision to cut interest rates was a step in the right direction.
The President took the unusual step of altering his prepared speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We'd like to know how it feels to be in the film business, how you started and the steps you've taken to be where you are now. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: moving slowly from one stage of something to the next
dictionaryExamples: I know there's a lot to prepare, but just take things step by step and don't worry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The book actually guides you step by step on how you can cope with this fear and defeat it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to go back somewhere the same way that you came
dictionaryExamples: I was lost so I retraced my steps.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mentally retracing his steps of the morning, he remembered rushing out of his place at the last minute. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to move somewhere by lifting your foot and putting it down in a different place
dictionaryExamples: She stepped carefully over the dog.
She stepped backward and fell over a chair.
They stepped out onto the balcony.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The moment he stepped out of the train he realized he had left his suitcase inside. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to put your foot on or in something
dictionaryExamples: I accidentally stepped on her foot.
Be careful not to step in the mud.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I ha[d] to dance with a boy [whose] name is Alex and every time he stepped on my feet. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to leave an important job
dictionaryExamples: She stepped down as captain of the swim team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus, he decided to retire, to step down from the tough and competitive environment and planned for the rest of his life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: the man who is married to your mother but is not your father
dictionaryExamples: His stepfather gave him a job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once, Matthew told Pat that he was mistreated by his stepfather in his childhood. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the woman who has married your father but is not your mother
dictionaryExamples: My stepmother owns her own business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He made up his mind to defeat them, and asked his stepmother for some kibidango, one of [the] traditional snacks in Japan. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a fixed idea that people have about what a particular type of person is like, especially an idea that is wrong
dictionaryExamples: racial   stereotypes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seems commonly accepted that the new ''high-tech'' society has turned us into lazy people, without aims, targets, even hobbies in our spare time, unless watching videos or playing computer games. I am a student, I am young and I know a lot of people like me who do not fit in this stereotype. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: having the qualities that you would expect a particular kind of person to have
dictionaryExamples: a stereotypical student
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another person would rather perceive a stereotypical celebrity, a singer or a sports star as a greedy, self-absorbed and shallow pleasure seeker, concerned only with his or her own appearance and flaunting undeserved wealth. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: very serious and without any humor
dictionaryExamples: a stern expression
stern criticism
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He shot his sister Sarah a stern look which did not deter her from grinning maliciously. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to become joined to something else or to make something become joined to something else, usually with a substance like glue
dictionaryExamples: Stick the tape on the back of the picture.
My car's stuck in the mud.
The cupcakes stuck to the pan.
It was so hot that my clothes stuck to me.
My book got wet and now the pages are stuck together.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Then I am going to buy those glow-in-the-dark stars to stick on the ceiling, so that at night, I can see stars. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: If something sharp sticks into something, it goes into it, and if you stick something sharp somewhere, you push it into something.
dictionaryExamples: The nurse stuck the needle into his arm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The body of his boss's wife lay on the ground, a knife stuck in her heart. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to continue to support someone when they are having problems
dictionaryExamples: I'll stick by you whatever happens.
She was determined to stick by her family.

sense.def: to go past the surface or edge of something
dictionaryExamples: Ryan's ears stick out a little, don't they!
There was a handkerchief sticking out of his jacket pocket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The seat was damaged and something was sticking out. Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Czech

sense.def: to limit yourself to doing or using one particular thing and not change to anything else
dictionaryExamples: Could you stick to the point, please?
Stick to the trail - you don't want to get lost.
I have trouble sticking to a budget.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll stick to baggy t-shirts, jeans, baseball caps and [sneak]ers. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: If people stick together, they support and help each other.
dictionaryExamples: If we all stick together, we can succeed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Who would ever have thoug[h]t that the little school band from the good old days would get so far? It must be at least 20 years since we left school, and I haven't seen any of the good old school mates for more than 10 [years], but they must have stuck together. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to support someone or something when they are being criticized
dictionaryExamples: I feel I have to stick up for him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two brothers Lev and Dmitri used to stick up for each other at school and could never be beaten at any physical sport because they were extremely strong. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to continue doing something or using someone to do work for you, and not stopping or changing to something or someone else
dictionaryExamples: He said that he was going to stick with the traditions established by his grandfather.
He's a good car mechanic - I think we should stick with him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [O]n Monday [the] 13 and Wednesday [the] 14 of March, we still stick with your plan. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: a long, thin piece of wood, usually broken or fallen from a tree
dictionaryExamples: The campers collected sticks to start a fire.
Don't wave that stick around - you could hurt someone!
The lawn was littered with sticks and leaves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when we ran into a quiet street, he stopped and hit me with a stick. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: a long, thin piece of wood that you use when you are walking/playing hockey, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She uses a walking stick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very sad, because I have lost my hockey stick and it was very special to me; a very famous player [gave] it to me as a present. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: made of or covered with a substance that can stick to other things
dictionaryExamples: This tape is really sticky.
You need to wash those sticky hands.
The floor's still sticky where I spilled the juice.
Do you have any of those yellow sticky notes?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [On] the wedding day, everyone ha[s] a chance to eat special food: sticky rice cakes, spring rolls and a lot [of other dishes]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: hard and difficult to bend
dictionaryExamples: I need a stiff piece of cardboard.
He had on stiff leather shoes.
If the dough is stiff, add more sour cream.

sense.def: not easy to move
dictionaryExamples: a stiff neck
The hinges on this door are really stiff.
My knee feels stiff this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She tried to sit up straight and quickly reali[z]ed all her mus[c]les were stiff from non-activity. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: behaving in a way that is formal and not relaxed
dictionaryExamples: He was always very stiff with us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In spite of his often stiff attitude, Mr. Stevens' very detailed description of their contact in the past and his eagerness to visit Miss Kenton in 1956 show that he does have strong feelings for her, even though he still hides this behind the eternal argument of "a need for contact of a purely professional character." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a strong alcoholic drink
dictionaryExamples: I thought he could use a stiff drink after that car almost hit him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, she prepared herself a stiff drink: gin and tonic with some ice, the very same one she used to have when Jack was there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: very severe or difficult
dictionaryExamples: stiff competition/opposition
We need stiffer penalties for drunk driving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, these budget airlines have given stiff competition to bigger airlines by reducing airfares. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: extremely bored/scared/worried, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I pretended to listen, but I was bored stiff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Squeaky noises coming out from the deep corners of my house frightened me. I [was] scared stiff. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to say that something is continuing to happen now or that someone is continuing to do something now
dictionaryExamples: I'm still hungry.
I still haven't finished my essay.
I still have a scar on my knee from that fall two years ago.
Do you still work for the post office?
There's still time for us to get to the theater before the movie starts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, I think my bag [is] still in my room. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: despite that
dictionaryExamples: You may not approve of what he did, but he's still your brother.
He was diagnosed with cancer but still returned to work.
She doesn't really have the time, but she still offered to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was sure that it was not in my house but I still wanted to check. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: even better
dictionaryExamples: Give her a call, or better still go see her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To my mind, the best place to do the painting is my bedroom, because you'll have plenty of space to work,  and, better still, we won't bother anybody. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not moving
dictionaryExamples: Children find it difficult to sit/stand/stay still for very long.
I can't brush your hair if you don't hold still.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to have my dog painted, too, but I'm afraid that'll be impossible because it won't stay still! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: Still water or air does not have waves or wind.
dictionaryExamples: She dived into the still  water of the lake.
The air was so still  that not even the leaves on the trees were moving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the foot of the monastery's ruins was a pool, wide and still, and smooth in the sunlight, surrounded by flowers and tall trees, wonderfully bloomed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to encourage something to grow, develop or become active
dictionaryExamples: The government plans to cut taxes in order to stimulate the economy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This would hopefully stimulate the opening of several outdoor cafés downtown that we need as alternative meeting points for adults and youngsters. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to make someone excited and interested about something
dictionaryExamples: The film was intended to stimulate and entertain.
Good teachers should ask questions that stimulate students to think.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really enjoy watching [the] movies which are provided in your theat[e]r because all [the] movies that I have seen are thought-provoking enough to stimulate our interest. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: something that makes something else happen, grow, or develop more
dictionaryExamples: The report provided the stimulus for more studies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nicole saw these events as the pursuit of excellence, I tend to agree with her and find them advantageous because they can serve as a goal and as a motivational stimulus for many athletes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to mix food or liquid by moving a spoon around and around in it
dictionaryExamples: Stir the sauce gently until it begins to boil.
Stir the egg yolks into the warm milk.
She paused to stir some sugar into her coffee.
Slowly add the flour, stirring until completely blended.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then you add the instant sauce and stir.  First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: to move slightly or make someone move slightly
dictionaryExamples: The baby stirred in its sleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is no wind, not a lea[f] is stirring. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to make someone feel a strong emotion
dictionaryExamples: The case has stirred great anger among the public.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Clearly, that was what I found so intriguing about the event: that mesmerizing state of being united in awe - not being able to grasp fully the rationale behind the unpredictable turns history takes but feeling one's emotions stirred and expressing this frankly. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

blocks.phrasalVerb: stir up sth or stir sth up

sense.def: to cause arguments or bad feeling between people, usually on purpose
dictionaryExamples: I think he just likes to stir up trouble.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had a rough childhood and was constantly stirring up trouble. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a short line of thread that is sewn through a piece of material
dictionaryExamples: The stitches around the collar are coming undone.

sense.def: one of the small pieces of thread that is used to sew together a cut
dictionaryExamples: She needed 15 stitches in her head.

sense.def: the goods that are available in a store
dictionaryExamples: This store sells its old stock at a discount.
We'll be getting our new stock in on Friday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In [the] fashion industry, [a] sale begins at the end of each season and just lasts a short time, because those [shop] owners want to make room for new stock. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: available/not available in a shop
dictionaryExamples: The book is out of stock at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And sometimes the item you are looking for is out of stock. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to think carefully about a situation before making a decision
dictionaryExamples: We need to pause and take stock of what still needs to be done.

sense.def: to have something available for people to buy
dictionaryExamples: We stock a good range of spices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, unless you are quite wealthy, you can [only] buy what is in the shops and these tend to stock only what is in fashion, so it is hard not to be 'in'. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a very thin piece of clothing that covers a woman's foot and leg
dictionaryExamples: a pair of stockings
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Try to avoid miniskirts, fishnet stockings and sexy outfits in general, we are "mountain people" and are not very keen on this kind of fashion! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: the place where stocks and shares in companies are bought and sold
dictionaryExamples: Stock markets around the world are reacting to news of the US president's announcement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The second unlucky job was office workers whose business was related [to] the stock market in Korea. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: the organ inside your body where food goes after it has been eaten and where it starts to be digested
dictionaryExamples: He has an upset stomach.
The doctor asked him to lie down on his stomach.
The sight of blood turns my stomach.
She has stomach problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because I'm going to see a doctor [about] my stomach, I'll miss the class tomorrow. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: likely to vomit
dictionaryExamples: I feel sick to my stomach.

sense.def: pain in your stomach
dictionaryExamples: I've got terrible stomachache.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left because I have [to see] a doctor.  It's important because I have a stomachache. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a hard, natural substance that is found in the ground
dictionaryExamples: a stone wall/floor
a stone stairway
They cut enormous blocks of stone out of the hillside.
The kids were throwing stones at a wooden box.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are houses made of stone and wood. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a hard, valuable substance that is often used in jewelry
dictionaryExamples: precious stones
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know, that gold ring, with a little precious stone in the cent[e]r, meant a lot to me, because it belonged to my older sister, Giulia. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a very short distance
dictionaryExamples: The house is just a stone's throw from the beach.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whatever you want it is a stone's throw from your home. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to do everything that you can in order to achieve something or to find someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Both sides have vowed to leave no stone unturned in the search for peace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has left no stone unturned so as to reach her [goal], always asserting her assets and views with conviction. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a seat that does not have a back or arms
dictionaryExamples: a bar/kitchen/piano stool
a three-legged stool
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite being provided with a machine which gives out hot and cold drinks, the cafeteria does not contain any table, stool or chair. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to not continue doing something that you were doing
dictionaryExamples: Once I start eating chocolate, I can't stop.
Stop shouting - you're giving me a headache!
I couldn't stop laughing.
Stop it!/Stop that!
When will it stop snowing?
Fortunately, police stopped the fight before anyone got hurt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Once you have started, you will not want to stop. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: If a bus, train, etc. stops at a particular place, it pauses at that place so that people can get on and off.
dictionaryExamples: Does this bus stop at Thirty-fourth Street?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The train stopped at the station. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to stop a trip or an activity for a short time
dictionaryExamples: He stopped at a coffee shop for lunch.
Why don't you just stop somewhere and ask for directions?
I stopped to pick up a letter that I'd dropped.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We went cycling north, following the coast from a road and about four hours later we stopped at a beautiful beach, where we had a lot of fun. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to prevent someone from doing something or something from happening
dictionaryExamples: Something must be done to stop the fighting.
If she really wants to leave, I don't understand what's stopping her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went and beat one of the guys to stop the fighting, however, the fighting didn't stop. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to not move any more or to make someone or something not move any more
dictionaryExamples: Stop the car, I want to get out!
I heard him shout, "Stop right now!"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were disap[p]ointed because we wanted to walk more and were ready to go home, but Sasha said: "Stop!" Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: to not continue to operate, or to make something not continue to operate
dictionaryExamples: My watch stopped.
Can you stop the video for a minute?
The air conditioner stopped working.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: If I am driving my car and suddenly the engine stops working, I can call, from my cell [phone], and ask for help. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be willing to do anything in order to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: He will stop at nothing to get what he wants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They stopped at nothing to get the higher scores, to make themselves noticed, even if that meant telling some lies to a teacher about a schoolmate. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to almost do something but decide not to do it
dictionaryExamples: She stopped short of accusing him of lying.

sense.def: to stop somewhere for a short period of time when you are on a long journey
dictionaryExamples: We stopped over in Los Angeles for two nights on the way to New Zealand.

sense.def: a place where vehicles, especially buses, stop in order to allow passengers to get off and on
dictionaryExamples: a bus stop
I'm getting off at the next stop.
Is this our stop?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] bus stop is near the market. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: when you stop an activity or trip, or a period of time when you stop
dictionaryExamples: Please remain in your seat until the plane comes to a complete stop.
We'd have been here sooner, but we made a few stops along the way.
At the beginning of the project there were a lot of stops and starts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best part was (without a doubt) when I made a little stop in a small town... I f[e]ll in love with that town! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to end something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: We must put a stop to the violence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe these new activities (video - video games), which are quite distracti[ng], are at the same time so addictive that youngsters find it hard to put a stop to it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: a short stop between parts of a trip
dictionaryExamples: The plane tickets include a two-night stopover in Singapore.
The tour included a stopover in Pisa on the way to Florence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We both thought that it was a good idea to have that stop-over at your place as it was on our route to Norway anyhow. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: when you put things in a safe place until they are needed
dictionaryExamples: We've had to build some cabinets to give us more storage space.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We would prefer a youth hostel or something similar.  For us it is a better option because we will have a lot of equipment with us and staying in a campsite would not offer very much storage space. First Certificate in English; B2; Romanian

sense.def: a building or part of a building where you can buy things
dictionaryExamples: a shoe/jewelry/hardware/electronics store
grocery/convenience/department stores
Are you going to the store?
I'll stop at the store and pick up tissues on my way home.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Yesterday I went to a store, and I bought some new clothes. 
 Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: going to happen soon
dictionaryExamples: You never know what's in store for you.
There's a bit of a shock in store for him when he gets home tonight!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nobody knows what the future will have in store! Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; German

sense.def: to put or keep things in a special place for use in the future
dictionaryExamples: I stored my things at my mother's house while I was away.
We store the garden tools in a shed in the backyard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we can just go to the fridge where all the fresh food is stored ready to eat. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to keep information on a computer
dictionaryExamples: The data is stored on a hard disk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, using [a] computer is important for me because I can store my personal records such as [my] diary or expenses. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to remember things, usually so that you can tell people about them later
dictionaryExamples: I've been listening to their conversations and storing it all up for future use.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although I like people I often make fun of them or tell one of the many jokes stored up in my hopelessly overloade[d] brain. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to keep something and not use it, so that it can be used in the future
dictionaryExamples: She had stored up some nuts to use in the cake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We become energetic and we can store up this energy for those times in which we're bound to a more tight or compulsory timetable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: very bad weather with a lot of rain, snow, wind, etc.
dictionaryExamples: A lot of trees were blown down in the recent storms.
They're still clearing up the storm damage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One day I was playing [on the] computer and my mother told me to turn it off because a storm was coming. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If it is stormy, the weather is bad with a lot of wind and rain.
dictionaryExamples: a stormy night
stormy seas
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a cold and stormy night. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: A stormy relationship or situation involves a lot of anger and arguments.
dictionaryExamples: a stormy relationship
a stormy meeting/debate
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I ha[d] not expected that you w[ould] contact me again (especially after our stormy discussion a month ago). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a description of a series of real or imaginary events that is intended to entertain people
dictionaryExamples: Will you read/tell me a story, daddy?
Martha asked me to read to her from her favorite book of bedtime stories.
He writes children's stories.
I don't know if it's true but it's a good story.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell an English book called "Cats and Dogs". There [are] lots of different and funny stories in it. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: a level of a building
dictionaryExamples: a three-story house
She lived on the third floor of a seven-story building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a one-story building in [the] Russian style with one, rather small, room with a bar and 10 tables. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a report in a newspaper or on a news broadcast of something that has happened
dictionaryExamples: The main story in the papers today is the president's speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If someone famous goes to a pub, he should be careful what he drinks, because he could find an interesting story about his alcoholism in [the] newspapers tomorrow. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

blocks.phrase: to make a long story short

sense.def: to mention only the final result or point of something without going into other details
dictionaryExamples: To make a long story short, he never played baseball again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To make a long story short, my mother turned out to be an understanding person. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: an explanation of why something happened, which may not be true
dictionaryExamples: Did he tell you the same story about why he was late?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Susan repeated the same story three or four times: Jason had come from work at 5 o'clock and she had gone to the grocer's to get some potatoes for dinner. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a large box-shaped device which is used to cook and heat food either by putting the food inside or by putting it on the top
dictionaryExamples: a gas/electric stove
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fridge, the television, the stove and the Hi-Fi equipment will be attached to a computer network. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: not curved or bent
dictionaryExamples: a straight line
She has straight hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has straight [blond] hair and blue eyes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: honest
dictionaryExamples: a straight answer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I'm asking you to give us a reasonable and straight reply. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: in a position that is level or vertical
dictionaryExamples: That shelf's not straight.

sense.def: to make sure that you completely understand a situation
dictionaryExamples: Let me get this straight - am I paying for this?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Next time you should try to get your facts straight. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to manage to stop yourself from smiling or laughing
dictionaryExamples: I can never play jokes on people because I can't keep a straight face.

sense.def: in a straight line
dictionaryExamples: Go straight, then turn left at the traffic light.
He was looking straight at me.
The library is straight ahead.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: From my house we must go straight, then we must take second turn to the left. 
 Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: without pausing or delaying
dictionaryExamples: I got home and went straight to bed.
Do you want to go straight to the party or stop for a bite to eat first?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I came back home at 11:30, I went straight to bed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to sit or stand with your body vertical
dictionaryExamples: Stand up straight and put your shoulders back!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She tried to sit up straight and quickly reali[z]ed all her mus[c]les were stiff from non-activity. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If you cannot think straight, you are not thinking clearly about something.
dictionaryExamples: I was so tired, I couldn't think straight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My stress wouldn't let me think straight. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: easy to do or understand
dictionaryExamples: The doctor gave a straightforward explanation of the operation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The question of w[h]ether we should keep animals in zoos is not as straightforward as it may seem at first. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: pressure put on something by a bad situation or by too much weight or force
dictionaryExamples: All those books put a strain on the shelf and it broke!
Excess weight puts a lot of strain on the heart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I certainly could live without watching television for a week, but it would put a tremendous strain on my everyday life because I find watching TV relaxing and I like being swept by the flood of information that you watch and listen to without really paying attention to it. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when you feel nervous and worried about something
dictionaryExamples: She's a lot better than she was but she's still not ready to face the stresses and strains of a job.
He's been under a lot of strain recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [Our dog] helps us in our everyday life and [relieves the] stresses and strains. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: an injury to part of your body that is caused by using it too much
dictionaryExamples: back strain

sense.def: to injure part of your body by using it too much
dictionaryExamples: I think I've strained a muscle.
Don't read in the dark or you'll strain your eyes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I went to the optician's to have my eyes checked and he said I had some trouble with my eyesight, so he advised me to wear glasses and not to strain my eyes. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to cause too much of something to be used, especially money
dictionaryExamples: The war is straining the defense budget.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It sounded very good, but I soon discovered that the service was quite inadequate and all the staff there had to say was that they couldn't do any more and that the budget was too strained. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a thin piece of hair, thread, rope, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She tucked a strand of hair behind her ear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She noticed a loose strand of white hair, and immediat[e]ly pinned it back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: one part of a story, situation, idea, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There are a number of different strands to the plot.

sense.def: unable to leave a place
dictionaryExamples: We were stranded at the airport for ten hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not a single member of the group would have imagined that the "Luxury coach" would break [down] and leave them stranded in the middle of nowhere, and what was worse without mobile network coverage. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If something is strange, it is surprising because it is unusual or unexpected.
dictionaryExamples: You say the strangest things sometimes.
I had a strange feeling that we had met before.
We kept hearing strange noises coming from the attic.
It's strange that tourists almost never visit this village.
That's strange - I'm sure I put my glasses in my bag and yet they're not there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rebecca's present was very strange, she g[ave] me a cat. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: A strange person or place is one that you are not familiar with.
dictionaryExamples: I really don’t like strange people coming to my door.
I've never been here before either, so it's all strange to me too.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She doesn't like a big city and strange people. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: in a way that is unusual, unexpected or difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: She was strangely calm.
Strangely enough, I'm not feeling very hungry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Strangely enough this has not happened yet to zoos. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: someone you have never met before
dictionaryExamples: Mom always warned us to never talk to strangers.
I can't just walk up to complete strangers and start talking to them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I opened the door when I had heard the bell ringing.  I saw a stranger standing in front of me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: a narrow piece of material used to fasten two things together or to carry something
dictionaryExamples: a watch strap
a bra strap
I want a bag with a shoulder strap.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When Cathy un[w]rapped the small parcel she found a little red book which had a slim strap with a tiny golden lock. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: helping to achieve a plan, usually in business, politics, or war
dictionaryExamples: strategic planning
strategic   weapons
The new offices are in a strategic location, with easy access to the highway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This would prove to be a strategic advantage, given the relatively reduced financial power our company has currently. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: in a strategic way
dictionaryExamples: A few strategically placed police officers monitored the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Large containers strategically situated along the village seem an appropriate solution. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Basque

sense.def: a plan that you use to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: the administration's economic strategy
a long-term strategy
Chess is a game that requires strategy.
We're working on new strategies to improve our share of the market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My strategy was simple: all the players had [a] lot [of] experience, [so] I thought that the only chance to win [wa]s to bluff it out. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the long, dried stems of plants such as wheat, often given to animals for sleeping on and eating
dictionaryExamples: a straw basket/hat
straw-colored hair
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last but not least, many Japanese style hotels and restaurants now have square holes in tatami (straw mat) rooms so that foreign visitors can comfortably stretch their legs under the low table without having to be seated on folded legs like Zen monks! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: the last in a series of unpleasant events which finally makes you stop accepting a bad situation
dictionaryExamples: The last straw was when the company fired most of the managers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The last straw was that as a result of the unreali[z]ed itinerary, I couldn't do what I had planned. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a thin plastic or paper tube that you use for drinking through
dictionaryExamples: Could I have a straw, please?

sense.def: a small, red fruit with a green leaf at the top and small, brown seeds on its surface
dictionaryExamples: I picked some fresh strawberries today - would you like some?
strawberry jam/ice cream
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first we drank something - it was a special drink with strawberries. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a small river
dictionaryExamples: a mountain stream
underground streams
A little stream flows through their garden.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On our way I saw small streams, small [areas of] jungle and beautiful animals also. Preliminary English Test; B1; Singhalese

sense.def: a continuous flow of things or people
dictionaryExamples: There has been a steady stream of phone calls from worried customers.
An endless stream of traffic clogged the roads today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This teahouse is packed throughout [the] day with workers and retired people, who come to sip tea, talk, and watch the endless stream of passers-by in the old city of China. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a road in a town or city that has houses or other buildings
dictionaryExamples: a street map
Our daughter lives just across the street from us.
He was walking down the street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My street is quiet and friendly. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used in the name of a street as part of an address
dictionaryExamples: 142 Ross Street

Diane's house is 
                      in Cherrywood Street.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I live in a flat, number 66 New George Street. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Kurdish

sense.def: the ability to do things that need a lot of physical effort or power
dictionaryExamples: upper body strength
It's a sport that requires great physical strength.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, we must start [by] running [for] thirty minutes per day to improve our physical strength. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a good quality or ability that makes someone or something effective
dictionaryExamples: We all have our strengths and weaknesses.
The great strength of this arrangement is its simplicity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As everything, education in Spain has its strengths and weaknesses. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: when you are brave or determined in difficult situations
dictionaryExamples: I think she showed great strength of character.
He has a great deal of inner strength.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All in all, being famous takes a lot of courage and strength of personality to be able to face fame and all the risks that come along [with it]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: the power or influence that an organization, country, etc. has
dictionaryExamples: economic strength
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to the very function of sport[s], a countr[y']s success in international competition has been asso[c]iated with its general strength and viability and [has] consequently been a matter of national pride. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to become stronger or make something become stronger
dictionaryExamples: exercises to strengthen the leg muscles
If something isn’t done to strengthen the railroad bridge, it may collapse.
As she continued to speak her voice strengthened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Using the bike keeps your body in good shape -  the daily exercise is good for your heart [and] your lungs, and strengthen[s]  your muscles. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: using or needing a lot of effort
dictionaryExamples: strenuous exercise
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With the ever-growing influence of modern techni[ques], it has become increasingly important to strive for near perfection in every move they make; the pursuit of excellence therefore carrying more weight than ever and leading to strenuous training programs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: feelings of worry caused by difficult situations such as problems at work
dictionaryExamples: People under a lot of stress may experience headaches, minor pains and sleeping difficulties.
Yoga is a very effective technique for dealing with stress.
the stresses and strains of work
stress-related illness
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think you are all ac[cu]st[o]med to city things, and all of them bring us stress, so I think you should go to the countryside, where you will find peace and so you'll relax. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: when you say one part of a word more strongly than the rest
dictionaryExamples: The meaning of a sentence often depends on stress and intonation.
When "insert" is a verb, the stress is on the second syllable, but when it is a noun, the stress is on the first syllable.

sense.def: special importance that you give to something
dictionaryExamples: At school, they laid/put/placed great stress on academic achievement.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, I think they should put some more stress on improving their student's writing skills, even down to basics like grammar, because our sales people have to hand out a lot of written information as well, which will make us look much better - especially as far as the English-speaking market is concerned - if the English is flawless. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to emphasize something in order to show that it is important
dictionaryExamples: I stressed that this was our policy.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to stress that very often famous people become reserved, bad-tempered and angry with the world for interfering [with] their lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to say one part of a word more strongly than the rest
dictionaryExamples: In the word "engine," you should stress the first syllable.

sense.def: worried and not able to relax
dictionaryExamples: She just started a new job and is feeling pretty stressed.
I was really stressed out before the exam.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was a little bit stressed when I woke up in the morning. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: making you feel worried and not able to relax
dictionaryExamples: a stressful day/job

She's very good at coping with stressful situations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is good to go there after [a] stressful day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: to become longer or wider, or to pull something so that it becomes longer or wider
dictionaryExamples: Don't pull my sweater - you'll stretch it.

sense.def: to make your body or part of your body straighter and longer
dictionaryExamples: "I'm so tired," he said, yawning and stretching his arms.
Paul always stretches before and after exercising.
Stretch your arms above your head.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all cycling is a sport so you have the possibility to move your body, to stretch your joints and to strengthen your muscles. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to cover a large area
dictionaryExamples: The fields stretched away into the distance.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I remember playing in the fields that stretched out to the horizon and sailing and swimming in the streams and lakes surrounding the small village where my parents live. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a continuous area of land or water
dictionaryExamples: This particular stretch of coast is especially popular with walkers.
Traffic is at a standstill along a five-mile stretch of the I95  just south of Stamford.
Some very rare birds inhabit this stretch of the river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's a stretch of coastline in the South East of Spain that one could still call "real Spain" not many years ago. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: A strict person makes sure that children or people working for them behave well and does not allow them to break any rules.
dictionaryExamples: a strict teacher

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teacher was strict but nice.  Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: If a rule, law, etc. is strict, it must be obeyed.
dictionaryExamples: She gave me strict instructions to be there by ten.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like the government to impose strict rules and regulations on capturing animals. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: always behaving in a particular way because of your beliefs
dictionaryExamples: She's a strict vegetarian, so she doesn't eat poultry or fish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When organi[z]ing our lunch, please note that seven of us are strict vegetarians. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: exactly correct
dictionaryExamples: a strict translation of a text
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You mustn't take this in its strict sense; when I say "severe," I mean aware and mindful of today's problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: exactly or correctly
dictionaryExamples: That's not strictly true.

Strictly 
 speaking, we're not allowed to give you any advice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Strictly speaking, we don't think about the future when the subject is nature because we think that it's eternal. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to emphasize that something is not allowed
dictionaryExamples: The use of cameras is strictly forbidden.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Eric was going to [have] serious problems, because smoking was strictly forbidden in this school. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to hit someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Two climbers were struck by falling rocks.
