I don't know anyone who was struck by lightning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only seconds later, the tree was struck by lightning. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: If a thought or idea strikes you, you suddenly think of it.
dictionaryExamples: It struck me that I had forgotten to order the champagne.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sitting there, waiting, I began to think and an idea struck m[e]. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

blocks.phrase: what strikes me or the thing that strikes me...

sense.def: used when talking about a very obvious quality that you noticed when you first saw or met someone or something
dictionaryExamples: What strikes me about Cole is how grown-up he seems for a seven-year-old.
The thing that struck me about Emma was her extraordinary beauty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What strikes me most is the way she is dealing with other people. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to stop working for a period of time because you want more money, better working conditions, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Flight attendants are threatening to strike to get more flexible schedules.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The town['s] transport workers have started to strike." First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to give two things the same amount of attention
dictionaryExamples: It's important to strike a balance between spending and saving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything has good and bad sides, the most important thing is to strike a balance. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: If someone or something strikes you as having a particular quality, they seem to have that quality.
dictionaryExamples: He didn't strike me as a passionate man.
They strike me as creative and original people.
His comments struck me as aggressive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mrs. Kingshaw strikes me as a rather frivolous woman. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to find a supply of gold, oil, etc. in the ground
dictionaryExamples: They hope to strike oil in the desert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their very own father had struck oil, made tons of money with it and did not even want to give some to his children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to light a match in order to produce fire
dictionaryExamples: I struck a match and lit the candle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their instant reaction was to park the car, put their raincoats on, get out and strike a few useless matches: they were their last light resour[c]e apart from the lightning in the sky and the weak [head]lights. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If something bad strikes something or someone, it affects them strongly and quickly.
dictionaryExamples: The hurricane struck the coast at about eight in the morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And there had been the blight w[hic]h struck half of the plantation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a period of time when people are not working because they want more money, better working conditions, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The city's bus drivers have been on strike for three weeks.
a teachers' strike
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed, the bus company has plan[n]ed a strike. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: someone who is on strike
dictionaryExamples: Managers have threatened to fire the strikers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were also people who agreed with the strikers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: easily noticed
dictionaryExamples: There are striking similarities between the two cases.
There's a striking resemblance between the cousins.
He's very striking, with a full beard and flowing, collar-length hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most striking thing was the fact that I filed it. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: very thin rope used for tying things
dictionaryExamples: a bundle tied with string
a piece of string
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: [W]e used to have oil lamps, which used a cotton string dipping in the oil in [a] small bottle, and [we] burned the tip of the cotton string to give us light during the night time, it was very little light, and many things we couldn't do under the oil lamps because the light range was very small. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a piece of wire or cord that is part of a musical instrument and that produces musical notes when played
dictionaryExamples: guitar/violin strings
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had been playing six numbers already when it happened: my bottom E string broke in the middle of my solo. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a number of similar things
dictionaryExamples: a string of questions
As a writer, she's enjoyed a string of successes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cities have grown, bringing with this growth a string of problems which were not thought of years ago. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Haitian Creole

sense.def: to secretly use the influence that you have over important people to get something or to help someone
dictionaryExamples: I may be able to pull a few strings, if you need the money urgently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This isn't secret: I thought some of these ideas might be of interest and perhaps an article about them [i]n your newspaper would pull the necessary strings at the City Hall to produce some very much needed changes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If there are no strings attached to an offer or arrangement, there is nothing that is unpleasant that you have to accept.
dictionaryExamples: I'll drive you home - no strings attached.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is not that often that one comes across true "no strings attached" generosity. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a long, narrow piece of something
dictionaryExamples: a strip of paper
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that workers had to use the most basic tools and [their] hands to produce socks from the strips of silk. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: a long, straight area of color
dictionaryExamples: The zebra is a wild African horse with black and white stripes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like clothes with stripes, because I think that's a little old-fashioned. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: to try very hard to do or achieve something
dictionaryExamples: to strive for happiness/peace
We are constantly striving to improve our service.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The credit belongs to the man who is actually in the arena, who strives valiantly, [...] who, at best, knows the joys of high achievement, and who, at worst, if [he] fails, at least fails while daring greatly. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a sudden problem in your brain that changes the flow of blood and makes you unable to move part of your body
dictionaryExamples: She suffered/had a stroke that left her unable to speak.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure there's a high risk [of] a heart at[t]ack or a stroke if you go on the way you [are going] now. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: a style of swimming
dictionaryExamples: What stroke do you prefer?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although both may know how to swim, the professional, who was trained in proper strokes and hydrodynamic[s], will definitely turn out the better swimmer. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: something good that happens to you by chance
dictionaryExamples: He had exactly the part that I needed so that was a stroke of luck.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a one-hour interview she was asked whether she could start work the very next day. A real stroke of luck. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a movement that you make against something with your hand, a pen, brush, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a brush stroke
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The power of the brush strokes and the intense energy in the image made me sigh with adoration. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to gently move your hand over a surface
dictionaryExamples: Stroke the dog if you like, it won't bite.
He stroked his son's hair.
She stroked her chin and shut her eyes before answering.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And do not forget to stroke your cat! First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: A strong person or animal is physically powerful.
dictionaryExamples: strong arms/legs
Are you strong enough to lift this table by yourself?
She must be very strong to carry that much weight in her backpack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this game because the story is very good end the p[rotagon]ist is so strong! Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: A strong object does not break or get damaged easily.
dictionaryExamples: a strong box/chair
The table is made with very strong glass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In winter I wear big jackets, gloves, warm trousers and strong boots. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: very noticeable or powerful
dictionaryExamples: strong  coffee
There's a strong smell of gas!
I can give you a stronger pain-killing medication if you need it.
It's surprising what strong memories a photograph can produce.
He bears a strong resemblance to his brother.
My grandmother had a strong influence on me.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: We took a lot of food and water, because of the weather which was very hot, with a strong sun. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: produced using a lot of power
dictionaryExamples: a strong kick/blow
Her voice was clear and strong.
Strong winds are forecast in the area for the next few days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unluck[i]ly, the rest of the days were cloudy and with strong winds. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: Strong relationships last for a long time, and are not easily spoiled.
dictionaryExamples: strong relationships
We have very strong family ties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Actually, now our relationship is very strong. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: of a good quality or level and likely to be successful or effective
dictionaryExamples: a strong economy
They're a very strong team.
She's the strongest candidate we've interviewed for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My reason for applying for this trip is that I am very interested in meeting people from different countries and as I have a strong background in languages I would be very helpful in the communication field. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: A strong feeling, belief, or opinion is felt in a very deep and serious way.
dictionaryExamples: She has strong opinions/views.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays the importance of family life is a matter which arouses fierce[ly] strong passions. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: If a person or their personality is strong, they are confident and able to deal with problems well.
dictionaryExamples: All my aunts are strong women.
He has a strong personality, but don't let him frighten you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mary was a strong and intelligent woman. She was stronger and her personality was more developed than her aunt['s]. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: words that some people might consider to be offensive
dictionaryExamples: The movie contains strong language.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But what I do see is local kids standing [on] the corner, chat[t]ing, smoking and using strong language. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Slovak

sense.def: something that someone is very good at
dictionaryExamples: Cooking is not my strong point.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She's got a lot of strong points, more than weaknesses. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: something that is very likely to happen
dictionaryExamples: There's a strong possibility of rain this afternoon.

sense.def: a lot of opposition/support, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There has been strong opposition to the cuts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, in spite of strong opposition [by] the car companies and people's egoistic interests, car traffic should be gradually redu[c]ed and eventually prohibited. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: continuing to be successful or healthy after a long time
dictionaryExamples: The club was set up in 1987, and it's still going strong.
He's 93 and still going strong!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am proud of him and happy that he is still going strong. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Finnish

sense.def: very much or in a very serious way
dictionaryExamples: They strongly believe their children should make choices for themselves.
Many locals are strongly opposed to the development.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I strongly disagree with the statement saying that "At school, students should only study what they enjoy". First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: relating to the structure of something
dictionaryExamples: structural damage
The last five years have seen big structural changes in the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, Hong Kong has been undergoing various structural changes and economic issues since the financial turmoil in 1998. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: the way that parts of something are arranged or put together
dictionaryExamples: the grammatical structure of a sentence
They have a very old-fashioned management structure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, as far as the Greek language is concerned, I think it would be very hard for you and for everybody to learn it because of its difficult and very complicated grammar, vocabulary and structure. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a building or something that has been built
dictionaryExamples: The house was a wooden structure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, for most foreign visitors to Japan I think it is a wonderful experience to go to Nara city and see the world's oldest and biggest wooden structure, or to see traditional Noh dance and Kabuki play. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to arrange something in an organized way
dictionaryExamples: How is the course structured?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since women in the Western countries started working in the 70s, there has been a big change in the way our family life is structured. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: organized so that the parts relate well to each other
dictionaryExamples: a structured series of lectures
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The exchange of political or economic ideas, as well as new tec[h]nology, can provide the basis for a structured development of which could emerge a just and truly happy society. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to try very hard to do something difficult
dictionaryExamples: He's been struggling to pay off his debts.
Fish struggle for survival when the water level drops in the lake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Think about the people in the poor countries!  They struggle to survive. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to fight someone when they are holding you
dictionaryExamples: He struggled with the stranger who had suddenly grabbed his arm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I bit his hand and ran to the phone. He reached me and we struggled for 10 minutes. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to use a lot of effort to defeat someone or prevent something
dictionaryExamples: For years she struggled with/against the establishment to get her theories accepted.
He is struggling with an ankle injury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just like Mahatma Gandhi, who advocated non-violent methods of struggle, Picasso struggled against Fascism [by] peaceful means, namely with his art. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: when you try very hard to do something difficult
dictionaryExamples: It was a real struggle to stay awake during the movie
The Revolutionary War was a struggle for independence.
Central banks everywhere are still fighting the struggle against inflation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their life was a severe financial struggle, and Tom's dream was to run somewhere far away. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a physical or mental fight
dictionaryExamples: a struggle with cancer
the struggle between good and evil
Clearly there will be a power struggle within the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend started to walk into the water when suddenly a crocodile grabbed her leg. After a long struggle, she managed to get herself up on land. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: determined not to change your ideas, plans, etc., although other people want you to
dictionaryExamples: He can be very stubborn sometimes.
She’s sick, but she’s too stubborn to see a doctor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, Alex was too stubborn to give up and it was like talking to a brick wall. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the quality of being stubborn
dictionaryExamples: We were infuriated by his stubbornness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Henry's words do not fail to show his royal stubbornness, only comparable to that of a mule. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: not able to move anywhere
dictionaryExamples: This door seems to be stuck.
My key got stuck in the lock.
Seven of us were stuck in the elevator for over an hour.
I hate being stuck  behind a desk all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You want to go to your job, to an important appoi[n]tment or to the hospital because you have a health problem and you are always stuck in traffic. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: not able to continue reading, answering questions, etc. because something is too difficult
dictionaryExamples: I keep getting stuck on difficult words.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have got stuck so many times. However, whenever I got stuck, I [said] to myself that nobody could speak a foreign language fluently from the beginning. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to have to deal with someone or something unpleasant because no one else wants to
dictionaryExamples: Whenever we eat out, I always get stuck with the bill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore you are stuck with "aunt Mabel" having fun while pulling your leg.  What you mus[t]n't do in this sort of situation is lose your temper. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a person who is learning at a school or in college
dictionaryExamples: a law student
an undergraduate student
a graduate student
a student teacher
He was a student at the University of Chicago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm a student at a college in Gloucester. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a room where television/radio programs are made or music is recorded
dictionaryExamples: She spent three months in the studio working on her latest album.
a studio audience
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He offered me a contract and asked me to go to his music studio to record a CD. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: a movie company or a place where movies are made
dictionaryExamples: a movie/film studio
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will visit a local film studio. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a room where an artist, designer or photographer works
dictionaryExamples: She has a studio at the back of the house where she does her painting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll be very happy [if] you can give me a chance to use the camp's art studio and [hope] you'll be able to prepare some materials like oil paints, canvas and bru[s]hes for me. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to refer to a substance or a group of things, ideas,  etc., without saying exactly what they are
dictionaryExamples: There's sticky stuff all over the chair.
We'll have to carry all our camping stuff.
This week in class, we're discussing articles about industrial pollution, global warming, and stuff like that.
Do you want help bringing your stuff  in from the van?
I’ve got a lot of stuff to do this weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Talking about acces[s]ories, I like using caps, jewelry, belts, purses and all that stuff. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to know a lot about a subject, or to be very good at doing something
dictionaryExamples: She's an excellent teacher - she really knows her stuff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The thing was that she should have been be able to tell them what to do; she never doubted her own abilities. She knew 	"her stuff" all right. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to push something into a small space, often quickly or in a careless way
dictionaryExamples: He stuffed the papers into his briefcase and left.
This box is absolutely full - I can't stuff another thing into it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A casserole stood on the stove waiting for his arrival and the freeze[r] and fridge were stuffed full with food for the week he would be here. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to step badly and almost fall over
dictionaryExamples: Mary stumbled on the loose rocks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My attic was so dark that I stumbled and fell. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to make a mistake, such as pausing or repeating a word, while speaking or performing
dictionaryExamples: He kept stumbling over the same word.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the new-stars worried so much that she began stumbling over the words in the middle of her hit. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to discover something by chance, or to meet someone by chance
dictionaryExamples: I stumbled across these photographs while I was cleaning out my desk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After months of property website surfing and house-hunting over weekends, we finally stumbled upon this amazing end of terrace house in Lavender Road. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: very surprised and shocked
dictionaryExamples: We were stunned by the news of her death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was stunned and gaped at him with blank horror. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: very beautiful or attractive
dictionaryExamples: a stunning dress
a stunning view
They make a stunning couple.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that it would be ideal for you to go there and take some pictures of it since the architecture is absolutely stunning! First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: silly or not intelligent
dictionaryExamples: I just made a stupid mistake.
Whose stupid idea was it to travel at night?
It was stupid to quit his job like that.
It was a stupid thing to do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The coach] said that we must learn to be like Rambo! But I think that's stupid, because in football you can't be like Rambo. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the state of being unwise or not intelligent
dictionaryExamples: The accident was caused by my own stupidity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most important point however was that I found out that our two countries have similar problems and that prejudices against any country or people are based on stupidity and intolerance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a way of doing something that is typical of a particular person, group, place, or period
dictionaryExamples: a style of painting/writing
Jon has an interesting hands-on style of management.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love Hip Hop music. This style of music is my life. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a way of designing hair, clothes, furniture, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She's had her hair cut in a really nice style.
the latest styles
The classic black dress is always in style.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And they like the same style of clothes as I [do]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: the quality of being attractive and fashionable or behaving in a way which makes people admire you
dictionaryExamples: She's got style.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when he came back, his popularity was increased. That's reasonable, because he's got style, he is authentic and brill[i]ant. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to prevent someone from enjoying themselves, especially by going somewhere with them
dictionaryExamples: Are you sure you don't mind me coming with you? I'd hate to cramp your style.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would never want neither to cramp their style nor to make them feel unimportant, lonely or lost. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: fashionable and attractive
dictionaryExamples: a stylish black suit
The film's direction is subtle and stylish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I pay attention to fashionable and stylish clothes, of course, if they don't seem strange [or] unus[u]al. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: without being consciously aware of something
dictionaryExamples: I think that subconsciously I knew I was in danger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is probably only wishful thinking that most people would wake up every morning wondering how to make the world a better place. In fact, most of us do it subconsciously. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: an area of knowledge which is studied in school or college
dictionaryExamples: My favorite subjects are history and geography.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have several subject[s]: History, English, literature.  It's not the same subject every day. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: the person or thing which performs the action described by the verb
dictionaryExamples: "Bob" is the subject of the sentence "Bob threw the ball."

sense.def: what someone is writing or talking about
dictionaryExamples: Our subject for discussion is homelessness.
She has made a series of documentaries on the subject of family relationships.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She likes swimming and practising yoga. In fact, this was the subject of our first lesson. Preliminary English Test; B1; Romanian

sense.def: to start talking about a different subject
dictionaryExamples: I'd tried to explain the situation, but he just changed the subject.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, changing the subject, I accidentally broke your beautiful vase. I'm really sorry, I'll try to find [another] vase that looks similar. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: often affected by something, especially something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: Departure times are subject to alteration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course these are only suggestions subject to changes and modifications. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: only able to happen if something else happens
dictionaryExamples: The agreement is still subject to approval by the League's 30 teams and the players.

sense.def: a person who is written about in a book or who is shown in a picture
dictionaryExamples: Rembrandt is the subject of her latest novel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No matter wherever we go, enjoy[ing] the beauty of [the] city, walking through the J[ew]ish district, discuss[ing] the subject of [a] painting or just sit[ting] in silence, [the] world is real only with him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to make someone or something experience something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: In prison, he was subjected to beatings and interrogations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Homeless [people] are subjected to a very harsh and unhealt[h]y st[y]le of life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: influenced by someone's beliefs or feelings, instead of facts
dictionaryExamples: a subjective judgment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really love my city and country, but I am afraid I'm a little bit subjective. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Hungarian

sense.def: to send a document, plan, etc. to someone so that they can consider it
dictionaryExamples: Applications must be submitted before January 1st.
Companies are required to submit monthly financial statements to the board.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to my friends and professors, I am hardworking and never fail to submit my essays on [time]. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to accept that someone has control over you and do what they tell you to do
dictionaryExamples: He was forced to submit to a search.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Kingshaw has to submit to the role of victim once more. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: happening after something else
dictionaryExamples: The mistakes were corrected in a subsequent edition of the book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With a rapid economic growth and a subsequent increase in income level, working life in Korea has changed dramatically. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: after that
dictionaryExamples: In 1982 he was arrested and subsequently convicted on drug trafficking charges.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The evaporated water subsequently conden[s]es in the sky and later drop[s] down as rain. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hausa

sense.def: money given by a government or other organization to pay part of the cost of something
dictionaryExamples: housing subsidies for the poor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rest of the money could be spent on subsidies for home owners and tenants and offering lo[an]s with a lower interest rate. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a solid, liquid, or gas
dictionaryExamples: an organic/chemical substance
a dangerous substance
What sort of substance could withstand those temperatures?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Chemical substances are added to our food. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the most important part of what someone has said or written
dictionaryExamples: The substance of his argument is that men are more logical than women.

sense.def: large in amount
dictionaryExamples: a substantial sum of money
The first draft of his novel needed a substantial amount of rewriting.
The findings show a substantial difference between the opinions of men and women.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  The taxis: Considerin[g] that you are willing to spend quite a substantial amount of money, this is the best transport one can get. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to a large degree
dictionaryExamples: The new rules will substantially change how we do things.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The quality of the individual classes differed substantially. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to use someone or something instead of another person or thing
dictionaryExamples: You can substitute oil for butter in this recipe.
Dayton came in to substitute for Williams in the second half.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [M]y opinion is that we shouldn't substitute one for the other, but read one and watch [the] other. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a thing or person that is used instead of another thing or person
dictionaryExamples: Tofu can be used as a meat substitute in vegetarian recipes.
Vitamins should not be used as a substitute for a healthy diet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had been looking forward to seeing his performance for ages, so as soon as I realized there was a substitute on the stage, I was really disappointed. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: when you use someone or something instead of another person or thing
dictionaryExamples: The coach has made two substitutions on the team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The gradual substitution of the old bus fleet with a modern one would be a serious effort, [and] it would demand buckets of money. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: words shown at the bottom of a movie or television screen to explain what is being said
dictionaryExamples: It's a French movie with English subtitles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another way of improving language is to project each film with subtitles. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: not obvious or easy to notice
dictionaryExamples: a subtle change/difference
a subtle hint
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will have to find your own subtle balance between the number of radiators you use and the opening of windows to create a suitable atmosphere. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: A subtle flavor, color, etc. is delicate and not strong or bright.
dictionaryExamples: The garlic has a more subtle flavor than you might imagine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What attracts your attention most are the colors: warm, pleasant to the eye, subtle and somewhat unrealistic. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: clever in a way that does not attract attention
dictionaryExamples: a subtle way of solving the problem
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is indeed a subtle talent, being able to balance between deciding and listening. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: an area near a large city where many people who work in the city live, containing homes and towns or smaller cities
dictionaryExamples: She lives in the Chicago suburbs.
Many people living in this affluent residential suburb work in the city.
Box Hill is a suburb of Melbourne.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Peterhof is only a small suburb of St. Petersburg and it is not famous [for] its nightlife. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a system of trains that travel underground
dictionaryExamples: We can take the subway to Grand Central Station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The conference will take place at the Palace Hotel which can be reached by subway, taxi and bus. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: to achieve what you are trying to achieve
dictionaryExamples: She’s been trying to pass her driving test for months and she finally succeeded.
She succeeded in passing the exam.
You need to be pretty tough to succeed in today's business world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: More will follow in the future: I am sure that finally I will succeed in managing English in an acceptable way! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: when you achieve what you want to achieve
dictionaryExamples: I'm not having any success reaching him by phone.
We’ve tried to contact him, but so far without success.
We are all very proud of the success of of our graduates.
The success rate for this operation is very low.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I searched in the taxi-cab and in the company with no success. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: something that has a good result or that is very popular
dictionaryExamples: The movie is a big/huge box-office success.
She's determined to make a success of her new business.
The dinner party was a great success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And lastly the rest of the space we can use for further information and details about the history of our school and our successes in the past. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: achieving what you want to achieve
dictionaryExamples: a successful operation
My second attempt at making pizza was more successful.
This year's harvest was one of the most successful since the record crop of 1985.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our project was really very successful and we also won a prize. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: having achieved a lot or made a lot of money through your work
dictionaryExamples: a successful artist/author/lawyer/doctor
a successful career
He runs a very successful computer business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to finish by asking Mr. Smith to talk a bit about his life and his successful career. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: very popular
dictionaryExamples: a successful film
He's the author of several wildly/hugely successful children's books.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suppose the facts about your film career, especially about your first film and [your] most successful film would be pretty interesting [as well]. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: in a way that is successful
dictionaryExamples: A number of patients have been successfully treated with the new drug.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you can see, I managed to do the project successfully. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: happening after each other
dictionaryExamples: He has just won the World Championship for the third successive year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their bodies no longer get worn out by successive pregnancies thanks to birth control medicines and techniques. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who has a position or job after someone else
dictionaryExamples: He is her most likely successor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cleopatra f[e]ll in love with him but he was murdered by his nephew and successor Octavio. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: an organization, product, etc. that follows and takes the place of an earlier one
dictionaryExamples: This range of computers is very fast, but their successors will be even faster.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The natural successor of the car was first thought of in the late seventies, but due to lack of computing power for the control systems, the dual mode vehicle was never made. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to not be able to stop yourself from doing something
dictionaryExamples: I succumbed to temptation and had some cheesecake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As days went by, I became more anxious and finally had to succumb to the urge to go to the game. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to die or suffer badly from an illness
dictionaryExamples: Many of them succumbed to cholera.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Could he have succumbed to the cold? or maybe hunger? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to use your tongue and cheek muscles to eat something in your mouth or to pull liquid or air into your mouth
dictionaryExamples: to suck a lollipop
The baby sucked his thumb.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He laughed at me and told me that he poisoned the pages of the diary so he would suck his fingers to turn the pages and die. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: done or happening quickly and unexpectedly
dictionaryExamples: His sudden death came as a shock to everyone.
There was a sudden change of plans.
Her sudden departure took us by surprise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After arriving in Vienna, Martins was really shocked when he got to know about his friend's sudden death. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: suddenly and unexpectedly
dictionaryExamples: All of a sudden we heard a loud knock on the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All of a sudden, a weird creature popped into his dream. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: quickly and unexpectedly
dictionaryExamples: I don't remember much about the accident -  it all happened so suddenly.
I suddenly realized how late it was.
I was just drifting off to sleep when suddenly I heard a crash outside.
Suddenly a dog appeared in front of us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly a car appeared at the end of the street. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to take legal action against someone and try to get money from them because they have harmed you
dictionaryExamples: He's threatening to sue the newspaper for slander.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you do not pay attention to any of my complaints and if I do not hear from you within 15 working days, I will not hesitate to sue you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: someone who suffers from an illness or other health problem
dictionaryExamples: AIDS/cancer sufferers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The body becomes more and more frail and prone to illnesses so that the last ten years of the unnaturally prolonged life [are] spent in pain and agony, with the sufferer quite often acutely aware of his decaying and incapable body. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when someone experiences pain or unpleasant emotions
dictionaryExamples: The war will cause widespread human suffering.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There had been too much suffering for days, months, years. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: as much as is necessary
dictionaryExamples: This recipe should be sufficient for five people.
It was thought that he'd committed the crime but there wasn't sufficient evidence to convict him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To resolve that, try to have a sufficient amount of sleep so that both your body and mind will keep fit. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: as much as is necessary
dictionaryExamples: McGeechan has not recovered sufficiently to play in the semifinal tomorrow.
The case was sufficiently serious to warrant investigation by the police.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for me, I like to think that my situation will be better than those who are not educated sufficiently. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a group of letters that you add to the end of a word to make another word
dictionaryExamples: The suffix "-ness" added to the end of the word "sweet" forms the word "sweetness," changing an adjective into a noun.

sense.def: a sweet substance used to give flavor to food and drinks
dictionaryExamples: I don't take sugar in my coffee, thanks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to eat chicken with bread and tea without sugar. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to express an idea or plan for someone to consider
dictionaryExamples: I suggest that we ask someone for directions, or we’ll never find the place.
Liz suggested (that) I try the shop on Mill Road.
He suggested having the meeting at his house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also suggest you should go to the Alps because there [is] a lot of beautiful scenery and if it's winter there are many place[s] to ski. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to say that someone or something is suitable for something
dictionaryExamples: Can you suggest a good hotel?
I suggest having the rice with your salmon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest the "Renoir." Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to make something seem likely to be true
dictionaryExamples: The evidence suggests this was the original site of the settlement.
Something about what he said suggested that he wasn't happy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So animals cannot be [as] unhappy as the topic suggests. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: an idea or plan that someone suggests
dictionaryExamples: We don't know where to eat out tonight - have you got any suggestions?
Clara made some very helpful suggestions.
They didn't like my suggestion that we should all share the cost.
I know only one restaurant in town, so I'm open to suggestions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I wan[t] to give you some suggestions that will be useful for you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: something that makes something seem likely to be true
dictionaryExamples: There's no suggestion of any connection between the two men.

sense.def: when you intentionally kill yourself
dictionaryExamples: to attempt/commit suicide
The suicide rate among men between the ages of 16 and 25 has risen alarmingly.
Many suicides occur in prisons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The savage thinks he can change it but fails and commits suicide by hanging himself. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a set of clothes consisting of a jacket and pants or a jacket and skirt made from the same material
dictionaryExamples: She wore a dark blue suit.
All the businessmen were wearing pinstripe suits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got a beautiful suit. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: to do the same as someone else has just done
dictionaryExamples: If other shops lower their prices, we will have to follow suit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Bitten by a insurmountable curiosity she goes to India to [find out] about her and she even follows suit: she ends up [in] the Himalay[a]s driven by a strong desire to know more. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be convenient or suitable for a particular person, situation or occasion
dictionaryExamples: We could go now or this afternoon - whatever time suits you best.
City life seems to suit her.
"How about eight o'clock outside the movie theater?" "That suits me fine."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you find it difficult to arrange your visit for these two dates, please let us know which other Sunday would suit you most. First Certificate in English; B2; Serbian

sense.def: to make someone look more attractive
dictionaryExamples: You should wear more red - it suits you.
That new hairstyle really suits you – you look terrific.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: You have to create some clothes [that] will suit them and will not make them ridiculous. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to be right for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: These plants are better suited to a warm climate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion mixed schools are best suited to [the] current environment. International English Language Testing System; C1; Kazakh

sense.def: the state of being suitable
dictionaryExamples: Nobody could doubt her suitability for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His suitability for the post mentioned in your advertisement is so obvious that it strikes me [as] weird why you hesitate. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: acceptable or right for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The movie may not be suitable for very young children.
It's a nice enough dress but it's not really suitable for a wedding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think they are more suitable for boys than for girls. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in a way that is acceptable or right
dictionaryExamples: I believe the committee was suitably impressed by his résumé.
This book is interesting and suitably challenging for an eight-year-old.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, a lot of people think animals are not suitably looked after - they have to live in small [space]s and, moreover, the weather [is] often rather different from [w]hat animals are used to. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a large rectangular container with a handle for carrying clothes and possessions while traveling
dictionaryExamples: Have you packed/unpacked your suitcase yet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Juliana, I think I left my suitcase in your house. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: an amount of money
dictionaryExamples: Huge sums of money are spent on cleaning up the oil spill.
The sum involved in the sale was not reported.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My poor aunt Yutta [h]as died and she's left me a big sum of money. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to describe briefly the most important facts or characteristics of something
dictionaryExamples: The oral report should  sum up the main points of the written essay.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, young people are interested in many things but in my opinion, music, TV and clothes are issues about which they care more than others. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to describe briefly the main facts or ideas of something
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to briefly summarize the arguments for and against.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This report will attempt to summari[z]e the findings, the trends and changes as well as analy[z]e and explain the reasons for the changes between the periods and evaluate their impact on our lives. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Czech

sense.def: a short, clear description that gives the main facts or ideas about something
dictionaryExamples: He gave a brief summary of events.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Below is a summary of the most relevant points and recommendations. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the season of the year between spring and fall, when the weather is warmest
dictionaryExamples: We usually go away in (the) summer.
We always spend our summers on the island.
I love these warm summer nights.
It was a perfect summer's day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like going to [the] park in the summer. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: the top of a mountain
dictionaryExamples: The climbers hope to reach the summit before nightfall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, heliboarding - that is, when a helicopter carries you to the summit of a mountain and you slide down on your own - is gaining popularity. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: an important meeting between the leaders of two or more governments
dictionaryExamples: a two-day summit
a summit meeting
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In 1994 the UN held a summit on social development in Copenhagen. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to officially order someone to come to a place
dictionaryExamples: He was summoned to a meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result, my parents were summoned to see the headmaster for their daughter's misconduct and bad influence [on] other students. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to ask for someone or something that you need to help you in an emergency
dictionaryExamples: They summoned an ambulance.
She immediately summoned a doctor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The villagers were also relieved that a "bomoh" or witch-doctor had been summoned to exorcise the pontianak. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to make a great effort to produce a quality to help you deal with a situation
dictionaryExamples: summon up his/her/my/the courage
She summoned up all her strength and pushed against the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I summoned up my courage and asked her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: the large, bright star that shines in the sky during the day and provides light and heat for the Earth, or the light and heat that comes from the sun
dictionaryExamples: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.
We thought we'd go out for a walk while the sun was shining.
Sit in the sun where it’s a lot warmer.
I think I got too much sun today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When [the] sun is shining I like walking in Finsbury Park. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to sit or lie in the sun
dictionaryExamples: We spent the day sunbathing on the beach.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather is very good here, so I hope [to] go to the beach with my mother in the mornings to sunbathe. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the day of the week after Saturday and before Monday
dictionaryExamples: They go walking every Sunday.
We're going to visit my aunt and uncle on Sunday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She play[s] tennis every Sunday evening. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Ukrainian

sense.def: dark glasses that you wear to protect your eyes from the sun
dictionaryExamples: Make sure you wear sunglasses outside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left my sunglasses in your house yesterday. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the light from the sun
dictionaryExamples: The garden gets a lot of sunlight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are many sources of light in this world such as sunlight, moonlight, [and] candle light. [...] Nowadays, the electric light has becom[e] part of our lives, especially [at] night.  First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: bright because of light from the sun
dictionaryExamples: We're having the party outdoors, so I'm hoping it'll be sunny.
It was a lovely sunny day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather is always sunny. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: when the sun appears in the morning and the sky becomes light
dictionaryExamples: I always get up before sunrise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have also decided to buy something new. I would like to have a poster, maybe a big black and white photo or a picture of a sunrise, what do you think about that? Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: when the sun disappears in the evening and the sky becomes dark
dictionaryExamples: They close the park at sunset.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can go to Focone Beach, where the sunset is so beautiful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the light and heat that come from the sun
dictionaryExamples: The children were out playing in the sunshine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know I love sunshine. It's my [energy source]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: excellent
dictionaryExamples: We were served some superb seafood.
The show's cast  is superb.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My homemade pizzas are superb, although I say it myself, and I would like to make one for the two of us. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: If someone is superficial, they never think about things that are serious or important.
dictionaryExamples: He's a very superficial person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Are they the role models of an open-minded public or do they set wrong examples by encouraging superficial values based on appearance rather than personality, possessions rather than deeds, and wealth rather than virtues? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: not complete and involving only the most obvious things
dictionaryExamples: superficial knowledge
a superficial resemblance
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many people believe that our school obliges us to gain "superficial" knowledge, since the latter is based on our immature age and on our inadequate experience.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is not deep or basic
dictionaryExamples: Superficially, he is impressive, but his knowledge is really very slight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed too many people today travel too quickly and too superficially to learn anything from their experience. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Ewe

sense.def: not needed, or more than is needed
dictionaryExamples: superfluous details/information
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a very good party and it might be superfluous to add that I got terribly drunk and didn't stagger home until seven in the morning. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: better than other things
dictionaryExamples: This is clearly the work of a superior artist.
She was chosen for the job because she was the superior candidate.
Some people think acoustic recordings are superior to digital ones.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our service is superior in terms of price, but unfortunately doesn't have some features other competitors' services have. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: higher in rank or position than other people
dictionaryExamples: When your superior officer gives you an order, you do it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is my view that he is an excellent applicant who would be able to fulfil any demands of his superior officers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: having the opinion that you are better than other people
dictionaryExamples: I can’t stand Bill’s superior attitude.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The song is about a boy that tries to change his behavior and appearance so that he c[an] feel superior to the others. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: someone in a higher position or at a higher rank than you
dictionaryExamples: We will need a letter of recommendation from one of your superiors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our superiors are always helping to maintain a healthy and co[m]fortable work environment so we do our job more efficiently. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: when something is better than other things
dictionaryExamples: the superiority of modern design
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe a state which felt certain about the superiority of democratic values would not need to forbid any text, or any creative work for that matter. International English Language Testing System; C2; Swedish

sense.def: when you think that you are better than other people
dictionaryExamples: She has an air of superiority.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had an air of superiority and I found her conceited as she was not talking to anybody else except for the teacher. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the form of an adjective or adverb which expresses that the thing or person being described has more of the particular quality than anything or anyone else of the same type
dictionaryExamples: "Richest" is the superlative of "rich."
The whole article was full of superlatives.

sense.def: a large store that sells many different foods and other products used in the home
dictionaryExamples: I have to stop at the supermarket on the way home.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: The supermarket is on Church Street near the post office. 
 Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Farsi

sense.def: used to describe things that cannot be explained by our knowledge of science or nature
dictionaryExamples: supernatural powers/forces
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The book consists of six completely different 'ghost stories' which involve ghosts and supernatural phenomena, something that attracts young readers. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: things that cannot be explained by our knowledge of science or nature
dictionaryExamples: She's very interested in the supernatural.

sense.def: to watch a person or activity to make certain that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The UN is supervising the distribution of aid by local agencies in the disaster area.
The children play while two teachers supervise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our main activity will be to supervise the 8 to 12 year [old]s during those activities. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: when you supervise someone or something
dictionaryExamples: He needs constant supervision.
Students are not allowed to handle these chemicals unless they are under the supervision of a teacher.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The little one was bui[l]t especially for you, so that you can leave your children under the supervision of two well-trained lifeguards. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a person whose job is to supervise someone or something
dictionaryExamples: His supervisor told him to work faster.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I held the post of general supervisor in a campus in Oxford two years ago, and now I am working as a receptionist in a luxurious hotel. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a meal that you eat in the evening
dictionaryExamples: What are we having for supper?
I just heat a quick supper in the microwave if I get home late from work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, I hope you'll come to my house to visit me and my family one day next week and have supper with us. What about Friday? Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: an extra amount or part added to something
dictionaryExamples:
to take a vitamin
                       supplement
a newspaper with a color supplement
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No miracle promises for overnight improvements, no food supplement and pills will bring the desired results. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: to add to something to make it larger or better
dictionaryExamples: He supplements his income by working in a bar in the evenings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was moonlighting to supplement his income. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: added to something
dictionaryExamples: supplementary materials
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This has also been noted by the local authorities, which has resulted in a supplementary grant to the Language Department of our college. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a person or company that provides something that people want or need
dictionaryExamples: They are the world’s largest supplier of baby foods.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have been employed by the Swedish fruit supplier "Northern Fruit Corp.'' for the last 6 years. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: an amount of something that is available for use
dictionaryExamples: the water supply
Medical supplies were desperately needed in areas hit by the earthquake.
Demand for cheap housing far outstrips supply.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please send me a list of [the] clothes [needed] and/or supplies. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to provide things that people want or need, often over a long period of time
dictionaryExamples: Fran supplied the sandwiches for the party.
The dam supplies water and power to San Francisco.
At the beginning of term, students are supplied with a list of books that they are expected to read.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be able to supply you with [a] reference from my employer. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to look after someone by paying for their food, clothes, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Both parents work full time to support their family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sara has to work hard to support her family. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: to help someone, often when they are having problems
dictionaryExamples: My family has always supported me in whatever I've wanted to do.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: You can meet a lot of people [who] can support you in your research, and have a lot of friends too, and large schools have better facilit[ie]s. 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to like a particular sports team, often going to see them play
dictionaryExamples: I'm not a Mets fan - I've always supported the Yankees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I liked it very much because this is the team that I support. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to agree with an idea, group, or person
dictionaryExamples: Do you support their views on the environment?

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I support this idea because I believe that [it] is the [only] way to stop the traffic in cities. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to give encouragement or financial help to someone or something because you want them to succeed
dictionaryExamples: I think it's important to support local businesses by buying locally.
