sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These films are more attractive for older viewers and support the local film business. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: to help to show that something is true
dictionaryExamples: There's no evidence to support his story.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the claims made on your leaflet weren't at all supported by evidence. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to hold the weight of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Is this ladder strong enough to support me?
The building's dome is supported by marble pillars.
When babies first learn to stand, they hold on to something to support themselves.
I wrap my knee to support it when I play tennis.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Next, electricity is transported by high voltage cables supported by towers up to a transformer station. International English Language Testing System; C2; Spanish

sense.def: help or encouragement given to someone when they are having problems
dictionaryExamples: Carol gave me a lot of support when I lost my job.
She's been a great support to my mom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mother needs our support now and I'll go as soon as I can. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: agreement with an idea, group or person
dictionaryExamples: Environmental groups have gained support among young people.
Is there much public support for the proposal?
I signed a petition in support of the human rights campaign.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Julian, I wanted to tell you that you have my moral support. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the money someone needs in order to buy food and clothes and pay for somewhere to live
dictionaryExamples: He is dependent on his father for support.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Re[cei]ving my pocket money las[t] week, I was thinking what would happen if I lo[st] my father's support. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who supports a particular idea, group or person
dictionaryExamples: Supporters of the bill expect it to pass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to supporters of Animal Rights, people wouldn't like being kept in zoos. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: giving help or encouragement
dictionaryExamples: a very supportive friend
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sports facilities were perfect, and the people working in the sport cent[e]r were very friendly and supportive. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used to show that you do not believe that something you have been told is true
dictionaryExamples: Well, the tickets are supposedly in the mail.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "The Bride" sets out to kill the first of Bill's assassins, supposedly the most dangerous person in the world in terms of knives. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to control feelings so that they do not show
dictionaryExamples: I could barely suppress my anger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He tried to suppress his fear. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to prevent information from being known
dictionaryExamples: to suppress evidence/news
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I personally, would bring my child up as a person who is able to discuss and who does not suppress any criticism at all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to stop someone or something by using force
dictionaryExamples: The rebellion was suppressed by government forces.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With the fresh sound of Clarisse's words of freedom and thought, happiness and nature, [there] arises in Montag the need of making a move, of rebelling against a flat and empty system that suppresses the individuality of men. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: having the highest rank or the most importance or at the highest level
dictionaryExamples: the Supreme Court
supreme power
Like most politicians, he has supreme confidence in himself
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would go back to the time when emperors reigned supreme in China and the West had not yet discovered it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: certain
dictionaryExamples: "What's wrong with him?" "I'm not sure."
I'm sure (that) I left my keys on the table.
I’m not sure where they live.
Ben isn't sure whether/if he'll be able to come to the party or not.
Are you sure about that?
She’s sure to win.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's in your room but I'm not sure. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to take action so that you are certain that something happens, is true, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Make sure that the door is locked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So please make sure that you we[ar] old clothes. Key English Test; A2; Albanian

sense.def: without any doubt
dictionaryExamples: I think he's Canadian but I don't know for sure.
One thing's for sure - once the baby's born, your lives will never be the same again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For sure, you'll love Brazil. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be confident of your own abilities, qualities, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She seems a bit more sure of herself since she got a job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is a tall, dark man who walks with confidence and is sure of himself because of his success [i]n the world of business. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to be confident that something is true
dictionaryExamples: He'll win this year, I'm sure of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that I [would be a] really useful person for your company. I'm sure of it. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: something that is certain to happen
dictionaryExamples: Your promotion is a sure thing – you’re the best person for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although I never knew at which time [it] would be, the only sure thing I had in mind was the need to come back home, into your arms! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If you are sure to do something, it is certain that you will do it.
dictionaryExamples: He's sure to go back there again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What she does not know is that her ex-husband has a very serious type of cancer and is sure to pass away in a few months (that is why he agrees to spend his summer with his son, knowing it would be the last). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: as expected
dictionaryExamples: He said the book was on his desk, and sure enough, there it was.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And sure enough, these challenging problems come unsolicited most of the time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hungarian

sense.def: used to show agreement
dictionaryExamples: "Can I take this pen?" "Sure."
"Do you want to come swimming with us?" "Sure."
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Sure! I want to go with you.  
 Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to show that you believe something is very likely
dictionaryExamples: Surely they'd have called us by now to say they're not coming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surely the trip with your parents will be very nice. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used to express surprise that something has happened or is going to happen
dictionaryExamples: Surely you don't expect me to believe that?
Surely he wasn't expecting us to pay the whole amount?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surely it doesn't mean that they have learn[ed] the exciting news? First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to look at information on the Internet by moving from one page to another using electronic links
dictionaryExamples: Are you working or just surfing?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I  like it [very much] because it is cool and I can do a lot of things with it, such as playing games and surfing the Internet. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to ride on a wave as it comes toward land, while standing or lying on a special board
dictionaryExamples: I spent the summer learning how to surf.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really enjoy[ed] learning how to surf, it was terrific. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the top or outside part of something
dictionaryExamples: The sun was reflected on the surface of the water.
Tropical rainforests used to cover 10% of the Earth's surface.
The marble has a smooth, shiny surface.
Neil Armstrong was the first person to set foot on the surface of the moon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When we came back to the surface we just looked like real miners. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: what someone or something seems to be like when you do not know much about them
dictionaryExamples: On the surface, he seemed very pleasant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Miss Marple on the other hand is an old, nervous but gentle lady on the surface but inside that head of hers there is a brain [as] sharp as a knife, cutting through the mysteries she [is] involved in. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the sport of riding on a wave on a special board
dictionaryExamples: Let's go surfing this afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies are surfing and football. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to increase very quickly
dictionaryExamples: Prices surged on the stock exchange.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Followed by a dip bri[ef]ly afterwards, the value surged to close to 100 million tons in 2002. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a large increase in something
dictionaryExamples: a surge in food prices
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also in technology, we have noticed a surge of the newest trends in even the smallest countries. International English Language Testing System; C1; Creole

sense.def: a doctor who is specially trained to perform medical operations
dictionaryExamples: He is a leading surgeon at a London hospital.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have been a surgeon for almost 20 years now, and I have worked in many different situations. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: when a doctor cuts your body open and repairs or removes something
dictionaryExamples: heart surgery
He patient had surgery on his knee.
She has undergone several surgeries on her back and will require more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother had to go through gall-stone surgery in Finland, where she was spending her holiday. First Certificate in English; B2; Norwegian

sense.def: the name that you and other members of your family all have
dictionaryExamples: Her first name is Sarah but I don't know her surname.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her name is Teresa and her surname is unknown to us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be or do better than someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: The book's success surpassed everyone's expectations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I visited "The Acropol" restaurant two weeks ago and to my astonishme[nt] it surpassed all my expectations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an amount of something that is more than you need
dictionaryExamples: Every year we produce a huge surplus of wheat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most developed countries are the ones who didn't have a surplus of food and they had to find a way of producing it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: an event that you did not expect to happen
dictionaryExamples: Don't tell Anne we're having a party for her - I want it to be a surprise.
It was a nice surprise to get home and find the letter.
Last night's heavy snow came as a complete surprise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last month I had a beautiful surprise for my birthday because my sister boug[ht] [me] a new bike. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the feeling that you get when something happens that you did not expect
dictionaryExamples: He looked at her in/with surprise.
To my surprise, they gave us everything we asked for.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He stared at me in surprise and didn't say anything. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to make someone feel surprise
dictionaryExamples: The news surprised everyone.
It doesn't surprise me that she wants to leave.
It won't surprise anyone to learn that the offer has been rejected.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I saw a blue light that surprised me, I was scared. [A] strange creature was standing in front of me. [I]t was fat and ugly and then it tried to grab me... Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: feeling surprise because something has happened that you did not expect
dictionaryExamples: You’d be surprised how quickly the time passes.
I was surprised at/by her response.
I'm not surprised (that) he didn't come.
I wouldn't be surprised if he resigned.
We were pleasantly surprised to find that the hotel was so comfortable.
She looked at him with a surprised expression on her face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Jo, I'm surprised you can't find the information about the art class. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: not expected and making someone feel surprised
dictionaryExamples: He gave a very surprising answer.
The election results were not surprising.
I must say that it's surprising to find you agreeing with me for once.
There was a surprising amount of talk about resignations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That was a little bit surprising because I'm pretty small and it's hard for me to find clothes that really fit me! Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: unexpectedly or in a way that is unusual
dictionaryExamples: These chairs are surprisingly comfortable.
Not surprisingly the kids slept late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surprisingly, I saw my gr[a]ndmother walking in the rain! Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: to stop fighting and admit that you have been beaten
dictionaryExamples: Rebel troops are refusing to surrender.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Without the fire Ralph and Piggy have to surrender and as Piggy now has lost his vision he becomes weak and vulnerable [and] he must die - "The weak must go to the wall". Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to be or go everywhere around something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Snow-capped mountains surround the city.
Dense woods surrounded the house.
Jeanne sat at her desk, surrounded by books and papers.
She's surrounded by the people she loves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The place I've enjoyed [most] is a small lake surrounded by very [tall] trees and a lot of bushes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: If a feeling or situation surrounds an event, it is closely connected with it.
dictionaryExamples: Mystery still surrounds the exact circumstances of his death.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, there was at this point nothing pleasant about the atmosphere surrounding the house. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: in a position around something
dictionaryExamples:
A lot of the children in this school come in from the surrounding
                         communities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If all of you would help by using these facilities, our village could be very attractive  to people from surrounding villages, which could be very good for the economy of our village. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the place where someone or something is and the things that are in it
dictionaryExamples: beautiful/comfortable surroundings
Are you used to your new surroundings yet?
Some butterflies blend in with their surroundings so well that it's difficult to see them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The larger animals who [are]n't threaten[e]d should li[v]e in their natural surroundings. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: an examination of opinions, behavior, etc., made by asking people questions
dictionaryExamples: A recent survey found/showed that 58% of people did not know where their heart is.
They are conducting/carrying out/doing a survey.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have made a little survey on the subject of my report and I have [found] that most of the pupils of our school consider that the region and the area around [the] school should be filmed first. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to ask people questions in order to find out about their opinions or behavior
dictionaryExamples: Seventy-five percent of those surveyed were in favor of the proposal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of the people surveyed, only 22% of the people responded that they never visit the park. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to look at or examine something carefully
dictionaryExamples: I got out of the car to survey the damage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This means that we need a small team to survey the area first, and I am very happy to lead this team. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: when someone or something continues to live or exist, especially after a difficult or dangerous situation
dictionaryExamples: The doctors told my wife I had a 50/50 chance of survival.
His main concern is to ensure his own political survival.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For many animals zoos are [their] only hope for survival: for example, [the] Chinese panda or white eagle. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to continue to live or exist, especially after almost dying or being destroyed
dictionaryExamples: The baby was born with a heart problem and only survived for a few hours.
These plants cannot survive in very cold conditions.
The building survived the earthquake with little damage.
The family is struggling to survive on very little money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They struggle to survive. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: someone who continues to live after almost dying because of an accident, illness, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Rescuers have given up hope of finding any more survivors.
He was the sole  survivor of the plane crash.
She's a cancer survivor/a survivor of cancer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were the only survivors. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to think that something is probably true, or is likely to happen
dictionaryExamples: They suspected (that) he was lying.
I suspect she won't come - she's very busy.
Investigators suspect the outbreak was caused by contamination at the packing plant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I started to suspect that something wrong was happening there and I was about [to] leav[e] that place when I heard some of my friends calling for me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to think that someone may have committed a crime or done something bad
dictionaryExamples: The police suspect him of stealing the car.
Authorities have the power to evict residents when they suspect criminal activity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But other people were suspected of having killed them. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to not trust someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She suspected his motives for offering to help.

sense.def: someone who may have committed a crime
dictionaryExamples: He's the prime suspect  in the case.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had never thought that Doctor Quimper might [have] been a suspect, as well. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to not allow someone to go to work or school for a period of time because they have done something wrong
dictionaryExamples: Two students were suspended for damaging school property.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The director decided to suspend the girl because she had be[en] rude. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to stop something happening or existing for a short time
dictionaryExamples: The ferry service has been suspended for the day because of bad weather.
Relief agencies suspended aid yesterday.
I'm suspending judgment  on the book I'm reading until I've finished it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first the electrical and gas power were cut off and the transport was suspended but now everything is working. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the feeling of excitement or nervousness that you have when you are waiting for something to happen
dictionaryExamples: There is a gradual build-up of suspense throughout the movie.
What's your answer then? Don't keep me in suspense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Exciting, fun and full of suspense, I'm sure I'm going to enjoy it, and remember it as a very good time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Arabic

sense.def: a belief or idea that something may be true
dictionaryExamples: Some people have suspicions that he may not be able to play at all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I asked my mother what had happened and she confirmed my suspicions. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a feeling or belief that someone has committed a crime or done something wrong
dictionaryExamples: His strange behavior raised suspicions among his co-workers.
She is on of four people under suspicion.
In this particular case, they are above/beyond suspicion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some of us were told to go there and to kill those who [were] under suspicion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: making you feel that something illegal is happening or that something is wrong
dictionaryExamples: suspicious  behavior/circumstances
Neighbors were asked if they had noticed anything suspicious.
The fire at the bank is being treated as suspicious.
I don't really find it suspicious that he isn't home yet - he doesn't usually get in before seven.
There's a suspicious-looking van parked outside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Talking to Calloway made Martins very suspicious, because he [had] always thought of him as a nice and decen[t] person. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: not trusting someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Many of them remain  suspicious of journalists.
My mother has a very suspicious nature.
He gave me a suspicious look.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Paul was suspicious and asked her if she was al[l] right. [Jane] replied with a yes, but she looked nervous. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: in a way that shows that you do not trust someone or something
dictionaryExamples: He looked at her suspiciously.
He sniffed the soup suspiciously.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The old man, who was going upstairs, stopped and looked at us very suspiciously. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to cause or allow something to continue for a period of time
dictionaryExamples: The team may not be able to sustain this level of performance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And they have to work hard to reach and sustain this high level. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to support someone or something so that they can live or exist
dictionaryExamples: The money he received was hardly enough to sustain a wife and five children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The one concern I have is the ability of such a job to financially sustain an entire family. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: the degree to which something is sustainable
dictionaryExamples: We have to think about the sustainability of these energy sources.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: State and Society should be held responsible for ensuring the environment's sustainability and for preventing further damage. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: able to continue over a period of time
dictionaryExamples: sustainable development/growth
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is as you might know the aim of the concept of sustainable development. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: causing little or no damage to the environment and therefore able to continue for a long time
dictionaryExamples: sustainable energy
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being an engineer in the field of renewable and sustainable energy which includes solar energy, hydropower and wind energy, I can say I am quite [knowledgeable about] the specific problem of environmental issues and about how to mitigate the serious impacts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to move your throat in order to make food or drink go down
dictionaryExamples: My throat is so sore that it really hurts when I swallow.
The snake swallowed the bird whole.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I swallowed my eggs and bread and checked my bag for the fourth and last time. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to accept something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: They found the final decision hard to swallow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Occasionally he would beat her, but she just swallowed it with a sense of helplessness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to not show your feelings and to not allow them to affect the way that you behave
dictionaryExamples: I swallowed my pride and asked them for help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has had to put up with all the psychological harm that her husband has put her through and at the same time, she has had to keep on struggling for her children, never givin[g] in; holding back her tears, swallowing her pride just for the benefit of her daughters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a large, white bird with a long neck which lives on lakes and rivers
dictionaryExamples: We saw two swans gliding down the river with their signets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ugly duckling became a beautiful swan. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to give something to someone and get something from them in return
dictionaryExamples: Would you mind if Dave swapped places with you for a bit?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People come here to swap opinions and news. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to use language which people think is rude or offensive
dictionaryExamples:
He
 started swearing for no good reason.
When the taxi driver started to swear at him, he walked off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I heard the ringing of the phone I became so furious that as soon as I answered the phone, I started swearing at it. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to make a serious promise
dictionaryExamples: swear allegiance/to tell the truth
I don't know anything about what happened, I swear (it).

I swear to you I’ll take care
 of them.
I think she’s upstairs, but I wouldn’t swear to it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That day I swore to myself that I would never trust anybody again. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: used to say that you are sure something is true
dictionaryExamples: I could have sworn that she said she lived in Canterbury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would have sworn that they were our neighbor's dogs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: the salty colorless liquid that comes through your skin when you are hot, nervous or ill
dictionaryExamples: The sweat was pouring off me ten minutes into the game.
By the time we'd climbed to the top of the hill, we were covered in sweat.

She wiped the beads  
                      of sweat from her forehead.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Pearls of sweat appeared on her foreh[e]ad. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to produce liquid through your skin because you are hot, nervous or ill
dictionaryExamples: The room was hot and I was starting to sweat.
The prisoners were sweating with fear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I began to sweat and my fear changed to panic when we opened a door. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a warm piece of clothing which covers the top of your body and is pulled on over your head or buttons down the front
dictionaryExamples: Put a sweater on if you're cold.
a V-neck/turtleneck sweater
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got lots of present[s], for example I got a nice sweater. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: a piece of clothing made of soft cotton which covers the top of your body and is pulled on over your head or zips up the front
dictionaryExamples: a hooded sweatshirt
She was dressed casually in jeans and a sweatshirt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, I'm always wearing tight-fitting, blue jeans, I really love them as they're always in fashion, and if it's cold, a v-neck, long sleeved sweatshirt. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to clean the floor using a brush
dictionaryExamples: I swept the floor.
He swept up the pieces of broken glass.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found your watch yesterday, while I was sweeping the floor. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to be pushed or carried along in a forceful way
dictionaryExamples: Many trees were swept away in the flood.
They got swept along by the crowd.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, we were swept away by an avalanche. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to move quickly, especially in a way that shows you think you are important
dictionaryExamples: She swept past me in the corridor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Arriving at the central station, we wee met by a roar of "We are red! We are white! We are Danish dynamite!" and let ourselves be swept along with the stream of people from all over the suburbs heading toward the city hall square of our Capital. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: with a taste like sugar
dictionaryExamples: The pineapple was sweet and juicy.
Do you want your pancakes sweet or savoury?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like rice and sweet dishes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: attractive, often because of being small
dictionaryExamples: Look at that kitten - isn't she sweet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a toy bear and it's so sweet. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: kind and friendly
dictionaryExamples: It was really sweet of you to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you ever so much for the present you've sent me! It was really sweet of you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: sweet food such as cake or candy
dictionaryExamples: Rosie tries to avoid sweets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yes, if you can bring some sweets and some snacks, it would be great! Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Japanese

sense.def: happening or moving quickly
dictionaryExamples: a swift response
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Individual performances were amazing. Jimmy Page's heavy blues riffs, his swift solos and his talent [for] compos[ing] songs of an incredible richness clearly showed he was still one of the greatest figures of rock 'n' roll. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: quickly
dictionaryExamples: The authorities have moved swiftly to quell the violence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Time seems to flow more swiftly when we need it most, and those two days went by without us having finished the paper. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to move through water by moving your body
dictionaryExamples: We spent the day on the beach but it was too cold to swim.
I swam two miles this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this place because I like to swim. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a time when you swim
dictionaryExamples: Do you want to go for swim this afternoon?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to play vo[l]leyball on the beach and have a swim in the sea. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: someone who is swimming or who can swim
dictionaryExamples: Oliver is a very strong swimmer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is the best swimmer in the club, much faster than I could [ever] be. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the activity of moving through water by moving your body
dictionaryExamples: Let's go swimming today.
The doctor recommended swimming as the best all-round exercise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to go swimming and cycling. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: an area of water that has been made for people to swim in
dictionaryExamples: an indoor/outdoor swimming pool
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like [it] when we go to [the] swimming pool. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a piece of clothing you wear to go swimming
dictionaryExamples: I bought a new swimsuit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's hot here, but I have my swimsuit, so, this afternoon I'll go to the beach or to the swimming pool. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: to move smoothly backward and forward, or to make something do this
dictionaryExamples: He walked briskly along the path swinging his rolled-up umbrella.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When Mary ent[e]red the bar, the room was empty and there was a rope swinging from a beam. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a chair hanging on two ropes that children sit on and swing backward and forward
dictionaryExamples: Jake wanted me to push him on the swing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you remember the swing by the big tree in my garden? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to change from one thing to another
dictionaryExamples: She started studying English at college, but switched to Business Studies in her second year.
He's just switched jobs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For many years I had created my system under MS-DOS (Disk Operating System), but two years ago I switched and since them I've worked with Unix. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

blocks.phrasalVerb: switch off sth or switch sth off

sense.def: to turn off a light, television, etc. by using a switch
dictionaryExamples: Remember to switch the computer off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They couldn't call me because my phone was switched off. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

blocks.phrasalVerb: switch on sth or switch sth on

sense.def: to turn on a light, television, etc. by using a switch
dictionaryExamples: Could you switch the light on?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will switch on a light and will sing "Happy Birthday" and the party will begin. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: a small object that you push up or down with your finger to turn something electrical on or off
dictionaryExamples: a light switch
Can you flip the switch?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I turned off the switch until the end of the day. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: larger than usual
dictionaryExamples: a bruised, swollen face
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I cried almost all day and wanted to go home as quick[ly] as possible but suddenly, someone took a photograph of me with swollen eyes. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a weapon with a long sharp metal blade and a handle, used especially in the past
dictionaryExamples: He rode toward me, waving his sword in the air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took the ancient sword in my hands and felt the power flow through my veins. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: something that has both a positive and a negative effect
dictionaryExamples: Being that intelligent is a double-edged sword - he finds it difficult to talk to ordinary people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you might see, technological advancements are a double-edged sword. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a list of the subjects that are included in a course of study
dictionaryExamples: Freud isn't on the syllabus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Physical Education is now generally considered an important part of a person's progress towards a mature, well-rounded adult human being, a fact that is reflected by the inclusion of Physical Education as [an] obligatory subject in national school syllabi. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a sign, shape or object that is used to represent something else
dictionaryExamples: Five interlocking rings is the symbol of the Olympic games.
The wheel in the Indian flag is a symbol of peace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This was the first time it arrived and it was a point of hope for all the friends of nature and particularly for the World Wildlife Fund, wh[o] have chosen the panda [as their] symbol. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: representing something else
dictionaryExamples: symbolic meanings
The Capitol building has come to be symbolic of the government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reason why people value certain items so greatly is that these items have a great symbolic value to their owners. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: showing that you understand and care about someone's problems
dictionaryExamples: He suffers from back trouble too, so he was very sympathetic about my problem.
She was very sympathetic when I told her about my situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nobody wants to talk to him apart from Alice, she feels sympathetic and understands him. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: agreeing with or supporting someone's ideas or actions
dictionaryExamples: He was sympathetic to their views.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you'll be sympathetic to our demands and take some action. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to understand and care about someone's problems
dictionaryExamples: It's a really bad situation - I do sympathize with her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In our lives, it is crucial that we develop relationships between other individuals, in order to have somebody to sympathize with us in bad times and stand on our side to help us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to agree with or support someone's ideas or actions
dictionaryExamples: I sympathize with the general aims of the organization.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a result, they tend to sympathize with more radical groups and parties in order to support a change in the current system. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when you show that you understand and care about someone's problems
dictionaryExamples: The president has sent a message of sympathy to the relatives of the dead soldiers.
I don't have much sympathy for her - I think she's brought her troubles on herself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No matter how sensitive or impassive one's attitude towards animals is, after having thought it over thoroughly most of us feel deep sorrow and sympathy for the poor creatures kept in cages. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: agreement with or support for someone's ideas or actions
dictionaryExamples: Scott was in sympathy with this view.

sense.def: a physical feeling or problem which shows that you have a particular illness
dictionaryExamples: He's complaining of all the usual flu symptoms - fever, headache, muscle ache.
He had symptoms of food poisoning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We asked her what had happened and she told us she had some w[ei]rd symptoms so she went for an examination to see what was wrong. She finally discovered that... she was pregnant! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a problem that is caused by and shows a more serious problem
dictionaryExamples: This endless debate is a symptom of our lack of confidence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The problem with tackling homelessness is that it is just a symptom. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a word or phrase that means the same as another word or phrase
dictionaryExamples: 'Quick' and 'fast' are synonyms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dynamic, Go-Getters, Ambitious, Stalwarts - These are just some of the synonyms that the young people of today's generation are known by. International English Language Testing System; C2; Malayalam

sense.def: If one thing is synonymous with another, they are very closely connected with each other in people's minds.
dictionaryExamples: It is a country where wealth is synonymous with corruption.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Working is synonymous with integration in the society. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If one word is synonymous with another, they have the same meaning.
dictionaryExamples: Would you say that 'idle' is completely synonymous with 'lazy'?

sense.def: a set of connected pieces of equipment that operate together
dictionaryExamples: They've had an alarm system installed at their home.
a central air-conditioning system
The computer system keeps crashing and no one is able to figure out why.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They had a new sound system which is very loud. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a way or method of doing things
dictionaryExamples: the legal/education system
the public transportation system
We'll have to work out a new filing system.
the metric system of measuring and weighing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You will have the possibility to get to know our political system. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: parts of the body that work together in order to make something happen
dictionaryExamples: the body's digestive/immune system
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now stem cells are widely used in cosmetic surgery - this extremely expensive treatment is offered to well-off people who want to look younger and strengthen their immune system. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: done using a fixed and organized plan
dictionaryExamples: the systematic collection and analysis of information
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On account of systematic and thorough rationalization in almost every sector of Western economics, workers are not needed as they were in the fifties or sixties. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: in a systematic way
dictionaryExamples: We went through all the documents systematically.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unemployment is a major problem today but it can be dealt with systematically and it is worth investing in a solution to this problem because of the social implications. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese
